Description A: The lamprey swims by means of a wave of muscle contractions traveling down one side of the body, 180° out of phase with a similar wave on the opposite side.
Description B: The lamprey swims by means of synchronized muscle contractions on both sides of the body occurring simultaneously.

Description A: Stance begins with contact of the foot or paw with the ground, and during early stance, the knee and ankle joints flex.
Description B: Stance begins with contact of the foot or paw with the ground, and during early stance, the knee and ankle joints extend.

Description A: In intact cats, the central pattern generator can produce both the rhythm and the spatiotemporal pattern of locomotion even without sensory input.
Description B: The central pattern generator in intact cats requires sensory feedback to produce both rhythm and spatiotemporal patterns of locomotion.

Description A: The step cycle is divided into four phases: flexion (F), initial extension (E1), second extension (E2), and third extension (E3).
Description B: The step cycle is divided into four phases: flexion (F), initial extension (E1), second flexion (F2), and third extension (E3).

Description A: The spinal cord is sufficient to generate the rhythm underlying locomotion and much of the specific pattern of muscle activity.
Description B: The spinal cord alone cannot generate the rhythm underlying locomotion without input from the brainstem.

Description A: Coordination of left–right alternation during locomotion depends on inhibitory commissural neurons crossing the midline.
Description B: Coordination of left–right alternation during locomotion depends on excitatory commissural neurons crossing the midline.

Description A: Central pattern generators (CPGs) are modular and allow independent control of activity around different joints.
Description B: Central pattern generators (CPGs) are rigid structures that do not allow independent joint control.

Description A: In quadrupedal locomotion, circuits controlling the forelimb are located in the cervical enlargement, and circuits controlling the hindlimb are in the lower thoracic and lumbar spinal cord.
Description B: In quadrupedal locomotion, circuits controlling the forelimb and hindlimbs are concentrated in the cervical part of the spinal cord.

Description A: The rhythm of swimming in lamprey is produced by excitatory glutamatergic neurons, which excite commissural inhibitory neurons and motor neurons.
Description B: The rhythm of swimming in lamprey is produced by inhibitory GABAergic neurons, which inhibit commissural neurons and motor neurons.

Description A: During locomotion, proprioceptive input from the hip joint helps regulate phase transitions, such as the initiation of the swing phase.
Description B: During locomotion, proprioceptive input from the hip joint suppresses phase transitions, delaying the swing phase.

Description A: Mammals generally have a higher upper frequency limit of hearing compared to nonmammalian species, which are limited to frequencies below 12 to 14 kHz.
Description B: Mammals generally have a lower upper frequency limit of hearing compared to nonmammalian species, which can hear beyond 100 kHz.

Description A: The synaptic ribbons in hair cells are surrounded by synaptic vesicles that are 35 to 40 nm in diameter.
Description B: The synaptic ribbons in hair cells are surrounded by synaptic vesicles that are 100 to 150 nm in diameter.

Description A: The cochlea amplifies weak sound stimuli and introduces distortions that contribute to sound perception.
Description B: The cochlea filters out weak sound stimuli and eliminates distortions to preserve sound fidelity.

Description A: Approximately 90% of spiral ganglion cells terminate on inner hair cells, ensuring robust auditory signal transmission.
Description B: Approximately 90% of spiral ganglion cells terminate on outer hair cells, ensuring robust auditory signal transmission.

Description A: Hair cells amplify their inputs to enhance sensitivity, sharpen frequency selectivity, and widen the range of detectable stimulus levels.
Description B: Hair cells dampen their inputs to reduce sensitivity, narrow frequency selectivity, and restrict the range of detectable stimulus levels.

Description A: Outer hair cells receive inputs from the brainstem that cause hyperpolarization, which desensitizes the cochlea.
Description B: Outer hair cells receive inputs from the brainstem that cause depolarization, which enhances cochlear sensitivity.

Description A: Electrical resonance in nonmammalian ears tunes hair cells to specific frequencies using factors like cochlear K+ channels.
Description B: Electrical resonance in mammalian ears tunes hair cells to specific frequencies using factors like cochlear K+ channels.

Description A: The cochlear prosthesis leverages the tonotopic organization of the cochlea to restore a degree of hearing.
Description B: The cochlear prosthesis bypasses the tonotopic organization of the cochlea to restore a degree of hearing.

Description A: Sensorineural hearing loss commonly results from the degeneration of cochlear hair cells and their afferent fibers.
Description B: Sensorineural hearing loss commonly results from excessive regeneration of cochlear hair cells and their afferent fibers.

Description A: Distortions introduced by the cochlea are a hallmark of sensitive hearing and are used to screen newborns for hearing deficits.
Description B: Distortions introduced by the cochlea degrade sensitive hearing and hinder the screening of newborns for hearing deficits.

Description A: Some ion channels can be blocked by common ions such as Mg2+, Ca2+, Na+, and polyamines like spermine.
Description B: Some ion channels can be blocked exclusively by rare ions not normally present in cells, such as Francium and Astatine.

Description A: Voltage-gated channels often open when the cytoplasmic side of the membrane becomes more positive (depolarization).
Description B: Voltage-gated channels often open when the cytoplasmic side of the membrane becomes more negative (hyperpolarization).

Description A: Transitions between ion channel states typically occur in a few milliseconds on average.
Description B: Transitions between ion channel states typically occur over several hours on average.

Description A: Ligand-gated channels can enter a refractory state when exposed to an agonist for a prolonged period, a process called desensitization.
Description B: Ligand-gated channels can enter a refractory state automatically without the presence of any agonist.

Description A: The S4 segment of voltage-gated ion channels contains positively charged residues such as arginine or lysine, which function as a voltage sensor.
Description B: The S4 segment of voltage-gated ion channels contains negatively charged residues such as tyrosine and glutamate, which function as a voltage sensor.

Description A: Voltage-gated Na+ and Ca2+ channels are composed of a large subunit containing four repeats of a six-segment motif.
Description B: Voltage-gated Na+ and Ca2+ channels are composed of a single small subunit with two transmembrane segments.

Description A: Calmodulin binds to some voltage-gated Ca2+ channels to inactivate them in response to increased cytoplasmic Ca2+ levels.
Description B: Calmodulin activates voltage-gated Ca2+ channels by decreasing cytoplasmic Ca2+ levels.

Description A: TRP channels are nonselective cation channels involved in sensory processes like pain, heat, and cold sensation.
Description B: TRP channels are exclusively chloride channels responsible for taste and smell responses.

Description A: The pore region of potassium channels forms the selectivity filter allowing passage of K+ ions but excluding smaller Na+ ions.
Description B: The pore region of potassium channels allows any positively charged ions, including K+ and Na+, to pass equally.

Description A: Inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels occurs via a conformational change separate from the activation process.
Description B: Inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels occurs as a simple reversal of the activation process.

Description A: Peripheral nervous system nerves have higher regenerative potential compared to central nervous system nerves after injury.
Description B: Central nervous system nerves have higher regenerative potential compared to peripheral nervous system nerves after injury.

Description A: Schwann cells in the peripheral nervous system promote axonal regeneration by producing growth factors and removing myelin debris.
Description B: Oligodendrocytes in the central nervous system promote axonal regeneration by producing growth factors and removing myelin debris.

Description A: Wallerian degeneration is a regulated and active process involving protease activation and cytoskeletal disassembly.
Description B: Wallerian degeneration is a passive process due to the simple loss of nutrient supply from the cell body.

Description A: Central nervous system injuries often lead to the formation of a glial scar, which inhibits axonal regeneration.
Description B: Peripheral nervous system injuries often lead to the formation of a glial scar, which inhibits axonal regeneration.

Description A: Axotomy leads to chromatolysis, during which the neuron's cell body swells and RNA/protein synthesis increases.
Description B: Axotomy leads to chromatolysis, during which the neuron's cell body shrinks and RNA/protein synthesis decreases.

Description A: Myelin in the central nervous system contains growth-inhibiting factors that limit axonal regeneration.
Description B: Myelin in the central nervous system contains growth-promoting factors that enhance axonal regeneration.

Description A: Neurogenesis in certain regions of the adult mammalian brain challenges the traditional belief that no new neurons can form in adulthood.
Description B: Neurogenesis does not occur in the adult mammalian brain, confirming the belief that no new neurons form in adulthood.

Description A: In Wlds mutant mice, distal stumps of axons persist much longer after injury due to stabilization by mutant NMNAT1 protein.
Description B: In Wlds mutant mice, distal stumps of axons degenerate faster after injury due to destabilization by mutant NMNAT1 protein.

Description A: Reactive astrocytes contribute to the formation of a glial scar, which inhibits central nervous system regeneration.
Description B: Reactive astrocytes enhance axonal regrowth by dissolving scars and promoting axonal regeneration in the central nervous system.

Description A: Insertion of a peripheral nerve graft into the central nervous system can promote regeneration of injured central axons.
Description B: Insertion of a central nerve graft into the peripheral nervous system can promote regeneration of injured peripheral axons.

Description A: Each miniature end-plate potential (mEPSP) represents the action of a multimolecular packet or quantum of acetylcholine.
Description B: Each miniature end-plate potential (mEPSP) represents the action of a single acetylcholine molecule.

Description A: The mean open time for acetylcholine receptor-channels is approximately 1 ms, allowing the movement of 17,000 ions per opening.
Description B: The mean open time for acetylcholine receptor-channels is approximately 1 ms, allowing the movement of 170,000 ions per opening.

Description A: Acetylcholine receptor-channels have a conductance of 30 pS and behave like simple ohmic resistors.
Description B: Acetylcholine receptor-channels have a conductance of 300 pS and behave like fluctuating resistors.

Description A: The reversal potential of acetylcholine receptor-channels is at 0 mV due to the weighted average of equilibrium potentials for sodium and potassium ions.
Description B: The reversal potential of acetylcholine receptor-channels is at -70 mV due to the dominance of potassium equilibrium potential.

Description A: The pore diameter of acetylcholine receptor-channels is approximately 0.6 nm, making them permeable to Na+, K+ and Ca2+.
Description B: The pore diameter of acetylcholine receptor-channels is approximately 0.1 nm, making them impermeable to sodium ions.

Description A: During synaptic transmission, more than 200,000 acetylcholine receptor-channels open simultaneously, generating a total current of −500 nA.
Description B: During synaptic transmission, approximately 2,000 acetylcholine receptor-channels open simultaneously, generating a total current of −500 pA.

Description A: Nicotinic acetylcholine receptor-channels open when two acetylcholine molecules bind to extracellular binding sites.
Description B: Nicotinic acetylcholine receptor-channels open when a single acetylcholine molecule binds to extracellular binding sites.

Description A: Acetylcholine receptor subunits are homologous proteins with four membrane-spanning alpha helices each.
Description B: Acetylcholine receptor subunits are homologous proteins without any membrane-spanning regions.

Description A: In the open state, acetylcholine receptor-channels allow sodium and potassium ions to pass without discrimination.
Description B: In the open state, acetylcholine receptor-channels only allow calcium ions to pass and exclude sodium and potassium ions.

Description A: The autoimmune disorder myasthenia gravis results from antibodies binding to the extracellular domain of acetylcholine receptors.
Description B: The autoimmune disorder myasthenia gravis results from antibodies enhancing the function of acetylcholine receptors.

Description A: The primary somatosensory cortex (S-I) comprises four cytoarchitectonic regions: Brodmann’s areas 3a, 3b, 1, and 2.
Description B: The primary somatosensory cortex (S-I) comprises three cytoarchitectonic regions: Brodmann’s areas 3a, 3b, and 1.

Description A: The secondary somatosensory cortex (S-II) is located on the upper bank of the lateral sulcus and on the parietal operculum.
Description B: The secondary somatosensory cortex (S-II) is located on the lower bank of the central sulcus and on the parietal operculum.

Description A: Neurons in areas 3b and 1 of S-I process details of surface texture, whereas those in area 2 represent the size and shape of objects.
Description B: Neurons in areas 3b and 1 of S-I represent the size and shape of objects, whereas those in area 2 process details of surface texture.

Description A: The receptive fields of neurons in S-II are often bilateral, representing symmetric, mirror-image locations on both hands.
Description B: The receptive fields of neurons in S-II are unilateral, only representing one hand at a time.

Description A: Thalamocortical axons terminate primarily on clusters of stellate cells in layer IV of the cortex.
Description B: Thalamocortical axons terminate primarily on clusters of pyramidal cells in layer IV of the cortex.

Description A: Pyramidal neurons form the principal excitatory class of somatosensory cortex and compose approximately 80% of S-I neurons.
Description B: Pyramidal neurons form the principal inhibitory class of somatosensory cortex and compose approximately 80% of S-I neurons.

Description A: The homunculus represents different parts of the body in proportion to their importance to the sense of touch.
Description B: The homunculus represents different parts of the body in proportion to their size on the skin.

Description A: The somatosensory cortex is organized into vertical columns that are approximately 300 to 600 μm wide.
Description B: The somatosensory cortex is organized into vertical columns that are approximately 3 to 6 μm wide.

Description A: Injury to a peripheral nerve can result in the cortical projection targets acquiring new receptive fields.
Description B: Injury to a peripheral nerve permanently eliminates the cortical projection targets, leaving them unresponsive.

Description A: Cortical magnification is greatest in body regions with the highest density of touch receptors, such as the lips and fingers.
Description B: Cortical magnification is distributed equally among all body regions, regardless of receptor density.

Description A: The paramedian pontine reticular formation contains a family of burst neurons responsible for generating the saccadic pulse.
Description B: The paramedian pontine reticular formation contains omnipause neurons responsible for generating the saccadic pulse.

Description A: Medium-lead excitatory burst neurons make direct excitatory connections to motor neurons and interneurons in the ipsilateral abducens nucleus.
Description B: Medium-lead excitatory burst neurons make direct inhibitory connections to motor neurons and interneurons in the ipsilateral abducens nucleus.

Description A: The superior colliculus integrates visual and motor information into oculomotor signals for the brain stem.
Description B: The superior colliculus functions only as a motor command center without integrating visual information.

Description A: Lesions of the paramedian pontine reticular formation result in paralysis of ipsiversive horizontal gaze while sparing contraversive and vertical saccades.
Description B: Lesions of the paramedian pontine reticular formation result in complete paralysis of saccadic movements, including vertical and contraversive saccades.

Description A: Omnipause neurons discharge at a high rate except immediately before, during, and just after a saccade.
Description B: Omnipause neurons discharge continuously even during saccades.

Description A: The oculomotor vermis of the cerebellum, acting through the caudal fastigial nucleus, controls the duration and accuracy of saccades.
Description B: The oculomotor vermis of the cerebellum acts exclusively through the medullary nucleus to control saccade duration.

Description A: Horizontal saccades are generated in the pontine reticular formation, specifically in the paramedian pontine reticular formation.
Description B: Horizontal saccades are generated in the mesencephalic reticular formation, specifically in the rostral interstitial nucleus of the medial longitudinal fasciculus.

Description A: Neurons in the superficial layers of the superior colliculus respond to visual stimuli and are organized in a retinotopic map of the visual field.
Description B: Neurons in the superficial layers of the superior colliculus primarily respond to auditory stimuli rather than visual stimuli.

Description A: Lesions of the frontal eye field alone cause transient contralateral neglect and paresis of contraversive gaze, which recover rapidly.
Description B: Lesions of the frontal eye field alone cause permanent deficits in vertical saccades with no recovery over time.

Description A: The medial vestibular nucleus and nucleus prepositus hypoglossi integrate velocity signals into position signals for horizontal saccades.
Description B: The medial vestibular nucleus and nucleus prepositus hypoglossi primarily generate saccadic burst signals for vertical eye movements.

Description A: Unmyelinated C fibers mediate thermal and noxious stimuli in both muscles and the skin.
Description B: Myelinated C fibers mediate thermal and noxious stimuli in muscles and the skin.

Description A: Large-diameter unmyelinated fibers conduct action potentials more slowly than myelinated fibers due to increased internal resistance along the axon.
Description B: Large-diameter myelinated fibers conduct action potentials faster than smaller fibers because their internal resistance to current flow is low and nodes of Ranvier are widely spaced.

Description A: The conduction velocity of large myelinated fibers in meters per second is approximately six times their axon diameter in micrometers.
Description B: The conduction velocity of large myelinated fibers in meters per second is approximately three times their axon diameter in micrometers.

Description A: Group III muscle sensory fibers are unmyelinated and signal painful trauma using a conduction velocity of 4-36 m/s.
Description B: Group III muscle sensory fibers are small myelinated fibers that signal trauma with a conduction velocity of 4-36 m/s.

Description A: Group II fibers in muscle innervate Golgi tendon organs that signal muscle contraction.
Description B: Group II fibers in muscle innervate secondary spindle endings and receptors in joint capsules that mediate proprioception.

Description A: Nerve conduction studies measure the time it takes action potentials to travel between the spinal cord and the brain stem.
Description B: Nerve conduction studies measure conduction velocities between electrode pairs placed along peripheral nerves.

Description A: Piezo1 ion channels are primarily found in sensory DRG neurons mediating touch.
Description B: Piezo1 ion channels are primarily found in non-neural tissues such as blood vessels and the kidney.

Description A: Heat nociceptors are mediated exclusively by C fibers with TRPV1/2 channels for detecting temperatures above 45°C.
Description B: Heat nociceptors are mediated by Aδ fibers with TRPV1/2 channels for detecting temperatures above 45°C.

Description A: Merkel cells work independently of sensory axons and are not affected by knockout experiments targeting Piezo2.
Description B: Merkel cells express Piezo2 channels and release neurotransmitters during sustained pressure on the skin.

Description A: C-LTMR fibers in hairy skin respond to gentle tactile stimuli and may mediate social or pleasurable touch.
Description B: Aδ LTMR fibers in hairy skin exclusively mediate social or pleasurable touch from tactile stimuli.

Description A: Ionotropic receptors open ion channels directly as part of the receptor macromolecule, leading to fast and brief effects.
Description B: Ionotropic receptors open ion channels indirectly via secondary messengers, causing slow and prolonged effects.

Description A: Metabotropic receptors produce effects that begin slowly and can last for long periods, ranging from hundreds of milliseconds to many minutes.
Description B: Metabotropic receptors act quickly and only produce short-lived effects lasting milliseconds.

Description A: G protein–coupled receptors activate G proteins, which may trigger second messenger cascades like the cAMP pathway or directly affect ion channels.
Description B: G protein–coupled receptors directly phosphorylate proteins and do not involve second messengers like cAMP.

Description A: Receptor tyrosine kinases initiate protein phosphorylation upon ligand binding, including phosphorylation of tyrosine residues.
Description B: Receptor tyrosine kinases primarily activate G proteins and second messengers instead of phosphorylating tyrosine residues.

Description A: The cAMP signaling cascade starts with the activation of adenylyl cyclase by a G protein's α-subunit, converting ATP into cAMP.
Description B: The cAMP signaling cascade starts by the direct production of cAMP by ionotropic receptors without involvement of G proteins.

Description A: Metabotropic receptors modify behaviors by activating motor patterns, emotional states, and learning mechanisms.
Description B: Metabotropic receptors exclusively control reflex actions and have no role in learning or emotional states.

Description A: IP3, a second messenger, releases Ca2+ from intracellular stores by binding to receptors on the smooth endoplasmic reticulum.
Description B: IP3, a second messenger, binds directly to ionotropic receptors in the plasma membrane to release extracellular Ca2+.

Description A: Protein kinase A (PKA) is activated when cAMP binds to its regulatory subunits, releasing the catalytic subunits.
Description B: Protein kinase A (PKA) is activated by direct interaction with ion channels, bypassing cAMP binding.

Description A: Calcium binds to calmodulin, which activates calmodulin-dependent protein kinase (CaM kinase).
Description B: Calcium directly phosphorylates proteins without needing calmodulin or other intermediaries.

Description A: The binding of a neurotransmitter to G protein–coupled receptors can amplify the signal by activating multiple G proteins.
Description B: The binding of a neurotransmitter to G protein–coupled receptors only activates one G protein at a time, preventing signal amplification.

Description A: Hebbian plasticity strengthens synapses when a presynaptic input and sufficient coactive inputs cause a neuron to fire an action potential.
Description B: Hebbian plasticity strengthens synapses regardless of the activity of coactive inputs.

Description A: Homeostatic plasticity prevents synapses from continuously becoming stronger under the influence of Hebbian plasticity.
Description B: Homeostatic plasticity enhances synaptic strength indefinitely without constraint.

Description A: The climbing fiber inputs in the cerebellum signal the occurrence of the unconditioned stimulus (US).
Description B: The climbing fiber inputs in the cerebellum solely encode the conditioned stimulus (CS).

Description A: Cerebellar long-term depression weakens granule-Purkinje cell synapses active immediately before the presentation of the US.
Description B: Cerebellar long-term depression strengthens granule-Purkinje cell synapses active immediately before the presentation of the US.

Description A: Neurovascular coupling in fMRI involves an increase in oxygenated blood in active brain regions.
Description B: Neurovascular coupling in fMRI involves a decrease in oxygenated blood in active brain regions.

Description A: Functional MRI measures changes in blood oxygenation levels as an indicator of neuronal activity.
Description B: Functional MRI measures changes in blood pressure as an indicator of neuronal activity.

Description A: The blood oxygenation level-dependent (BOLD) signal peaks approximately 4-5 seconds after neuronal activity.
Description B: The blood oxygenation level-dependent (BOLD) signal peaks immediately at the onset of neuronal activity.

Description A: In delay eyeblink conditioning, a conditioned stimulus (CS) such as a tone is paired with an unconditioned stimulus (US) like an air puff to the eye.
Description B: In delay eyeblink conditioning, a conditioned stimulus (CS) such as an air puff is paired with an unconditioned stimulus (US) like a tone.

Description A: fMRI uses a strong magnetic field to align hydrogen protons for brain imaging.
Description B: fMRI uses an electric field to align hydrogen protons for brain imaging.

Description A: Purkinje cells in the cerebellum are inhibitory and regulate downstream motor response timing through pauses in their firing.
Description B: Purkinje cells in the cerebellum are excitatory and regulate downstream motor response timing through increases in firing.

Description A: Rett syndrome is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the MECP2 gene, which encodes a transcriptional regulator that binds to methylated cytosine bases in DNA.
Description B: Rett syndrome is caused by gain-of-function mutations in the MECP2 gene, which encodes a transcriptional regulator that binds to unmethylated cytosine bases in DNA.

Description A: Williams syndrome is caused by a deletion of about 27 genes on the long arm of chromosome 7.
Description B: Williams syndrome is caused by a duplication of about 27 genes on the long arm of chromosome 7.

Description A: Angelman syndrome is associated with the loss of the protein product of UBE3A, a ubiquitin-protein ligase.
Description B: Angelman syndrome is associated with the overexpression of the protein product of UBE3A, a ubiquitin-protein ligase.

Description A: Prader-Willi syndrome is characterized by obesity, mild to moderate intellectual disability, and diminished or absent satiety.
Description B: Prader-Willi syndrome is characterized by hyperactivity, epilepsy, and inappropriate laughter.

Description A: Duplications of the 15q11-13 region are a well-established risk factor for nonsyndromic ASD.
Description B: Duplications of the 15q11-13 region are a well-established protective factor against ASD.

Description A: X-inactivation in females carrying MECP2 mutations allows partial viability by enabling roughly half of brain cells to express a normal MECP2 copy.
Description B: X-inactivation in females carrying MECP2 mutations leads to complete loss of MECP2 expression in all brain cells.

Description A: Research shows that overexpression of BDNF in mouse models of Rett syndrome improves the knock-out phenotype.
Description B: Research shows that suppression of BDNF in mouse models of Rett syndrome improves the knock-out phenotype.

Description A: Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome both result from mutations in genes subject to parental imprinting.
Description B: Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome are unrelated to imprinted genes, instead arising from de novo genome-wide mutations.

Description A: Phase II trials are underway for treatments like IGF-1 and BDNF-related compounds in Rett syndrome.
Description B: Phase III trials are completed for treatments like IGF-1 and BDNF-related compounds in Rett syndrome.

Description A: Williams syndrome individuals often exhibit increased sociability and affinity for music but impaired visuospatial abilities.
Description B: Williams syndrome individuals often exhibit social withdrawal, fear of music, and enhanced visuospatial abilities.

Description A: The basilar membrane deconstructs a complex sound by isolating the component tones at the appropriate segments.
Description B: The basilar membrane synthesizes a complex sound by combining the pure tones.

Description A: Inner hair cells form a single row and are most sensitive to a particular frequency.
Description B: Inner hair cells form three rows and are most sensitive to all frequencies equally.

Description A: The hair bundles of outer hair cells are firmly attached to the tectorial membrane.
Description B: The hair bundles of outer hair cells are not attached to the tectorial membrane.

Description A: Each organ of Corti contains approximately 16,000 hair cells innervated by around 30,000 nerve fibers.
Description B: Each organ of Corti contains approximately 30,000 hair cells innervated by around 16,000 nerve fibers.

Description A: The tip link connects each stereocilium to the side of the longest adjacent stereocilium.
Description B: The tip link connects each stereocilium to the base of the same stereocilium.

Description A: The tectorial membrane is a gelatinous shelf that extends the full length of the basilar membrane.
Description B: The tectorial membrane is a rigid structure that does not interact with the basilar membrane.

Description A: The frequencies from 20 kHz to 2 kHz, 2 kHz to 200 Hz, and 200 Hz to 20 Hz are each represented by one-third of the basilar membrane's extent.
Description B: The frequencies from 20 kHz to 2 kHz are distributed over the entire basilar membrane.

Description A: The mechanical sensitivity of a hair cell depends on the gating of ion channels by mechanical strain applied to its hair bundle.
Description B: The mechanical sensitivity of a hair cell depends on chemical signals rather than mechanical strain.

Description A: Each stereocilium’s core contains a fascicle of cross-linked actin filaments.
Description B: Each stereocilium’s core contains microtubules rather than actin filaments.

Description A: Outer hair cells are supported at their bases by Deiters’s cells.
Description B: Outer hair cells are supported at their bases by Hensen’s cells.

Description A: fMRI is based on two main concepts: the physics of magnetic resonance and the biology of neurovascular coupling, which allow measurement of the BOLD response to neuronal activity.
Description B: fMRI is based on two main concepts: the physics of magnetic resonance and the biology of neurotransmitter gating, which allow measurement of the BOLD response to neuronal activity.

Description A: The hippocampus can be associated with multiple cognitive functions and behaviors, illustrating a many-to-one mapping.
Description B: The hippocampus is exclusively linked to episodic memory, illustrating a one-to-one mapping.

Description A: fMRI cannot directly modify brain activity but instead measures involvement of regions in a behavior.
Description B: fMRI directly modifies brain activity to assess the necessity of regions for specific behaviors.

Description A: Studies have demonstrated that some patients in a vegetative state exhibit mental processing, such as visualizing cues upon command.
Description B: Studies have demonstrated that all patients in a vegetative state exhibit mental processing, such as visualizing cues upon command.

Description A: fMRI-based lie detection currently lacks reliability and is inadmissible in court.
Description B: fMRI-based lie detection is highly reliable and widely accepted as evidence in court.

Description A: Some glial cells possess receptors for neurotransmitters and ion channels, enabling communication with neurons.
Description B: Glial cells only provide structural support and do not interact with neurons or neurotransmitters.

Description A: Resting ion channels underlie the generation of resting potential and passive electrical properties in neurons.
Description B: Sensory receptor channels underlie the generation of resting potential and passive electrical properties in neurons.

Description A: The discovery of MRI in the 1970s was recognized with a Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2003 for Paul Lauterbur and Peter Mansfield.
Description B: The discovery of MRI in the 1970s was recognized with a Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2003 for Paul Lauterbur and Peter Mansfield.

Description A: Neurons are electrically polarized, with dendrites at one end and axons with presynaptic terminals at the other.
Description B: Neurons are electrically symmetrical, with dendrites and axons distributed equally on both ends.

Description A: The coupling between neural activity and vascular signals is nuanced, with blood flow sometimes increasing even in the absence of neuronal activity.
Description B: The coupling between neural activity and vascular signals is perfect, with blood flow always increasing in direct proportion to neuronal activity.

Description A: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) uses electrodes implanted in deep brain nuclei to disrupt aberrant neural activity.
Description B: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) uses electrodes implanted on the surface of the brain to disrupt aberrant neural activity.

Description A: Intracortical electrode arrays penetrate 1 to 2 mm into the cortex and can record action potentials from individual neurons.
Description B: Intracortical electrode arrays sit on the surface of the brain and record action potentials from clusters of neurons.

Description A: A replacement part BMI may restore memory by replacing damaged components of the hippocampus.
Description B: A replacement part BMI may restore memory by replacing components of the cerebellum.

Description A: Electroencephalography (EEG) measures signals from electrodes on the scalp capturing average activity from many neurons.
Description B: Electroencephalography (EEG) measures signals from electrodes implanted in the brain capturing activity from individual neurons.

Description A: BMIs can decode desired movements from the activity of dozens of neurons in motor cortical areas.
Description B: BMIs can decode desired movements from the activity of millions of neurons simultaneously across the entire brain.

Description A: Continuous decoders estimate the moment-by-moment details of a movement trajectory by processing execution-related neural activity.
Description B: Continuous decoders estimate movement goals by processing preparation-related neural activity instead of execution activity.

Description A: BMIs can monitor neural signals from motor-related brain areas like the dorsal premotor and primary motor cortex to decode movements.
Description B: BMIs can monitor neural signals exclusively from sensory regions like the occipital lobe to decode movements.

Description A: Neural activity can vary due to spiking 'noise,' making movement direction estimation less precise.
Description B: Neural activity is always consistent and spiking 'noise' does not affect movement direction estimation.

Description A: Antiseizure BMIs work by monitoring neural activity and responding immediately to disrupt seizure onset using electrical stimulation.
Description B: Antiseizure BMIs work by monitoring neural activity but cannot respond to disrupt seizure onset with electrical stimulation.

Description A: BMIs have been used for disorders such as Parkinson disease, epilepsy, and obsessive-compulsive disorder.
Description B: BMIs are effective only for motor disorders like Parkinson disease and cannot help with epilepsy or psychiatric conditions.

Description A: In Parkinson disease, loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra deprives the putamen–globus pallidus pathways of their drive.
Description B: In Parkinson disease, loss of dopaminergic neurons in the cerebellum deprives the putamen–globus pallidus pathways of their drive.

Description A: Induced pluripotent stem cells can be reprogrammed from skin fibroblasts and avoid issues of immunological incompatibility by using cells derived from an individual patient.
Description B: Induced pluripotent stem cells can only be generated from embryonic cells and cannot avoid issues of immunological incompatibility.

Description A: Transplanted dopaminergic neurons into the putamen release dopamine onto their targets without needing to form elaborate synapses.
Description B: Transplanted dopaminergic neurons into the putamen require extensive synapse formation before releasing dopamine onto their targets.

Description A: The adult brain and spinal cord can generate new oligodendrocytes but this production is often insufficient for restoring function.
Description B: The adult brain and spinal cord cannot generate new oligodendrocytes under any circumstances.

Description A: Clinical trials utilizing ES and iPS cell-derived neurons to counteract neurodegenerative disease are underway.
Description B: Clinical trials utilizing ES and iPS cell-derived neurons to counteract neurodegenerative disease have been universally banned due to ethical concerns.

Description A: Astrocytes can be reprogrammed into neurons in experimental settings to enhance neurogenesis in injured areas like the cerebral cortex.
Description B: Astrocytes lack any capacity to be reprogrammed into neurons in experimental settings.

Description A: Embryonic stem cells can differentiate into all cell types of the body, including neurons and glial cells.
Description B: Embryonic stem cells can only differentiate into neuronal cells but not glial cells.

Description A: Comprehensive neurogenesis in the adult human brain predominantly occurs in the hippocampus and olfactory bulb.
Description B: Comprehensive neurogenesis in the adult human brain occurs equally across all regions of the cerebral cortex.

Description A: Induced pluripotent stem cells offer significant advantages over ES cells because they do not require embryos for their production.
Description B: Induced pluripotent stem cells do not offer advantages over ES cells because they require embryos for their production.

Description A: Key mechanisms like NMNAT and SARM1 regulate the process of Wallerian degeneration.
Description B: The process of Wallerian degeneration is entirely passive and lacks any active, regulated mechanisms.

Description A: Individual cells in the inferior temporal cortex are highly shape-selective and can maintain their selectivity even across size, position, and rotation, contributing to perceptual constancy.
Description B: Individual cells in the inferior temporal cortex are highly shape-selective but cannot maintain their selectivity across size, position, or rotation.

Description A: Face cells in the inferotemporal cortex are organized into larger units called face areas, supporting face recognition.
Description B: Face cells in the inferotemporal cortex are distributed randomly, with no identifiable organization into larger units.

Description A: The inferotemporal cortex is involved in object categorization, memory formation, and assignment of emotional valence to objects, among other functions.
Description B: The inferotemporal cortex is primarily responsible for auditory processing with no known role in object categorization or memory.

Description A: Neurons with categorical selectivity for objects are found in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, a projection site of the inferior temporal cortex.
Description B: Neurons with categorical selectivity for objects are found exclusively in the primary visual cortex, with no input from the inferior temporal cortex.

Description A: Perceptual learning can enhance the ability to discriminate between complex objects and refine neural selectivity in the inferior temporal cortex.
Description B: Perceptual learning has no impact on the ability to discriminate between complex objects or neural selectivity.

Description A: Neurons in the temporal and prefrontal cortex exhibit delay-period activity, holding visual information in short-term working memory after a stimulus disappears.
Description B: No delay-period neuronal activity is observed in the temporal or prefrontal cortex for short-term memory.

Description A: High-level visual information processing is influenced by both bottom-up activation and top-down modulation.
Description B: High-level visual information processing is driven entirely by bottom-up activation, with no top-down modulation.

Description A: The corollary discharge in the brain adjusts visual perception during eye movements to stabilize the visual world.
Description B: The corollary discharge disrupts visual perception during eye movements, making the visual world appear unstable.

Description A: Neuronal activity from oculomotor proprioception reaches the lateral intraparietal area approximately 150ms after a saccade.
Description B: Neuronal activity from oculomotor proprioception reaches the lateral intraparietal area immediately before a saccade.

Description A: Visual masking can suppress a blur caused by saccades, particularly when a mask is flashed after the saccade.
Description B: Visual masking has no impact on the blur caused by saccades, even if a mask is flashed after the saccade.

Description A: The primary goal of preprocessing in fMRI is to remove known sources of noise in the data, which can be caused by the MRI machine or the subject.
Description B: The primary goal of preprocessing in fMRI is to enhance the signal of neural activity without addressing noise caused by the MRI machine or the subject.

Description A: The fusiform face area (FFA) in the fusiform gyrus shows robust and selective BOLD activity when humans view faces.
Description B: The fusiform face area (FFA) in the fusiform gyrus shows robust and selective BOLD activity when humans view scenes.

Description A: Motion correction in fMRI addresses head movement noise using a spatial interpolation algorithm.
Description B: Motion correction in fMRI addresses scanner drift noise using a spatial interpolation algorithm.

Description A: Temporal filtering removes low-frequency components likely caused by scanner drift in fMRI data.
Description B: Temporal filtering in fMRI enhances low-frequency components to better understand scanner drift.

Description A: Univariate activation treats each voxel independently and compares conditions by modeling BOLD activity with statistical regressors.
Description B: Univariate activation examines patterns of voxel correlations over time to analyze BOLD activity during tasks.

Description A: The default mode network involves the posterior medial cortex, lateral parietal cortex, and medial prefrontal cortex.
Description B: The default mode network involves the fusiform gyrus, primary motor cortex, and temporal pole.

Description A: Reverse inference is weaker than forward inference because brain regions generally support multiple functions.
Description B: Forward inference is weaker than reverse inference because brain regions are mapped to specific functions with high reliability.

Description A: Functional connectivity analysis measures correlations of BOLD activity between voxels or regions over time.
Description B: Functional connectivity analysis measures correlations of neuronal spiking rates between brain regions over time.

Description A: Machine learning is used in multivariate pattern analysis to classify brain activity patterns based on conditions or stimuli.
Description B: Machine learning is used in univariate activation to classify brain activity from each individual voxel independently.

Description A: Representational similarity analysis (RSA) compares neural similarity matrices to behavioral or computational similarity matrices.
Description B: Representational similarity analysis (RSA) compares temporal filtering methods across different fMRI studies.

Description A: Lesions of the parabrachial and pedunculopontine tegmental nuclei or the basal forebrain cause coma.
Description B: Lesions of the parabrachial and pedunculopontine tegmental nuclei or the basal forebrain cause wakefulness.

Description A: Damage to orexinergic neurons in the lateral hypothalamus causes narcolepsy, resulting in unstable sleep-wake cycles with normal amounts of sleep.
Description B: Damage to orexinergic neurons in the lateral hypothalamus causes insomnia, resulting in reduced total sleep time.

Description A: Glutamatergic neurons in the dorsolateral rostral pons, including the parabrachial nucleus, are essential for maintaining wakefulness.
Description B: Glutamatergic neurons in the dorsolateral rostral pons, including the parabrachial nucleus, are essential for promoting deep sleep.

Description A: Large bilateral lesions of the basal forebrain can produce coma.
Description B: Large bilateral lesions of the basal forebrain can enhance alertness.

Description A: Optogenetic or chemogenetic activation of cholinergic, GABAergic, or glutamatergic neurons in the basal forebrain produces arousal.
Description B: Optogenetic or chemogenetic activation of cholinergic, GABAergic, or glutamatergic neurons in the basal forebrain suppresses arousal.

Description A: Circuits involving mutually inhibitory neurons in the ventrolateral preoptic area regulate the transition from wakefulness to sleep.
Description B: Circuits involving mutually inhibitory neurons in the ventrolateral preoptic area regulate constant wakefulness.

Description A: The ascending arousal system integrates inputs from glutamatergic, cholinergic, and GABAergic neurons.
Description B: The ascending arousal system integrates inputs exclusively from serotonergic neurons.

Description A: Antagonists of monoamines can cause sleepiness.
Description B: Antagonists of monoamines can completely prevent sleep.

Description A: GABAergic neurons in the lateral hypothalamus promote wakefulness by inhibiting sleep-promoting circuits.
Description B: GABAergic neurons in the lateral hypothalamus promote drowsiness by activating sleep-promoting circuits.

Description A: Damage to both the ascending arousal system and cerebral hemispheres can result in coma.
Description B: Damage to both the ascending arousal system and cerebral hemispheres will enhance consciousness.

Description A: Lesions in the parietal cortex cause a neglect of the contralateral visual world.
Description B: Lesions in the parietal cortex cause a neglect of the ipsilateral visual world.

Description A: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area respond to targets for grasping, respond even when monkeys make grasping movements in total darkness, and project to the grasp region of premotor cortex.
Description B: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area only respond to targets for grasping under bright lighting conditions and do not project to the grasp region of premotor cortex.

Description A: Neurons in the ventral intraparietal area respond to objects coming toward the mouth, have tactile receptive fields on the face, and project to the mouth area of premotor cortex.
Description B: Neurons in the ventral intraparietal area respond exclusively to objects moving away from the mouth and have no tactile receptive fields on the face.

Description A: The parietal cortex sums a number of different signals—motor, visual, cognitive—to create a priority map of the visual field.
Description B: The parietal cortex only processes motor signals to create a priority map of the visual field, ignoring visual and cognitive inputs.

Description A: Neurons in the medial intraparietal area have a representation of arm position and respond to targets for reaching.
Description B: Neurons in the medial intraparietal area primarily respond to eye movements and have no representation of arm position.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area respond to targets for eye movements and objects of visual attention, discharge before eye movements, and have a representation of eye position.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area respond after eye movements, ignore objects of visual attention, and lack a representation of eye position.

Description A: Visual information provided by the parietal cortex enables the motor system to adjust hand grip to match the size of the object to which it reaches before the hand actually lands on the target.
Description B: Visual information provided by the parietal cortex has no role in adjusting hand grip to match the size of an object.

Description A: There are at least four different visual maps in the intraparietal sulcus, each of which corresponds to a particular motor workspace.
Description B: There are no visual maps in the intraparietal sulcus corresponding to particular motor workspaces.

Description A: Humans have great difficulty noticing a change in the visual world unless their attention is drawn to the spatial location of a change.
Description B: Humans effortlessly notice changes in the visual world, even without their attention being drawn to the spatial location of a change.

Description A: Neurons in the face region of area 3a in the somatosensory cortex have a representation of the position of the eye in the orbit that arises from the contralateral eye.
Description B: Neurons in the face region of area 3a in the somatosensory cortex represent the position of the eye in the orbit arising exclusively from the ipsilateral eye.

Description A: The ITR of a BMI is approximately 6.5 bps, corresponding to selecting two to three targets per second with greater than 90% accuracy.
Description B: The ITR of a BMI is approximately 2.5 bps, corresponding to selecting two to three targets per second with greater than 90% accuracy.

Description A: A discrete decoder estimates one of several possible movement goals from neural population activity.
Description B: A discrete decoder estimates the moment-by-moment details of a movement from neural population activity.

Description A: The ReFIT-KF decoder incorporated the closed-loop nature of BMIs into its calibration by assuming the user desired to move the cursor straight to the target.
Description B: The ReFIT-KF decoder used open-loop control and did not incorporate the closed-loop nature of BMIs into its calibration.

Description A: The primary purpose of a motor BMI is to provide control of a robotic limb or paralyzed limb.
Description B: The primary purpose of a motor BMI is to provide control of an auditory prosthesis for restoring hearing.

Description A: Cortical microstimulation in the primary somatosensory cortex can be used to provide tactile feedback during BMI control.
Description B: Cortical microstimulation in the primary somatosensory cortex cannot provide tactile feedback during BMI control.

Description A: Neural signals can be measured using electroencephalography, electrocorticography, or intracortical electrodes.
Description B: Neural signals can only be measured using intracortical electrodes, not electroencephalography or electrocorticography.

Description A: Functional electrical stimulation (FES) can restore movement in paralyzed arms by electrically stimulating intact muscles.
Description B: Functional electrical stimulation (FES) restores movement by manually activating the spinal cord of paralyzed patients.

Description A: A longer period of spike count collection generally increases decoding accuracy by averaging out noise.
Description B: A longer period of spike count collection always decreases decoding accuracy due to increased spiking noise.

Description A: Electrical stimulation of neurons can provide sensory information, such as texture or physical location, during BMI control.
Description B: Electrical stimulation of neurons cannot provide sensory information, such as texture or physical location, during BMI control.

Description A: Pilot clinical trials of BMI systems have allowed people with paralysis to type answers to questions using a computer interface.
Description B: Pilot clinical trials of BMI systems have only allowed for internal neural recordings without any typing or external interfacing.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) fire when a monkey prepares to make an eye movement to an object or focuses its attention on the object's location.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) fire when a monkey is preparing to grasp an object or focuses its attention on the object's features.

Description A: In the medial intraparietal area (MIP), neurons fire when a monkey is preparing to reach for a visual target, regardless of its physical direction.
Description B: In the medial intraparietal area (MIP), neurons fire only when a monkey plans to shift its gaze to a visual target without reaching.

Description A: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area (AIP) fire when the monkey is looking at or preparing to grasp objects and are selective for particular shapes.
Description B: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area (AIP) fire regardless of the object's shape when the monkey is preparing to grasp.

Description A: Persistent neural activity helps maintain short-term memory by representing sensory qualities like frequency through delay periods.
Description B: Persistent neural activity supports visual features such as shape and color without representing sensory qualities through delay periods.

Description A: Patients with right parietal lobe damage often experience hemineglect, ignoring the left side of their visual field and objects.
Description B: Patients with right parietal lobe damage experience complete blindness in their left visual field, termed hemiblindness.

Description A: Monkeys can be trained to rationally combine evidence from shapes to make decisions about reward locations.
Description B: Monkeys make reward-based decisions based on random guesses rather than rationally combining evidence from shapes.

Description A: Neurons in the parietal association cortex can represent cumulative evidence in probabilistic decision-making tasks.
Description B: Neurons in the parietal association cortex process decisions without encoding cumulative evidence in any measure.

Description A: In perceptual decision-making, the persistent activity of neurons provides models for reasoning via evidence accumulation.
Description B: Perceptual decision-making does not involve evidence accumulation and primarily uses instantaneous neuron firing.

Description A: Affordances refer to the possible behaviors afforded by an object, such as grasping, throwing, or lifting.
Description B: Affordances refer only to the permanent physical properties of an object, independent of interaction or behavior.

Description A: Hemineglect patients often fail to interrogate the neglected visual field, showing no awareness of missing sensory information.
Description B: Hemineglect patients frequently recognize their inability to perceive the neglected visual field and attempt to compensate.

Description A: The hypothalamus integrates behavior, autonomic, and neuroendocrine responses to regulate six vital functions: blood pressure and electrolyte composition, energy metabolism, reproductive behaviors, body temperature, defensive behavior, and sleep-wake cycles.
Description B: The hypothalamus primarily regulates only three vital functions: blood pressure, energy metabolism, and body temperature, with limited involvement in sleep-wake cycles and reproductive behaviors.

Description A: The settling point model explains how systems like body weight or lake levels can achieve constancy without feedback or error detection, relying instead on proportional adjustments to changes.
Description B: The settling point model depends on strict feedback mechanisms and error detection to maintain constancy in systems like body weight or lake levels.

Description A: The hypothalamus lies at the base of the brain, above the pituitary gland, and is bounded by structures like the optic chiasm and thalamus.
Description B: The hypothalamus lies at the base of the brain, below the pituitary gland, and is bounded by structures like the cerebellum and medulla.

Description A: The set point model has fallen out of favor since years of research failed to uncover molecular and neural bases for encoding specific set points.
Description B: The set point model is widely accepted as researchers have thoroughly discovered molecular and neural bases for encoding specific set points.

Description A: Body temperature regulation involves multiple sensors at different sites like the skin, core, and brain, which collectively contribute to a settling point.
Description B: Body temperature regulation solely depends on a single sensor in the preoptic area of the brain to maintain a set point.

Description A: The arcuate nucleus in the hypothalamus is primarily involved in regulating energy balance, including hunger and feeding behavior.
Description B: The arcuate nucleus in the hypothalamus primarily regulates circadian rhythms and thirst.

Description A: Neurons in the median preoptic nucleus (MnPO) are key regulators of body temperature.
Description B: Neurons in the median preoptic nucleus (MnPO) are primarily involved in regulating glucose metabolism.

Description A: The lateral hypothalamic area (LHA) is closely linked to reward pathways and contains neurons expressing orexin that stabilize wakefulness.
Description B: The lateral hypothalamic area (LHA) is primarily associated with thermoregulation and contains neurons regulating body temperature.

Description A: The enteric system consists of interconnected plexuses like the myenteric and submucous plexuses and can independently regulate gastrointestinal functions.
Description B: The enteric system consists solely of sensory neurons and relies entirely on inputs from the brain stem and spinal cord for gastrointestinal regulation.

Description A: Preganglionic neurons release acetylcholine (ACh), which acts on nicotinic receptors in autonomic ganglia to excite postganglionic neurons.
Description B: Postganglionic neurons release acetylcholine (ACh), which acts on nicotinic receptors in autonomic ganglia to excite preganglionic neurons.

Description A: Neurons are both electrically and chemically excitable, whereas glia are less excitable but regulate neuronal function through ion uptake and neurotransmitter removal.
Description B: Neurons are chemically excitable but not electrically excitable, whereas glia are highly excitable and regulate neuronal function by producing neurotransmitters.

Description A: In the central nervous system, oligodendrocytes provide the insulating myelin sheaths for axons, whereas Schwann cells myelinate axons in the peripheral nervous system.
Description B: In the central nervous system, Schwann cells provide the insulating myelin sheaths for axons, whereas oligodendrocytes myelinate axons in the peripheral nervous system.

Description A: Microtubules in axons typically have a single orientation with the plus end directed away from the cell body.
Description B: Microtubules in axons typically have a single orientation with the minus end directed away from the cell body.

Description A: Astrocytes maintain the blood–brain barrier and support neuronal function by contacting both capillaries and neurons.
Description B: Astrocytes maintain the blood–brain barrier but have no direct interactions with neurons or capillaries.

Description A: The rough endoplasmic reticulum forms a specialized structure called the nuclear envelope, which surrounds the DNA and is continuous with other portions of the endoplasmic reticulum.
Description B: The rough endoplasmic reticulum forms a barrier called the cytoplasmic sheath, which encases the DNA and is completely separate from the endoplasmic reticulum.

Description A: Dendrites contain most organelles found in the cell body, but the rough endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi complex decrease in density with distance from the cell body.
Description B: Dendrites completely lack the organelles found in the cell body, including the rough endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi complex.

Description A: Mitochondria are crucial for generating ATP, managing Ca2+ homeostasis, and participating in lipid biogenesis.
Description B: Mitochondria are not involved in Ca2+ homeostasis or lipid biogenesis but solely focus on generating ATP.

Description A: Tau proteins are present in axons and, when abnormally polymerized, contribute to neurofibrillary tangles in diseases such as Alzheimer’s.
Description B: Tau proteins are present in dendrites and, when abnormally polymerized, contribute to neurofibrillary tangles in diseases such as Parkinson’s.

Description A: Proteins synthesized in the rough endoplasmic reticulum are transported to the Golgi complex before being directed to secretory vesicles.
Description B: Proteins synthesized in the rough endoplasmic reticulum are directly deposited into lysosomes without passing through the Golgi complex.

Description A: Actin filaments, the thinnest components of the cytoskeleton, are concentrated beneath the plasma membrane and aid in structural plasticity of the cell’s periphery.
Description B: Actin filaments are the thickest components of the cytoskeleton and are primarily located in the nucleus to support chromosomal movement.

Description A: The tetracycline transactivator (tTA) binds to the tetO promoter to activate downstream transgene expression, and its activity is inhibited upon binding antibiotics like tetracycline.
Description B: The tetracycline transactivator (tTA) activates transgene expression only in the absence of the tetO promoter, and its activity is enhanced upon binding antibiotics like tetracycline.

Description A: RNA interference works by introducing a short RNA sequence that causes a specific mRNA to become double-stranded, leading to its degradation and reduced gene expression.
Description B: RNA interference works by introducing a short RNA sequence that enhances the stability of specific mRNAs, leading to increased gene expression.

Description A: Reverse tTA (rtTA) binds to the tetO promoter and activates transcription only when the animal is fed doxycycline.
Description B: Reverse tTA (rtTA) activates transcription in the tetO promoter only in the absence of doxycycline in the system.

Description A: The Cre/loxP system enables region-specific gene knockout by flanking genes with loxP sites and using Cre recombinase under a specific promoter.
Description B: The Cre/loxP system enables whole-organism gene knockout without targeting specific regions or controlling promoter activity.

Description A: The clock gene in mice is a transcriptional regulator with a PAS domain that oscillates its activity to control the circadian rhythm.
Description B: The clock gene in mice inhibits transcription and does not share any structural domains with the per gene.

Description A: Homologs of fly circadian rhythm genes like clock and per are conserved in mice and exhibit similar roles in regulating rhythmic behaviors.
Description B: Fly circadian rhythm genes like clock and per are unique to flies and have no conserved homologs or functions in mammals like mice.

Description A: CRISPR technology uses a Cas9-guide RNA complex to induce double-stranded breaks in the target DNA, enabling mutations or gene edits.
Description B: CRISPR technology functions by enhancing RNA stability without impacting DNA sequences at the target site.

Description A: PER/TIM protein dimers repress their transcription by interacting with CLOCK and CYCLE proteins, following distinct oscillation patterns in circadian cycles.
Description B: PER/TIM protein dimers enhance their own transcription by stabilizing CLOCK and CYCLE proteins, disrupting circadian oscillations.

Description A: The for (forager) gene influences foraging behavior in Drosophila, with rovers and sitters displaying genetic behavioral variability.
Description B: The for (forager) gene shows no impact on the foraging behaviors of Drosophila, as behavior is influenced only environmentally.

Description A: In certain Drosophila populations, natural environmental pressures favor a genetic balance between the rover and sitter phenotypes.
Description B: Rover and sitter larval traits arise exclusively from laboratory-induced manipulations and are not found in wild Drosophila populations.

Description A: Auditory cortex neurons in monkeys tuned to low frequencies are found at the rostral end of A1, while those responsive to high frequencies are located at the caudal region.
Description B: Auditory cortex neurons in monkeys tuned to low frequencies are found at the caudal end of A1, while those responsive to high frequencies are located at the rostral region.

Description A: Tonotopic maps in the primary auditory cortex (A1) are organized by frequency gradients that smoothly increase in one direction and form isofrequency contours in another direction.
Description B: Tonotopic maps in the primary auditory cortex (A1) are organized randomly without any frequency gradients or isofrequency contours.

Description A: Behavioral training of adult animals can cause a reorganization of the auditory cortex, leading to overrepresentation of behaviorally relevant frequencies.
Description B: Behavioral training of adult animals has no impact on the organization of the auditory cortex, and frequency representation remains unchanged.

Description A: Marmoset monkeys exhibit human-like pitch perception, including the ability to discriminate missing fundamentals in harmonic sounds.
Description B: Marmoset monkeys lack pitch perception and cannot discriminate missing fundamentals in harmonic sounds.

Description A: Silencing frequency-specific cortical areas in bats decreases responses in corresponding frequency-specific regions of the thalamus and inferior colliculus.
Description B: Silencing frequency-specific cortical areas in bats increases responses in corresponding frequency-specific regions of the thalamus and inferior colliculus.

Description A: Pitch-selective neurons in marmoset monkeys extract and encode pitch embedded in harmonic sounds near their preferred frequency.
Description B: Pitch-selective neurons in marmoset monkeys encode random frequencies that are unrelated to harmonic sounds.

Description A: Neurons in the FM-FM area of bats respond preferentially to pulse-echo pairs separated by a specific delay, representing distances to targets.
Description B: Neurons in the FM-FM area of bats respond randomly to sounds and do not encode target distances.

Description A: In the auditory cortex of humans, pure tones primarily activate core areas, whereas belt areas are more responsive to complex sounds such as narrowband noise bursts.
Description B: In the auditory cortex of humans, pure tones primarily activate belt areas, whereas core areas are more responsive to narrowband noise.

Description A: The anterior-ventral pathways in the auditory cortex specialize in identifying auditory objects, while dorsal-posterior pathways focus on sound-source location and motion.
Description B: The anterior-ventral pathways in the auditory cortex specialize in sound-source location, while dorsal-posterior pathways focus on auditory object identification.

Description A: Subcortical circuits mediate rapid, reliable performance for survival-critical auditory behaviors, while cortical pathways allow for slower, more differentiated tasks such as working memory and recognition.
Description B: Cortical circuits mediate rapid, reliable performance for survival-critical auditory behaviors, while subcortical pathways allow for slower, more differentiated tasks such as working memory and recognition.

Description A: Humans have approximately 350 different odorant receptors, whereas mice have approximately 1,000.
Description B: Mice have approximately 350 different odorant receptors, whereas humans have approximately 1,000.

Description A: Odorant receptors are part of the G protein–coupled receptor superfamily and have seven transmembrane domains.
Description B: Odorant receptors are part of the G protein–coupled receptor superfamily but lack transmembrane domains.

Description A: Odorants are detected by multiple receptors, and different combinations of receptors encode different odorants.
Description B: A single receptor detects all odorants and encodes them using the same mechanism.

Description A: The axons of olfactory sensory neurons pass through the cribriform plate and terminate in the olfactory bulb.
Description B: The axons of olfactory sensory neurons bypass the cribriform plate and terminate directly in the orbitofrontal cortex.

Description A: Each olfactory sensory neuron expresses only one odorant receptor gene.
Description B: Each olfactory sensory neuron expresses multiple odorant receptor genes.

Description A: Odorant binding occurs in a pocket formed by transmembrane domains.
Description B: Odorant binding occurs only in the cytoplasmic region of the receptor protein.

Description A: Humans can rapidly recover sensitivity to an odorant after its temporary removal.
Description B: Humans lose sensitivity to an odorant permanently after exposure to high concentrations.

Description A: Odorants activate unique combinations of glomeruli in the olfactory bulb.
Description B: Odorants activate all glomeruli in the olfactory bulb regardless of their chemical structure.

Description A: Pyramidal neurons in the piriform cortex are scattered and activated by more than one odorant.
Description B: Pyramidal neurons in the piriform cortex are precisely organized and activated by only one odorant.

Description A: Pheromones are detected in two separate structures: the nasal olfactory epithelium and the vomeronasal organ.
Description B: Pheromones are detected only in the nasal olfactory epithelium and not in the vomeronasal organ.

Description A: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) prevalence is estimated to be as high as 2.6% for the full spectrum of social disability.
Description B: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) prevalence is estimated to be less than 0.5% for the full spectrum of social disability.

Description A: Autism Spectrum Disorder must be detectable before the age of 3 years by definition.
Description B: Autism Spectrum Disorder is typically diagnosed during adulthood rather than childhood.

Description A: The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) consolidated Asperger syndrome and pervasive developmental disorder into Autism Spectrum Disorder.
Description B: The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5) introduced Asperger syndrome as a distinct diagnosis.

Description A: The male-to-female ratio of Autism Spectrum Disorder occurrence is estimated to be between 2:1 and 3:1.
Description B: The male-to-female ratio of Autism Spectrum Disorder occurrence is consistently higher in females.

Description A: ASD affects individuals across the IQ spectrum, and about half of all individuals with ASD also have intellectual disability.
Description B: Only individuals with high IQs are diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder.

Description A: Approximately 10% of children with Autism Spectrum Disorder have shown improvement in longitudinal studies, with little or no evidence of social disability later in life.
Description B: No individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder show improvement over time according to studies.

Description A: Autism Spectrum Disorder has no definitive biological markers but strong biological correlates such as gene mutations and neuroimaging findings.
Description B: Autism Spectrum Disorder is easily diagnosed using specific biological markers like blood tests.

Description A: The reasons for an increase in Autism Spectrum Disorder prevalence include changing diagnostic criteria, increased awareness, and possible true increase in incidence.
Description B: The increase in Autism Spectrum Disorder prevalence is entirely due to a single specific genetic mutation becoming more common.

Description A: The term 'Asperger syndrome' is no longer used as part of the Autism Spectrum Disorder classification in the DSM-5.
Description B: The term 'Asperger syndrome' remains a distinct diagnosis separate from Autism Spectrum Disorder in the DSM-5.

Description A: Autism spectrum disorders occur in all countries, cultures, and socio-economic groups.
Description B: Autism spectrum disorders are only prevalent in high-income countries.

Description A: Synaptotagmins are membrane proteins that act as major Ca2+ sensors to trigger vesicle fusion during neurotransmitter release.
Description B: Synaptotagmins are cytoplasmic proteins that act as major Ca2+ sensors to inhibit vesicle fusion during neurotransmitter release.

Description A: The SNARE complex stabilizes synaptic vesicle fusion by drawing the vesicle and plasma membranes into close apposition.
Description B: The SNARE complex destabilizes synaptic vesicle fusion by separating the vesicle and plasma membranes.

Description A: The fusion pore can reversibly open and close before complete vesicle collapse during neurotransmitter release.
Description B: The fusion pore irreversibly opens during neurotransmitter release, requiring complete vesicle collapse.

Description A: Clathrin-mediated endocytosis requires the formation of lattice-like coated pits during vesicle recycling.
Description B: Clathrin-mediated endocytosis occurs without the formation of lattice-like coated pits during vesicle recycling.

Description A: Synaptic vesicles utilize the V-ATPase pump to maintain an acidic pH of around 5.0 in their lumen.
Description B: Synaptic vesicles utilize a passive gradient to maintain an alkaline pH of around 7.5 in their lumen.

Description A: At low release rates, vesicles typically follow the kiss-and-run pathway for rapid recycling.
Description B: At low release rates, vesicles primarily undergo bulk retrieval for recycling.

Description A: Endocytosis by ultrafast clathrin-independent pathways begins just 50 ms after vesicle exocytosis.
Description B: Endocytosis by ultrafast clathrin-independent pathways begins several minutes after vesicle exocytosis.

Description A: SNARE proteins are universally involved in membrane fusion across species, from yeast to humans.
Description B: SNARE proteins are only involved in membrane fusion during vesicle recycling in humans.

Description A: Synapsin proteins play a role in restraining vesicles in the reserve pool and releasing them during high stimulation.
Description B: Synapsin proteins play a role in depleting vesicles during low stimulation without involvement in the reserve pool.

Description A: A total of five Ca2+ ions bind to synaptotagmin to trigger neurotransmitter release from vesicles.
Description B: A total of two Ca2+ ions bind to synaptotagmin to inhibit neurotransmitter release from vesicles.

Description A: The Kv7 subunits form non-inactivating channels that can even activate significantly at resting potential and are downregulated by acetylcholine through muscarinic G protein–coupled receptors.
Description B: The Kv7 subunits form inactivating channels that require strong depolarizations and are upregulated by acetylcholine through muscarinic G protein–coupled receptors.

Description A: Hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channels have a reversal potential around -40 to -30 mV and are permeable to both K+ and Na+.
Description B: Hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channels have a reversal potential around -100 mV and are permeable only to K+.

Description A: Kv3 channels are associated with neurons that fire at high frequency and allow rapid repolarization due to their fast deactivation.
Description B: Kv3 channels are associated with neurons that fire at low frequency and allow slow repolarization due to their delayed deactivation.

Description A: Kv1 family channels contribute to adaptation by strongly activating after an action potential, impeding subsequent spikes.
Description B: Kv1 family channels contribute to repetitive high-frequency firing by speeding up recovery after an action potential.

Description A: In Purkinje neurons, the high expression of Kv3 channels leads to the generation of narrow action potentials.
Description B: In Purkinje neurons, the high expression of Kv3 channels leads to the generation of broad action potentials.

Description A: SK channels open in response to increases in intracellular Ca2+ but are not voltage-dependent.
Description B: SK channels open in response to voltage changes but are not sensitive to intracellular Ca2+.

Description A: In dopaminergic neurons, voltage-activated Ca2+ channels opening during the falling phase of an action potential creates broader action potentials.
Description B: In dopaminergic neurons, voltage-activated Ca2+ channels opening during the rising phase of an action potential creates broader action potentials.

Description A: Persistent sodium currents in suprachiasmatic nucleus neurons are activated at voltages as negative as -70 mV, contributing to pacemaking.
Description B: Persistent sodium currents in suprachiasmatic nucleus neurons are activated only at voltages above -30 mV, contributing to pacemaking.

Description A: Nodes of Ranvier have a high density of Na+ channels but a low density of K+ channels in myelinated axons.
Description B: Nodes of Ranvier have a high density of K+ channels but a low density of Na+ channels in myelinated axons.

Description A: Hyperpolarizing inputs can make a neuron more excitable by reducing Cav3 channel inactivation.
Description B: Hyperpolarizing inputs can make a neuron less excitable by activating Cav3 channel inactivation.

Description A: The pattern of action potentials conveys important information, and some neurons are spontaneously active even in the absence of stimulation.
Description B: The pattern of action potentials conveys no significant information, and neurons are never spontaneously active without stimulation.

Description A: Neurotransmitter molecules are stored in synaptic vesicles, which release them into the synaptic cleft via exocytosis at active zones.
Description B: Neurotransmitter molecules float freely in the cytoplasm and are released spontaneously into the synaptic cleft without exocytosis.

Description A: The same neurotransmitter can have different effects depending on the type of receptor in the postsynaptic cell.
Description B: The same neurotransmitter always has the same effect, regardless of the type of receptor in the postsynaptic cell.
