Description A: The stretch reflex circuit demonstrates how interactions between sensory and motor neurons produce simple behaviors.
Description B: The stretch reflex circuit involves interactions only between interneurons and does not involve sensory or motor neurons.

Description A: Inhibitory synaptic inputs can create patterns of alternating neuronal firing and silence.
Description B: Inhibitory synaptic inputs completely block neuronal functionality and prevent any firing patterns.

Description A: The hippocampus contributes to explicit memory, which is accessible to consciousness.
Description B: The hippocampus does not contribute to memory or conscious recall.

Description A: Neurons in the spinal cord are grouped into functional networks, with local connections often integrating their activity.
Description B: Neurons in the spinal cord are randomly distributed and do not form functional networks.

Description A: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis affects motor neurons, while leprosy primarily affects sensory neurons.
Description B: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis affects sensory neurons, while leprosy primarily affects motor neurons.

Description A: The epicritic system processes fine touch and pressure, while the protopathic system processes pain and temperature.
Description B: The protopathic system processes fine touch and pressure, while the epicritic system processes pain and temperature.

Description A: Different brain circuits have evolved specialized organizations to efficiently perform specific functions.
Description B: All brain circuits function in the same way, regardless of the task they perform.

Description A: Transmitter release is triggered by the depolarization of the presynaptic membrane.
Description B: Transmitter release is triggered regardless of presynaptic membrane depolarization.

Description A: Calcium influx through voltage-gated Ca2+ channels is necessary for triggering transmitter release.
Description B: Calcium influx through voltage-gated Na+ channels is necessary for triggering transmitter release.

Description A: A 40 mV presynaptic depolarization is required to produce a postsynaptic potential.
Description B: A 10 mV presynaptic depolarization is required to produce a postsynaptic potential.

Description A: Presynaptic Na+ and K+ fluxes are not necessary for transmitter release once sufficient depolarization is achieved.
Description B: Presynaptic Na+ and K+ fluxes are directly responsible for transmitter release.

Description A: Synaptic delay is primarily due to the time required to open presynaptic Ca2+ channels.
Description B: Synaptic delay is caused primarily by the slow diffusion of neurotransmitters across the synaptic cleft.

Description A: Calcium channels at the active zone allow for highly localized Ca2+ influx, crucial for transmitter release.
Description B: Calcium channels are uniformly distributed along the presynaptic membrane, spreading Ca2+ influx widely.

Description A: Transmitter release exhibits a steep nonlinear dependence on presynaptic Ca2+ concentration.
Description B: Transmitter release exhibits a linear dependence on presynaptic Ca2+ concentration.

Description A: Miniature end-plate potentials are caused by spontaneous release of small packets of neurotransmitters.
Description B: Miniature end-plate potentials occur only in response to nerve stimulation.

Description A: N- and P/Q-type Ca2+ channels are primarily responsible for fast synaptic transmission.
Description B: L-type Ca2+ channels are primarily responsible for fast synaptic transmission.

Description A: At least four or five Ca2+ ions must bind to the sensor protein to trigger neurotransmitter release.
Description B: Only one Ca2+ ion is needed to bind to the sensor protein to trigger neurotransmitter release.

Description A: Ion channels are integral membrane proteins that allow ions to pass through the cell membrane.
Description B: Ion channels are integral membrane proteins responsible for transporting large proteins across the cell membrane.

Description A: Ion channels operate by allowing passive movement of ions down their electrochemical gradients.
Description B: Ion channels use ATP to actively transport ions against their electrochemical gradients.

Description A: Voltage-gated channels are regulated by changes in membrane potential.
Description B: Voltage-gated channels are regulated by binding of chemical transmitters to the extracellular membrane.

Description A: The negative resting potential in nerve cells is largely determined by potassium (K+) channels, which are 100-fold more permeable to K+ than to Na+.
Description B: The negative resting potential in nerve cells is largely determined by sodium (Na+) channels, which are 100-fold more permeable to Na+ than to K+.

Description A: Voltage-gated channels can act as temperature sensors in some cases, where temperature changes shift their gating potential.
Description B: Voltage-gated channels are only sensitive to membrane voltage changes and not physical factors like temperature.

Description A: Ion flux through channels is passive and determined by electrostatic and diffusional driving forces.
Description B: Ion flux through channels requires metabolic energy to pump ions across the membrane.

Description A: Ion pumps are slower than ion channels because pumps require conformational changes to move ions across the membrane.
Description B: Ion pumps are faster than ion channels because they actively bind and shuttle ions across the membrane.

Description A: Ligand-gated ion channels are activated by the binding of chemical ligands like neurotransmitters.
Description B: Ligand-gated ion channels are activated by changes in temperature rather than chemical ligands.

Description A: Ion channel gating allows them to transition between open and closed states based on specific stimuli.
Description B: Ion channel gating ensures they remain constantly open regardless of stimuli.

Description A: The high ion conductivity of channels allows for rapid electrical signaling in neurons.
Description B: The high ion conductivity of channels limits neurons to slow electrical signaling.

Description A: The neural plate arises from a restricted region of the ectoderm and gives rise to the central and peripheral nervous systems.
Description B: The neural plate arises from a restricted region of the mesoderm and gives rise to the central and peripheral nervous systems.

Description A: The mesoderm gives rise to muscle, connective tissues, and much of the vascular system.
Description B: The mesoderm gives rise to the gut, lungs, pancreas, and liver.

Description A: The caudal region of the neural tube gives rise to the spinal cord, while the rostral region becomes the brain.
Description B: The rostral region of the neural tube gives rise to the spinal cord, while the caudal region becomes the brain.

Description A: Neurulation is the process where the neural plate invaginates and separates from the ectoderm to form the neural tube.
Description B: Neurulation is the process where the neural plate flattens and forms the epidermal skin layers.

Description A: The organizer region secretes signals that induce the formation of the neural plate via neural induction.
Description B: The organizer region secretes signals that suppress the formation of the neural plate.

Description A: Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) suppress neural differentiation and promote epidermal fate in ectodermal cells.
Description B: Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) promote neural differentiation and suppress epidermal fate in ectodermal cells.

Description A: The spinal cord regions involved in motor output development are located mainly in the ventral half.
Description B: The spinal cord regions involved in motor output development are located mainly in the dorsal half.

Description A: FGF8 from the isthmic organizer promotes differentiation of dopaminergic neurons in the midbrain.
Description B: FGF8 from the isthmic organizer promotes differentiation of serotonergic neurons in the midbrain.

Description A: Transcription factors such as Otx2 and Gbx2 mark the midbrain–hindbrain boundary during patterning.
Description B: Transcription factors such as Otx2 and Shh mark the midbrain–hindbrain boundary during patterning.

Description A: The retina originates from the diencephalon as part of forebrain development.
Description B: The retina originates from the myelencephalon as part of hindbrain development.

Description A: When subjects imagine a face, activity in the fusiform gyrus is observed, although less intense than during actual face viewing.
Description B: When subjects imagine a face, activity is observed in the parahippocampal place area, although less intense than during actual face viewing.

Description A: In the change blindness paradigm, when a face is perceived consciously, increased activity is observed in the parietal and frontal cortices along with the fusiform gyrus.
Description B: In the change blindness paradigm, when a face is perceived consciously, increased activity is observed only in the fusiform gyrus without parietal and frontal cortex involvement.

Description A: Patients with damage to the medial temporal lobe often lose episodic memory but retain procedural memory, such as learning new motor skills.
Description B: Patients with damage to the medial temporal lobe often lose procedural memory but retain episodic memory, such as vividly recalling past events.

Description A: Patients with prosopagnosia cannot recognize faces even if they belong to close relatives but can infer familiarity from emotional responses.
Description B: Patients with prosopagnosia recognize faces if they belong to close relatives due to heightened emotional responses.

Description A: Charles Bonnet syndrome involves visual hallucinations, such as patterns, faces, or colored patches, originating from increased activity in the secondary visual cortex.
Description B: Charles Bonnet syndrome involves auditory hallucinations, such as hearing voices, originating from increased activity in the secondary auditory cortex.

Description A: Capgras syndrome is explained as the recognition of familiar faces without the expected emotional response, leading to the belief that the person is an impostor.
Description B: Capgras syndrome is explained as the failure to recognize faces at all, leading to the belief that the person is an impostor.

Description A: The fusiform face area (FFA) is specialized for the recognition of faces, while the parahippocampal place area (PPA) processes the recognition of locations.
Description B: The parahippocampal place area (PPA) is specialized for the recognition of faces, while the fusiform face area (FFA) processes the recognition of locations.

Description A: Unconscious visuomotor computations enabled patient D.F., suffering from form agnosia, to orient her hand correctly while inserting a card into a slot.
Description B: Unconscious cognitive computations allowed patient D.F., suffering from form agnosia, to verbally describe the orientation of a slot accurately.

Description A: In phantom limb sensations, predicted proprioceptive feedback explains why patients feel missing limbs undergoing movements.
Description B: In phantom limb sensations, actual sensory feedback from remaining nerves explains why patients feel missing limbs undergoing movements.

Description A: Benjamin Libet’s experiments showed that readiness potentials in the brain occur before the conscious intention to act, raising questions about free will.
Description B: Benjamin Libet’s experiments showed that conscious intentions to act occur before any readiness potentials in the brain, affirming free will.

Description A: At rest, the extracellular surface of the membrane has an excess of positive charge and the cytoplasmic surface an excess of negative charge.
Description B: At rest, the extracellular surface of the membrane has an excess of negative charge and the cytoplasmic surface an excess of positive charge.

Description A: Resting ion channels are primarily responsible for maintaining the resting membrane potential.
Description B: Voltage-gated ion channels are primarily responsible for maintaining the resting membrane potential.

Description A: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports three Na+ ions out of the cell and two K+ ions into the cell.
Description B: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports three K+ ions out of the cell and two Na+ ions into the cell.

Description A: The resting membrane potential in most neurons is between -60 mV and -70 mV.
Description B: The resting membrane potential in most neurons is between +60 mV and +70 mV.

Description A: The net movement of positive charge is defined as the direction of the electric current.
Description B: The net movement of negative charge is defined as the direction of the electric current.

Description A: Glial cells have resting ion channels primarily permeable only to K+ ions.
Description B: Glial cells have resting ion channels primarily permeable to Na+ and Cl− ions.

Description A: The Nernst equation is used to calculate the equilibrium potential for a specific ion species.
Description B: The Nernst equation is used to measure the membrane permeability directly.

Description A: The Na+-K+ pump contributes to the resting potential by extruding Na+ ions and bringing in K+ ions.
Description B: The Na+-K+ pump contributes to the resting potential by extruding K+ ions and bringing in Na+ ions.

Description A: Depolarization is a reduction or reversal of the charge separation across the membrane, making it less negative.
Description B: Depolarization is an increase in the charge separation across the membrane, making it more negative.

Description A: Hyperpolarization refers to an increase in the charge separation, leading to a more negative membrane potential.
Description B: Hyperpolarization refers to a decrease in the charge separation, leading to a less negative membrane potential.

Description A: The survival of motor neurons depends on trophic signals from their muscle targets, as demonstrated by Viktor Hamburger's experiments on chick embryos.
Description B: The survival of motor neurons depends solely on intrinsic factors and does not involve trophic signals from muscle targets, as demonstrated by Viktor Hamburger's experiments on chick embryos.

Description A: Neurotrophic factors like NGF prevent cell death by suppressing the synthesis of lethal proteins in neurons.
Description B: Neurotrophic factors like NGF promote cell death by stimulating the synthesis of lethal proteins in neurons.

Description A: Neurotrophins bind to Trk receptors to promote neuronal survival and maturation through intracellular signaling pathways.
Description B: Neurotrophins bind to Trk receptors to promote the apoptosis of neurons through intracellular signaling pathways.

Description A: Motor neurons benefit from GDNF and interleukin-6-like proteins to support their survival.
Description B: Motor neurons benefit only from a single neurotrophic factor to support their survival.

Description A: Both extrinsic and intrinsic pathways activate caspases that lead to apoptotic death of neurons.
Description B: Intrinsic pathways alone, without involvement of extrinsic signals, are responsible for the apoptotic death of neurons.

Description A: Neurons extend axons toward target cells that secrete neurotrophic factors, which promote neuronal survival through receptor-bound signaling.
Description B: Neurons extend axons toward target cells that secrete neurotrophic factors, which initiate neuronal apoptosis through receptor-bound signaling.

Description A: Withdrawal of neurotrophic factors from neurons triggers apoptosis by shifting the balance from antiapoptotic to proapoptotic Bcl-2 family members.
Description B: Withdrawal of neurotrophic factors from neurons promotes cell survival by shifting the balance from antiapoptotic to proapoptotic Bcl-2 family members.

Description A: Neurodegenerative disorders often involve apoptotic neuronal death mediated by caspases.
Description B: Neurodegenerative disorders often involve neuronal survival mediated by caspases.

Description A: Proprioceptive sensory neurons that innervate muscle spindles depend on neurotrophin-3 (NT-3) for survival.
Description B: Proprioceptive sensory neurons that innervate muscle spindles depend on brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) for survival.

Description A: Binding of nerve growth factor (NGF) to TrkA receptors activates intracellular pathways promoting neuronal survival and differentiation.
Description B: Binding of nerve growth factor (NGF) to TrkA receptors blocks intracellular pathways promoting neuronal survival and differentiation.

Description A: The size and position of receptive fields on the skin are not fixed permanently but can be modified by experience or injury to sensory nerves.
Description B: The size and position of receptive fields on the skin are fixed permanently and cannot be modified by experience or injury to sensory nerves.

Description A: S-II neurons have larger receptive fields than S-I neurons, often covering the entire hand and sometimes being bilateral.
Description B: S-II neurons have smaller receptive fields than S-I neurons, covering only localized areas of a single hand.

Description A: Higher centers in the brain use inhibitory circuits to suppress distracting inputs and focus on relevant information during skilled tasks.
Description B: Higher centers in the brain exclusively rely on excitatory circuits to amplify distracting inputs and enhance attention during skilled tasks.

Description A: The ventral and dorsal regions of the parietal lobe serve complementary functions in the touch system, similar to the 'what' and 'where' pathways of vision.
Description B: The ventral and dorsal regions of the parietal lobe serve identical functions in touch processing and are not analogous to the 'what' and 'where' pathways of vision.

Description A: S-II neurons do not represent vibration as periodic spike trains linked to the oscillatory frequency but instead abstract temporal or intensive properties of the vibratory stimulus.
Description B: S-II neurons represent vibration strictly as periodic spike trains linked directly to the oscillatory frequency at all times.

Description A: S-II neurons combine input from both the contralateral and ipsilateral hands, allowing us to perceive large objects such as watermelons with both hands.
Description B: S-II neurons process input exclusively from individual contralateral hands, making it impossible to perceive large objects such as watermelons with both hands.

Description A: Lesions in the posterior parietal cortex result in profound deficits in complex tactile recognition tasks but relatively mild impairments in simple somatosensory tests.
Description B: Lesions in the posterior parietal cortex result in severe deficits in simple somatosensory tests but minor impairments in complex tactile recognition tasks.

Description A: Experimental ablation of somatosensory areas in monkeys has shown deficits in texture and shape discrimination when S-II cortex is removed.
Description B: Experimental ablation of somatosensory areas in monkeys has no impact on texture or shape discrimination, even when S-II cortex is removed.

Description A: S-II responses to vibration depend on the context of prior stimuli, with neurons firing differently based on whether the preceding stimulus frequency was higher or lower.
Description B: S-II responses to vibration are completely unaffected by the context of prior stimuli, with neurons firing the same regardless of preceding stimulus frequency.

Description A: Patients with S-I cortex lesions have difficulty in simple tactile tests but also face pronounced motor deficits during skilled tasks like catching a ball.
Description B: Patients with S-I cortex lesions excel in simple tactile tests and have no motor deficits during skilled tasks like catching a ball.

Description A: Critical periods for binocular interaction development are limited to early postnatal life but can be reopened under certain conditions in adulthood.
Description B: Critical periods for binocular interaction development are restricted to early childhood and cannot be reopened in adulthood under any circumstances.

Description A: Prism goggles can systematically displace the retinal image in adolescent owls, leading to realignment of visual and auditory maps over time.
Description B: Prism goggles can systematically displace the retinal image in mature owls, leading to immediate realignment of visual and auditory maps.

Description A: Plasticity in adulthood is modest and slower compared to early postnatal critical periods, requiring special interventions to activate.
Description B: Plasticity in adulthood matches the potency and speed of early postnatal critical periods, requiring no interventions for activation.

Description A: Critical periods for sensory processing, language, and cognitive functions vary in humans, occurring at different developmental stages.
Description B: Critical periods for sensory processing, language, and cognitive functions occur uniformly across humans without variation in timing.

Description A: Juvenile owls wearing prism goggles display adaptive auditory remapping to align with displaced visual fields.
Description B: Juvenile owls wearing prism goggles lack any adaptive auditory remapping, resulting in permanent misalignment between visual and auditory fields.

Description A: Certain visual neurons in cats exhibit earlier critical periods for orientation selectivity compared to ocular dominance development.
Description B: Visual neurons in cats exhibit concurrent critical periods for orientation selectivity and ocular dominance development.

Description A: Neural maps in the barn owl are misaligned after prism goggles are applied, but can realign over time through auditory map adaptation.
Description B: Neural maps in the barn owl remain permanently misaligned after prism goggles are applied, with no capability for auditory map adaptation.

Description A: Environmental enrichment and social interaction can enhance ocular dominance plasticity in adult mice following deprivation.
Description B: Environmental enrichment and social interaction have no measurable effect on ocular dominance plasticity in adult mice following deprivation.

Description A: Critical periods may allow brains to adapt optimally to their environment during development but limit excessive changes later.
Description B: Critical periods enable brains to continually reorganize throughout life without limits on plasticity or resistance to excessive changes.

Description A: Following monocular deprivation, structural remodeling of thalamic axons occurs after functional changes in visual input.
Description B: Following monocular deprivation, structural remodeling of thalamic axons occurs before any functional changes in visual input.

Description A: Each dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neuron has a single axon with two branches: one projecting to the periphery and another to the central nervous system.
Description B: Each dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neuron has multiple axons, each projecting to different regions of the body and brain.

Description A: Thermal sensations are crucial for regulating body temperature and maintaining homeostasis at around 37°C (98.6°F).
Description B: Thermal sensations have little impact on body temperature regulation and homeostatic mechanisms.

Description A: DRG neurons involved in touch and proprioception have large cell bodies and are heavily myelinated.
Description B: DRG neurons involved in touch and proprioception have small cell bodies and are not myelinated.

Description A: The sensory systems respond to four elementary features of stimuli: modality, location, intensity, and duration.
Description B: The sensory systems respond to only three elementary features of stimuli: modality, location, and intensity.

Description A: Proprioception enables conscious awareness of posture and movements, especially in limbs and the head.
Description B: Proprioception governs only unconscious reflexes and does not allow conscious awareness of posture or movement.

Description A: Peripheral nerves include both sensory axons and motor axons that innervate muscles, blood vessels, glands, and viscera.
Description B: Peripheral nerves carry either sensory or motor axons but never both within the same nerve.

Description A: Associationist philosophers like James and John Stuart Mill proposed that experiences occurring close together forge strong associations for learning.
Description B: Associationist philosophers like James and John Stuart Mill argued that experiences occurring at random intervals create the strongest associations for learning.

Description A: Action potentials in peripheral nerves convey sensory information in a digital pulse code over long distances.
Description B: Action potentials in peripheral nerves convey sensory information as analog signals proportional to stimulus intensity.

Description A: Experiences with visual landmarks during repeated trips to a location can make the journey feel more familiar and faster over time.
Description B: Experiences with visual landmarks during repeated trips to a location make the journey seem longer and monotonous over time.

Description A: The efficiency of neural codes in sensory systems allows fine detail to be preserved while related stimuli are generalized.
Description B: The efficiency of neural codes in sensory systems sacrifices fine detail in order to completely suppress generalizations.

Description A: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a paradigmatic neuropsychiatric syndrome due to its etiological and phenotypic heterogeneity.
Description B: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is primarily characterized by its uniform genetic risk profile and minimal phenotypic variation.

Description A: The term 'Asperger syndrome' was eliminated in the DSM-5 in favor of including variations within a single spectrum construct.
Description B: The term 'Asperger syndrome' is still recognized in the DSM-5 as a separate and distinct disorder from Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).

Description A: The prevalence of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is estimated to be as high as 2.6%, far higher than just a few decades ago.
Description B: The prevalence of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) has decreased significantly over the last few decades, with an estimated prevalence now below 0.5%.

Description A: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) must be detectable before the age of 3 years, but recent studies suggest identification is possible within the first year of life in high-risk families.
Description B: Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) typically cannot be detected until a child is older than 10 years of age, even in high-risk families.

Description A: Diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is based on behavioral criteria due to the absence of definitive biological markers.
Description B: Diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is based on the clear identification of definitive genetic and biological markers.

Description A: Approximately 10% of children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) show significant improvement with little or no evidence of social disability later in life.
Description B: Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) rarely show improvement in social disabilities, and progress is generally unattainable.

Description A: The Sally-Anne test is used to evaluate 'mind blindness' in children with autism, revealing deficits in predicting others' beliefs.
Description B: The Sally-Anne test is designed to measure physical coordination abilities in children with autism.

Description A: Approximately 60% to 90% of monozygotic twins are concordant for Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), depending on diagnostic criteria.
Description B: Concordance rates for Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) are generally the same between monozygotic and dizygotic twins.

Description A: Rett syndrome, typically affecting girls, is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the MECP2 gene.
Description B: Rett syndrome, typically affecting boys, is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the FMR1 gene.

Description A: The absence of preferential attention to social stimuli in infancy is considered an early sign of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).
Description B: Preferential attention to social stimuli in infancy is considered an early sign of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).

Description A: Odorants are detected by olfactory sensory neurons embedded in the specialized olfactory epithelium lining a part of the nasal cavity.
Description B: Odorants are detected by basal stem cells embedded in the specialized olfactory epithelium lining a part of the nasal cavity.

Description A: The olfactory sensory neurons are interspersed with supporting cells and are continuously replaced from a layer of basal stem cells.
Description B: The olfactory sensory neurons connect directly to the olfactory cortex without being interspersed with supporting cells.

Description A: Humans have approximately 350 different types of odorant receptors belonging to the G protein–coupled receptor superfamily.
Description B: Humans have approximately 1000 different types of odorant receptors belonging to the G protein–coupled receptor superfamily.

Description A: The cilia of olfactory sensory neurons contain both odorant receptors and transduction machinery required to generate electrical signals.
Description B: The axons of olfactory sensory neurons contain both odorant receptors and transduction machinery required to generate electrical signals.

Description A: The axons of olfactory sensory neurons terminate in the olfactory bulb after passing through the perforated cribriform plate.
Description B: The axons of olfactory sensory neurons terminate in the olfactory cortex after passing through the perforated cribriform plate.

Description A: Trace amine-associated receptors (TAARs) are G protein–coupled receptors expressed in the olfactory epithelium and recognize volatile amines.
Description B: Trace amine-associated receptors (TAARs) are specialized basal stem cells found in the olfactory epithelium and recognize volatile amines.

Description A: Odorant receptors in the olfactory epithelium have seven hydrophobic transmembrane domains.
Description B: Odorant receptors in the olfactory epithelium have five hydrophobic transmembrane domains.

Description A: Olfactory sensory neurons in humans are relatively short-lived, lasting only 30 to 60 days, and are replaced continuously.
Description B: Olfactory sensory neurons in humans are long-lived, lasting several years, and are replaced continuously.

Description A: Odorant binding occurs in a pocket formed by the transmembrane domains of G protein–coupled odorant receptors.
Description B: Odorant binding occurs in the extracellular region of G protein–coupled odorant receptors, outside of the transmembrane domains.

Description A: Humans have odorant receptors with variable amino acid sequences, allowing recognition of structurally diverse ligands.
Description B: Humans have odorant receptors with uniform amino acid sequences, making recognition of structurally diverse ligands impossible.

Description A: Electrical synaptic transmission allows for near-instantaneous signal propagation between neurons.
Description B: Electrical synaptic transmission requires more time than chemical transmission due to additional biochemical steps.

Description A: Gap-junction channels are formed by a pair of hemichannels, called connexons, from the presynaptic and postsynaptic cells.
Description B: Gap-junction channels are formed exclusively by a single connexon provided by the presynaptic cell.

Description A: The pore diameter of a gap-junction channel is approximately 1.5 nm, which allows the passage of small inorganic ions and some organic molecules.
Description B: The pore diameter of a gap-junction channel is approximately 0.3 nm, restricting it to only passing a few ions.

Description A: Connexin 36 is the primary connexin found in neuronal gap-junction channels in mammals.
Description B: Connexin 26 is the primary connexin found in neuronal gap-junction channels in mammals.

Description A: Electrical synapses transmit both depolarizing and hyperpolarizing currents between cells.
Description B: Electrical synapses transmit only depolarizing currents between cells.

Description A: Rectifying synapses allow current to pass in one direction only, from the presynaptic to the postsynaptic cell.
Description B: Rectifying synapses allow current to pass equally in both directions between the presynaptic and postsynaptic cells.

Description A: In chemical synapses, neurotransmitters diffuse across a synaptic cleft that is typically 20–40 nm wide.
Description B: In chemical synapses, neurotransmitters diffuse directly through the membranes of the presynaptic and postsynaptic cells.

Description A: Ionotropic receptors mediate fast synaptic transmission by directly gating ion channels.
Description B: Ionotropic receptors mediate slow synaptic modulation through second messengers.

Description A: Metabotropic receptors often generate responses through second messengers like cAMP, resulting in slower synaptic modulation.
Description B: Metabotropic receptors directly open ion channels, generating fast synaptic responses.

Description A: Electrical synapses are particularly suited for synchronizing the activity of populations of neurons due to their fast signal transmission.
Description B: Electrical synapses are not suited for synchronizing neuronal activity because they process signals too slowly.

Description A: Long-term facilitation of sensory to motor neuron synapses involves CREB-1 activation and reduced CREB-2 protein levels.
Description B: Long-term facilitation of sensory to motor neuron synapses involves CREB-2 activation and reduced CREB-1 protein levels.

Description A: Serotonin downregulates miRNA-124 levels through a MAPK-dependent mechanism, enhancing CREB-1 activity.
Description B: Serotonin upregulates miRNA-124 levels through a MAPK-independent mechanism, suppressing CREB-1 activity.

Description A: piRNA-F binds to the Piwi protein and leads to methylation of the CREB-2 gene, reducing CREB-2 protein levels.
Description B: piRNA-F binds to the Piwi protein and leads to methylation of the CREB-1 gene, reducing CREB-1 protein levels.

Description A: Long-term synaptic growth requires local protein synthesis for maintenance beyond 24 hours.
Description B: Long-term synaptic growth requires local protein synthesis for initiation within the first 24 hours.

Description A: Long-term facilitation is synapse specific and occurs only at synapses stimulated by serotonin.
Description B: Long-term facilitation affects all synapses of a neuron regardless of serotonin stimulation.

Description A: CPEB functions as a prion-like protein to stabilize synaptic changes required for long-term facilitation.
Description B: CPEB functions as a standard protein without prion-like properties to stabilize synaptic changes.

Description A: Blocking local protein synthesis only affects the maintenance of synaptic growth after 24 hours.
Description B: Blocking local protein synthesis prevents the onset of synaptic growth from the initial stages.

Description A: Reconsolidation of memory involves protein degradation and subsequent new protein synthesis.
Description B: Reconsolidation of memory exclusively relies on protein degradation without new protein synthesis.

Description A: Synaptic tagging allows marked synapses to make use of proteins synthesized in response to serotonin.
Description B: Synaptic tagging prevents marked synapses from utilizing proteins synthesized in response to serotonin.

Description A: Serotonin-triggered synaptic facilitation involves both nuclear gene transcription and local protein synthesis.
Description B: Serotonin-triggered synaptic facilitation relies entirely on local protein synthesis without nuclear gene transcription.

Description A: The vestibular nerve projects ipsilaterally from the vestibular ganglion mainly to four vestibular nuclei in the dorsal part of the pons and medulla.
Description B: The vestibular nerve projects contralaterally from the vestibular ganglion mainly to four vestibular nuclei in the dorsal part of the pons and medulla.

Description A: The saccules are especially sensitive to vertical accelerations.
Description B: The saccules are especially sensitive to horizontal accelerations.

Description A: The lateral vestibular nucleus receives fibers from the semicircular canals medially and the otolith organs laterally.
Description B: The lateral vestibular nucleus receives fibers from the otolith organs medially and the semicircular canals laterally.

Description A: The rotational vestibulo-ocular reflex compensates for head rotation and receives its input predominantly from the semicircular canals.
Description B: The rotational vestibulo-ocular reflex compensates for head rotation and receives its input predominantly from the otolith organs.

Description A: Damage to the cerebellar flocculus impairs the ability to modulate the gain of the vestibulo-ocular reflex.
Description B: Damage to the cerebellar flocculus enhances the ability to modulate the gain of the vestibulo-ocular reflex.

Description A: The vestibular nuclei project to the oculomotor nuclei, reticular formation, lateral medullary nuclei, thalamus, and cerebellum.
Description B: The vestibular nuclei project to the oculomotor nuclei, spinal cord, prefrontal cortex, thalamus, and cerebellum.

Description A: The oculomotor center outputs include the abducens, oculomotor, and trochlear nuclei.
Description B: The oculomotor center outputs include the trigeminal, oculomotor, and trochlear nuclei.

Description A: Individual vestibular nuclei neurons can play roles in eye movements, head movements, and even posture.
Description B: Individual vestibular nuclei neurons exclusively coordinate eye movements without involvement in head movements or posture.

Description A: The translational vestibulo-ocular reflex compensates for linear head movements.
Description B: The translational vestibulo-ocular reflex compensates for rotational head movements.

Description A: The direction of nystagmus is clinically defined by the direction of its quick phase.
Description B: The direction of nystagmus is clinically defined by the direction of its slow phase.

Description A: Stimulation of the left PMRF during the swing phase of the left limb produces a transient increase in the electromyogram activity of the left flexor muscles and a simultaneous decrease in activity in the right extensor muscles.
Description B: Stimulation of the left PMRF during the swing phase of the left limb produces a transient increase in the electromyogram activity of the left extensor muscles and a simultaneous decrease in activity in the right flexor muscles.

Description A: Lesions in the posterior parietal cortex (PPC) cause walking cats to misplace the positioning of their paws as they approach an obstacle, increasing the probability of contact with the obstacle.
Description B: Lesions in the posterior parietal cortex (PPC) improve walking cats' ability to navigate around obstacles, reducing the probability of contact with the obstacle.

Description A: The motor cortex is essential for visually guided locomotion, especially when precise limb trajectory and foot placement adjustments are required.
Description B: The motor cortex is not essential for visually guided locomotion and does not contribute to precise limb trajectory or foot placement adjustments.

Description A: During locomotion, the cerebellum integrates motor commands, proprioceptive input, and state information from the spinal circuits to correct motor errors.
Description B: During locomotion, the cerebellum only processes visual input and does not integrate motor commands or spinal circuit information.

Description A: Treadmill training combined with weight support helps patients with partial spinal cord injury improve locomotor function by facilitating spinal circuit activity.
Description B: Treadmill training combined with weight support is ineffective at improving locomotor function in patients with partial spinal cord injury.

Description A: Patients with Parkinson's disease exhibit a characteristic slow, shuffling gait, caused by disruptions in basal ganglia function.
Description B: Patients with Parkinson's disease exhibit a fast, coordinated gait, caused by improvements in basal ganglia function.

Description A: Human infants display rhythmic stepping movements immediately after birth, suggesting innate central pattern generators in the spinal cord.
Description B: Human infants do not display rhythmic stepping movements after birth, indicating the absence of central pattern generators in the spinal cord.

Description A: Precise corticospinal control enables humans to adapt locomotor rhythms to complex terrains and obstacles.
Description B: Corticospinal control does not play a role in helping humans adapt locomotor rhythms to complex terrains and obstacles.

Description A: Damage to the cerebellum impairs limb coordination and produces ataxia during locomotion.
Description B: Damage to the cerebellum enhances limb coordination and prevents ataxia during locomotion.

Description A: Computational modeling of locomotor circuits helps reveal the dynamic interactions within neural networks, offering insights into rhythm and pattern generation.
Description B: Computational modeling is irrelevant for studying locomotor neural networks and cannot provide insights into rhythm and pattern generation.

Description A: Microglia in the dorsal horn are activated due to damage to the peripheral branch of primary sensory neurons.
Description B: Microglia in the dorsal horn are activated due to damage to the central branch of primary sensory neurons.

Description A: The spinothalamic tract has a crucial role in the transmission of nociceptive information.
Description B: The spinoreticular tract has a crucial role in the transmission of nociceptive information.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral thalamic nuclei process information about the precise location of an injury.
Description B: Neurons in the medial thalamic nuclei process information about the precise location of an injury.

Description A: Lesioning the spinothalamic tract can reduce sensation of pain contralateral to the lesion.
Description B: Lesioning the spinothalamic tract can reduce sensation of pain ipsilateral to the lesion.

Description A: The insular cortex processes information about the internal state of the body and contributes to autonomic components of pain responses.
Description B: The somatosensory cortex processes information about the internal state of the body and contributes to autonomic components of pain responses.

Description A: Electrical stimulation of the periaqueductal gray matter can selectively block nociception.
Description B: Electrical stimulation of the anterior cingulate cortex can selectively block nociception.

Description A: The gate control theory of pain suggests that nonnociceptive inputs can attenuate pain by closing a 'gate' at the dorsal horn.
Description B: The gate control theory of pain suggests that only nociceptive inputs can modulate the 'gate' at the dorsal horn.

Description A: Dynorphins interact primarily with kappa (κ) opioid receptors.
Description B: Dynorphins interact primarily with mu (μ) opioid receptors.

Description A: Neurons in the anterior cingulate cortex integrate the emotional aspects of pain.
Description B: Neurons in the anterior cingulate cortex integrate the sensory aspects of pain.

Description A: Morphine is more effective for persistent 'second pain' than for fast, acute 'first pain.'
Description B: Morphine is more effective for fast, acute 'first pain' than for persistent 'second pain.'

Description A: Cranial nerves mediate the sensory and motor functions of the face and head, as well as the autonomic functions of the body.
Description B: Cranial nerves do not mediate the autonomic functions of the body, only the sensory functions of the face and motor functions of the head.

Description A: The trochlear (IV) nerve exits from the dorsal surface of the midbrain, behind the inferior colliculus.
Description B: The trochlear (IV) nerve exits from the ventral surface of the brain stem, like all other cranial nerves.

Description A: The oculomotor (III) nerve provides parasympathetic innervation responsible for pupillary constriction and lens accommodation.
Description B: The oculomotor (III) nerve provides somatic motor innervation only and is not responsible for parasympathetic functions.

Description A: The reticular formation in the brain stem contains glutamatergic and GABAergic circuitry that regulates wake–sleep cycles and breathing.
Description B: The reticular formation in the brain stem contains glutamatergic circuitry, but does not use GABAergic processes for regulating breathing or wake–sleep cycles.

Description A: Hydranencephalic infants can cry, smile, and suckle despite not having a forebrain, as the brain stem organizes such behaviors.
Description B: Hydranencephalic infants cannot cry, smile, or suckle, as such behaviors are controlled exclusively by the forebrain.

Description A: The glossopharyngeal (IX) nerve transmits visceral information about blood oxygen and carbon dioxide levels from the carotid body.
Description B: The glossopharyngeal (IX) nerve transmits visceral information about blood oxygen and carbon dioxide levels from the vagus nerve.

Description A: The vagus (X) nerve provides parasympathetic control to most of the internal organs in the neck, thorax, and abdomen.
Description B: The vagus (X) nerve provides motor control to facial expression but does not participate in autonomic regulation.

Description A: Cranial nerve reflexes involve both mono- and polysynaptic brain stem relays for coordination of simple behaviors.
Description B: Cranial nerve reflexes involve only monosynaptic relays and do not use polysynaptic pathways in the brain stem.

Description A: The three sensory divisions of the trigeminal (V) nerve innervate distinct areas of the face, scalp, and oral cavity.
Description B: The three sensory divisions of the trigeminal (V) nerve only innervate the muscles of mastication and the tongue.

Description A: The spinal accessory (XI) nerve is purely motor and innervates the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles.
Description B: The spinal accessory (XI) nerve includes both motor and sensory functions and innervates the entire neck musculature.

Description A: The oculomotor system uses visual information to guide eye movements, requiring coordination of 12 muscles that move the two eyes.
Description B: The oculomotor system uses auditory information to guide eye movements, requiring coordination of 12 muscles that move the two eyes.

Description A: Horizontal rotation of the eye away from the nose is called abduction, while rotation toward the nose is called adduction.
Description B: Horizontal rotation of the eye away from the nose is called adduction, while rotation toward the nose is called abduction.

Description A: The lateral rectus muscle abducts the eye, and the medial rectus muscle adducts it.
Description B: The lateral rectus muscle adducts the eye, and the medial rectus muscle abducts it.

Description A: The superior oblique muscle depresses the eye when it is adducted, but intorts the eye when it is abducted.
Description B: The superior oblique muscle elevates the eye when it is adducted, but extorts the eye when it is abducted.

Description A: The primary role of the oculomotor system in humans is to position the fovea, which provides the sharpest vision, onto objects of interest.
Description B: The primary role of the oculomotor system in humans is to position the peripheral retina onto objects of interest.

Description A: The six extraocular muscles are grouped into three agonist-antagonist pairs.
Description B: The six extraocular muscles are grouped into six distinct agonist-antagonist pairs.

Description A: The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) innervates the superior oblique muscle, which passes through a bony pulley called the trochlea.
Description B: The trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV) innervates the inferior oblique muscle, which passes through a bony pulley called the trochlea.

Description A: Binocular vision allows stereopsis and depth perception by overlapping the visual fields of the two eyes.
Description B: Binocular vision removes stereopsis and depth perception by separating the visual fields of the two eyes.

Description A: The medial and lateral recti muscles rotate the eyes horizontally—adduction for the medial rectus and abduction for the lateral rectus.
Description B: The medial and lateral recti muscles rotate the eyes vertically—elevation for the medial rectus and depression for the lateral rectus.

Description A: Lesions of the abducens nerve result in the inability of the eye to abduct beyond the midline.
Description B: Lesions of the abducens nerve result in the inability of the eye to adduct beyond the midline.

Description A: Patients with multiple sclerosis can learn to improve their postural control with practice but may need more practice to retain the improvement compared to healthy individuals.
Description B: Patients with multiple sclerosis cannot learn to improve their postural control with practice regardless of effort.

Description A: During voluntary arm pulls in a supported stance, anticipatory leg muscle activity is unnecessary due to reliance on external support for postural stability.
Description B: During voluntary arm pulls in a supported stance, anticipatory leg muscle activity is necessary despite external support.

Description A: Postural equilibrium during walking depends on precise foot placement, which controls the speed and trajectory of the center of mass.
Description B: Postural equilibrium during walking is unaffected by foot placement and controlled solely by visual cues.

Description A: Vestibular information is critical when visual and somatosensory cues are ambiguous or absent during challenging postural tasks.
Description B: Vestibular information is insignificant when visual and somatosensory cues are ambiguous or absent during challenging postural tasks.

Description A: Visual inputs can induce illusions of motion, leading to compensatory tilting of the body.
Description B: Visual inputs are incapable of inducing illusions of motion or compensatory body tilts.

Description A: Loss of large-diameter somatosensory fibers leads to delays in automatic postural responses, increasing the risk of falls.
Description B: Loss of large-diameter somatosensory fibers improves automatic postural response timings, reducing the risk of falls.

Description A: The body schema integrates sensory information from somatosensory, vestibular, and visual systems to compute postural orientation.
Description B: The body schema functions independently of sensory inputs, relying solely on motor commands for postural orientation.

Description A: Individual sensory modalities can provide ambiguous information about postural orientation and motion.
Description B: Individual sensory modalities always provide accurate and unambiguous information about postural orientation and motion.

Description A: Patients with vestibular deficits depend on somatosensory inputs, leading to postural instability during surface tilts.
Description B: Patients with vestibular deficits compensate effectively using visual inputs, eliminating postural instability during surface tilts.

Description A: Visual processing is too slow to significantly affect rapid postural responses to sudden disturbances.
Description B: Visual processing is the fastest modality for regulating rapid postural responses to sudden disturbances.

Description A: In tritanopes, the loss of S-cone function arises from mutations in the S-pigment gene.
Description B: In tritanopes, the loss of S-cone function arises from mutations in the L-pigment gene.

Description A: For vision under low-light conditions, the mammalian retina has an ON bipolar cell that is exclusively connected to rods.
Description B: For vision under low-light conditions, the mammalian retina has an OFF bipolar cell that is exclusively connected to rods.

Description A: Retinal ganglion cells encode a 10-fold range of image intensities caused by object reflectances, instead of a 10-billion-fold range caused by ambient illumination variations.
Description B: Retinal ganglion cells encode a 10-billion-fold range of image intensities caused by object reflectances, instead of a 10-fold range caused by ambient illumination variations.

Description A: The lateral shifting of the stimulus–response relationship is a hallmark of light adaptation in the retina.
Description B: The lateral shifting of the stimulus–response relationship is a hallmark of color adaptation in the retina.

Description A: Under Weber’s law, threshold flash intensity should be proportional to the background intensity.
Description B: Under Weber’s law, threshold flash intensity should decrease as background intensity increases.

Description A: Light adaptation involves gain changes at multiple sites within the retina.
Description B: Light adaptation does not involve gain changes at any site within the retina but occurs entirely in the brain.

Description A: By dawn, rod cells saturate and cones take over due to gradual stimulation by increasing light intensities.
Description B: By dawn, cone cells saturate and rods take over due to gradual stimulation by increasing light intensities.

Description A: Calcium-dependent feedback pathways within photoreceptors help regulate light adaptation.
Description B: Potassium-dependent feedback pathways within photoreceptors help regulate light adaptation.

Description A: In bright light, ganglion cells often display strong center-surround antagonism in their receptive fields.
Description B: In bright light, ganglion cells often lose their center-surround antagonism in their receptive fields.

Description A: Dopamine released by specialized amacrine cells regulates changes in lateral inhibition.
Description B: Serotonin released by specialized amacrine cells regulates changes in lateral inhibition.

Description A: The brain stem regulates wakefulness and sleep and plays a critical role in controlling respiration and heartbeat.
Description B: The brain stem regulates emotions and directly controls cognitive decision-making processes.

Description A: Subcortical brain regions are bidirectionally connected with cortical brain areas, allowing internal state variables to influence cognitive functions.
Description B: Subcortical brain regions are exclusively connected to the motor cortex and cannot influence cognitive functions.

Description A: The hypothalamus maintains physiological stability by regulating the endocrine system and the autonomic nervous system.
Description B: The hypothalamus primarily controls skeletal muscle movement and is unrelated to physiological stability.

Description A: The dopaminergic pathways are involved in processing stimuli related to reinforcement expectation, contributing to motivational states.
Description B: The dopaminergic pathways are exclusively involved in regulating sleep and have no impact on reinforcement or motivation.

Description A: Lesions in the human amygdala impair fear learning, expression, and recognition in others.
Description B: Lesions in the human amygdala improve fear learning and expression while enhancing recognition in others.

Description A: The medial and ventral prefrontal cortex are closely interconnected with the amygdala, influencing emotional regulation and decision-making.
Description B: The medial and ventral prefrontal cortex are isolated from the amygdala and do not influence emotional regulation or decision-making.

Description A: Homeostatic processes in the nervous system have significant behavioral consequences, as studied by early physiologists like Claude Bernard and Walter Cannon.
Description B: Homeostatic processes in the nervous system have minimal behavioral consequences and are mostly unrelated to the work of early physiologists.

Description A: Addictive drugs like nicotine and alcohol impact neural pathways that reinforce survival behaviors.
Description B: Addictive drugs like nicotine and alcohol completely bypass neural pathways related to survival behaviors.

Description A: The amygdala orchestrates emotional responses by interacting with the hypothalamus, brain stem, and cortex.
Description B: The amygdala functions independently of the hypothalamus, brain stem, and cortex in managing emotional responses.

Description A: Disorders of electrical excitation in corticothalamic circuits can lead to conditions like seizures and epilepsy.
Description B: Disorders of electrical excitation in corticothalamic circuits are unrelated to conditions like seizures and epilepsy.

Description A: Loss of gray matter in the prefrontal, temporal, and parietal regions of the cerebral cortex is a well-documented abnormality in schizophrenia.
Description B: Loss of gray matter in the occipital, limbic, and cerebellar regions of the cerebral cortex is a well-documented abnormality in schizophrenia.

Description A: First-degree relatives who do not have a diagnosis of schizophrenia often exhibit cortical gray matter loss intermediate between healthy individuals and those diagnosed with schizophrenia.
Description B: First-degree relatives who do not have a diagnosis of schizophrenia exhibit no differences in cortical gray matter compared to healthy individuals.

Description A: The polygenic risk score provides probabilistic information about susceptibility to schizophrenia and can stratify populations in clinical studies.
Description B: The polygenic risk score provides definitive diagnostic information about schizophrenia and directly determines treatment plans.

Description A: The 22q11.2 microdeletion is the most common and well-studied genetic cause of syndromic schizophrenia.
Description B: The 20q13.3 microdeletion is the most common and well-studied genetic cause of syndromic schizophrenia.

Description A: Schizophrenia is associated with decreased functional connectivity between brain regions, as demonstrated by resting-state functional MRI.
Description B: Schizophrenia is associated with increased functional connectivity between brain regions, as demonstrated by resting-state functional MRI.

Description A: Excessive and inappropriate synaptic pruning during adolescence is a proposed mechanism for schizophrenia.
Description B: Increased synaptic formation during adolescence is a proposed mechanism for schizophrenia.

Description A: Antipsychotic drugs primarily block D2 dopamine receptors in the brain to reduce psychotic symptoms.
Description B: Antipsychotic drugs primarily block serotonin receptors in the brain to reduce psychotic symptoms.

Description A: Abnormal dopamine transmission in subcortical brain regions may contribute to the psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia.
Description B: Abnormal dopamine transmission in cortical brain regions solely accounts for all symptoms of schizophrenia.

Description A: Patients with schizophrenia often demonstrate fewer dendritic spines on pyramidal neurons, reflecting a loss of synaptic contacts.
Description B: Patients with schizophrenia often demonstrate increased dendritic spines on pyramidal neurons, reflecting an overabundance of synaptic contacts.

Description A: Current antipsychotic drugs do not effectively treat the cognitive impairments or deficit symptoms of schizophrenia.
Description B: Current antipsychotic drugs fully resolve cognitive impairments and deficit symptoms of schizophrenia.

Description A: Calcium acts as a second messenger to trigger the release of additional Ca2+ from internal stores by binding to the ryanodine receptor in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum membrane.
Description B: Calcium acts as a second messenger to bind to potassium channels in the plasma membrane to trigger the release of additional Ca2+.

Description A: The ryanodine receptor is opened by cytoplasmic Ca2+ and binds the plant alkaloid ryanodine, which inhibits the receptor.
Description B: The ryanodine receptor is opened by IP3 and is inhibited by cytoplasmic calcium.

Description A: Activation of CaM kinase by the calcium/calmodulin complex results in autophosphorylation, making the enzyme persistently active even in the absence of Ca2+.
Description B: Activation of CaM kinase by the calcium/calmodulin complex depends on the constant presence of Ca2+ to remain active.

Description A: PKA can become persistently active following a prolonged increase in cAMP due to slow degradation of free regulatory subunits via the ubiquitin pathway.
Description B: PKA becomes active only when regulatory subunits increase and cAMP levels decrease rapidly.

Description A: Receptor tyrosine kinases are often monomers in the absence of a ligand and form dimers upon ligand binding, allowing autophosphorylation.
Description B: Receptor tyrosine kinases are dimers in the absence of a ligand and function as monomers upon ligand binding.

Description A: Tyrosine kinases can activate an isoform of phospholipase C, specifically PLCγ, which cleaves PIP2 into IP3 and DAG.
Description B: Tyrosine kinases activate PLCβ to produce ATP and DAG by cleaving PIP2.

Description A: MAP kinases, such as ERK, are activated by specific cascades and can phosphorylate transcription factors important for memory formation.
Description B: MAP kinases, such as ERK, are directly activated by ion channels and do not regulate transcription factors.

Description A: Endocannabinoids such as anandamide and 2-AG are synthesized in postsynaptic neurons and diffuse to presynaptic terminals to inhibit neurotransmitter release.
Description B: Endocannabinoids such as anandamide and 2-AG are stored in vesicles and released at synaptic clefts to enhance neurotransmitter release.

Description A: Nitric oxide stimulates guanylyl cyclase, resulting in the formation of cGMP, a second messenger.
Description B: Nitric oxide inhibits guanylyl cyclase, blocking the formation of cGMP.

Description A: M-type K+ channel closure by muscarinic receptor activation depolarizes the neuronal membrane and enhances excitability.
Description B: M-type K+ channels open in response to muscarinic receptor activation, stabilizing the resting potential and reducing excitability.

Description A: Neurons communicate by two major mechanisms: electrical and chemical synaptic transmission.
Description B: Neurons communicate by only one mechanism: chemical synaptic transmission.

Description A: Electrical synapses are formed at regions of tight apposition called gap junctions, which provide a direct pathway for charge to flow between the cytoplasm of communicating neurons.
Description B: Electrical synapses are formed at regions of loose apposition called gap junctions, which prevent the flow of charge between the cytoplasm of communicating neurons.

Description A: Ionotropic receptors are ligand-gated ion channels that generate ionic currents to excite or inhibit the postsynaptic cell.
Description B: Ionotropic receptors are G-protein coupled receptors that slowly modulate cell behavior.

Description A: The neurotransmitter glutamate is released by rod and cone photoreceptors to form chemical synapses on bipolar cells.
Description B: The neurotransmitter dopamine is released by rod and cone photoreceptors to form chemical synapses on bipolar cells.

Description A: Gap junctions can be regulated by phosphorylation through different protein kinases, which enhance gap-junction coupling.
Description B: Gap junctions cannot be regulated by phosphorylation and remain static in all conditions.

Description A: At chemical synapses, a presynaptic action potential triggers the release of transmitter molecules, activating receptors on postsynaptic cells.
Description B: At chemical synapses, a presynaptic action potential directly causes depolarization in the postsynaptic cell without any transmitter.

Description A: Metabotropic receptors activate signaling pathways involving second messengers, such as cAMP, that regulate protein phosphorylation.
Description B: Metabotropic receptors directly open ion channels with no involvement of intracellular signaling pathways.

Description A: Each connexon in a gap-junction channel is composed of six subunits known as connexins.
Description B: Each connexon in a gap-junction channel is composed of four subunits known as connexins.

Description A: Chemical transmission allows for amplification of the presynaptic action potential through the release of thousands of transmitter molecules and activation of many postsynaptic receptors.
Description B: Chemical transmission does not allow for amplification of presynaptic signals and relies on one-to-one receptor activation.

Description A: Rod and cone photoreceptors respond to light and provide input to bipolar cells, extending their receptive fields via electrical synapses with amacrine cells.
Description B: Rod and cone photoreceptors respond to sound and provide input to bipolar cells, extending their receptive fields directly.

Description A: The center of mass (CoM) is a point that represents the average position of the body’s total mass and is located about 2 cm in front of the second lumbar vertebra in a standing adult.
Description B: The center of mass (CoM) is a point that represents the average position of the body’s total mass and is located about 10 cm behind the second lumbar vertebra in a standing adult.

Description A: Postural equilibrium refers to the ability to actively stabilize the body by resisting external forces like gravity.
Description B: Postural equilibrium refers to the ability of muscles to synchronize automatically to adjust body temperature.

Description A: Maintaining balance while standing requires keeping the downward projection of the center of mass (CoM) within the base of support.
Description B: Maintaining balance while standing requires ensuring the center of pressure (CoP) moves permanently outside the base of support.

Description A: When standing on an unstable surface, vestibular inputs play a greater role in maintaining balance compared to visual inputs.
Description B: When standing on an unstable surface, visual inputs are the primary source for maintaining balance compared to vestibular inputs.

Description A: Antigravity support, or 'postural tone,' requires both active tonic muscle contraction and passive bone-on-bone forces.
Description B: Antigravity support, or 'postural tone,' relies solely on passive bone-on-bone forces and not muscle contractions.

Description A: The base of support for humans standing on two feet is defined by the area under both feet in contact with the ground.
Description B: The base of support for humans standing on two feet is defined by the highest point of the head.

Description A: During balance recovery, the ground reaction force must act to move the center of mass (CoM) back within the base of support.
Description B: During balance recovery, the ground reaction force moves the center of pressure (CoP) permanently outside the base of support.

Description A: Dynamic equilibrium during standing can involve the CoM briefly moving outside the base of support while strategies like counter-rotation stabilize balance.
Description B: Dynamic equilibrium during standing prevents the CoM from ever leaving the base of support under any circumstances.

Description A: Postural responses to sudden disturbances such as platform movements can be adapted and improve with practice over several trials.
Description B: Postural responses to sudden disturbances are instinctual and cannot be modified with practice or experience.

Description A: Humans have postural response delays in ankle muscles of 90–120 ms, primarily due to larger body size and increased signal conduction distances.
Description B: Humans have postural response delays in ankle muscles of 5–10 ms, which occur independently of body size or nervous system limitations.

Description A: Myotonia congenita is caused by mutations in the gene coding for the ClC-1 chloride channel in skeletal muscle, leading to a decrease in chloride influx and resulting in membrane depolarization and repetitive firing.
Description B: Myotonia congenita is caused by mutations in the gene coding for the Na+ channel in skeletal muscle, leading to an increase in chloride influx and membrane hyperpolarization.

Description A: Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is caused by leaky ion channels arising from missense mutations in the voltage-sensor domains of either Ca2+ or Na+ channels, creating anomalous cation influx.
Description B: Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is caused by blocked ion channels arising from nonsense mutations in the potassium channel, preventing ion flow entirely.

Description A: Generalized onset seizures begin without an aura or focal onset and involve both cerebral hemispheres from the onset.
Description B: Generalized onset seizures typically start with an aura indicating focal initiation in one hemisphere before spreading.

Description A: In focal onset seizures, the symptoms depend on the location of the seizure focus and can include jerking movements or specific auras.
Description B: In focal onset seizures, the symptoms are random and independent of the location of the seizure focus in the brain.

Description A: Epilepsy is a chronic condition characterized by recurrent unprovoked seizures, and repeated seizures in response to alcohol withdrawal are not considered epilepsy.
Description B: Epilepsy is diagnosed as a condition caused by a single episode of seizure activity, including seizures related to alcohol withdrawal.

Description A: Typical absence seizures are nonmotor generalized onset seizures that last less than 10 seconds, are associated with staring, and do not involve post-ictal confusion.
Description B: Typical absence seizures are motor seizures that involve tonic-clonic jerking and post-ictal confusion lasting several minutes.

Description A: Inherited diseases of skeletal muscle with transient episodes of weakness or myotonia are caused by mutations in voltage-gated ion channels.
Description B: Inherited diseases of skeletal muscle with transient episodes of weakness are caused exclusively by loss of motor neurons.

Description A: The typical seizure spread involves normal cortical circuitry, with neurons being recruited from surrounding tissue during the event.
Description B: Seizure spreads skip normal cortical circuitry and are isolated to the initial seizure focus without affecting surrounding tissue.

Description A: Alpha waves of moderate amplitude on an EEG are typical of relaxed wakefulness and are most prominent over parietal and occipital areas.
Description B: Alpha waves of high amplitude are typical during intense mental activity and most prominent over frontal areas.

Description A: The EEG primarily reflects slower voltage changes across cell membranes, such as synaptic potentials, rather than action potentials.
Description B: The EEG primarily reflects high-frequency action potentials rather than slower voltage changes like synaptic potentials.

Description A: The nucleus ambiguus contains parasympathetic preganglionic neurons that innervate thoracic organs, including the esophagus, heart, and respiratory system.
Description B: The nucleus ambiguus contains parasympathetic preganglionic neurons that innervate the kidneys and intestines.

Description A: The trigeminal motor nucleus (N. V) lies at midpontine levels and innervates the muscles of mastication.
Description B: The trigeminal motor nucleus (N. V) lies at medullary levels and innervates the muscles of facial expression.

Description A: The Edinger-Westphal nucleus (N. III) contains preganglionic neurons that control pupillary constriction and lens accommodation through the ciliary ganglion.
Description B: The Edinger-Westphal nucleus (N. III) is responsible for controlling the contraction of the tongue.

Description A: The mesencephalic trigeminal nucleus relays mechanosensory information from the muscles of mastication and periodontal ligaments.
Description B: The mesencephalic trigeminal nucleus relays visual sensory information from the retina.

Description A: Special visceral afferents from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue travel to the nucleus of the solitary tract through the chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve.
Description B: Special visceral afferents from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue travel to the nucleus ambiguus through the trigeminal nerve.

Description A: Injury to the dorsal midbrain in the region of the posterior commissure can prevent pupillary light responses.
Description B: Injury to the dorsal midbrain in the region of the posterior commissure enhances pupillary light responses.

Description A: The hypoglossal nucleus (N. XII) in the medulla consists of several columns of neurons, each of which innervates a single muscle of the tongue.
Description B: The hypoglossal nucleus (N. XII) in the medulla innervates the muscles of the larynx and pharynx.

Description A: Dorsal respiratory group neurons participate in reflex actions such as the ventilatory response to low oxygen (hypoxia).
Description B: Dorsal respiratory group neurons are primarily responsible for producing swallowing motions.

Description A: The dorsal motor vagal nucleus contains parasympathetic preganglionic neurons that innervate the gastrointestinal tract below the diaphragm.
Description B: The dorsal motor vagal nucleus sends motor control signals to the muscles of mastication.

Description A: The pre-Bötzinger complex generates respiratory rhythm and is critical for maintaining normal breathing.
Description B: The pre-Bötzinger complex is involved in generating patterns for swallowing behaviors.

Description A: In situ hybridization is a technique used to detect specific mRNAs by hybridizing complementary probes that can be tagged chemically, fluorescently, or with antibodies.
Description B: In situ hybridization is a technique used to detect specific proteins by hybridizing complementary probes that can be tagged chemically, fluorescently, or with antibodies.

Description A: Cocaine blocks the reuptake of dopamine, leading to increased extracellular dopamine levels.
Description B: Cocaine increases the uptake of dopamine into presynaptic terminals, leading to decreased extracellular dopamine levels.

Description A: Amphetamines cause dopamine release through a nonexocytotic mechanism involving the plasma membrane DAT and vesicular VMAT2.
Description B: Amphetamines cause dopamine release through an exocytotic mechanism involving the plasma membrane DAT and vesicular VMAT2.

Description A: Neuropeptides are removed from the synaptic cleft primarily by diffusion and proteolysis by extracellular peptidases.
Description B: Neuropeptides are removed from the synaptic cleft primarily by reuptake via plasma membrane transporters.

Description A: Green fluorescent protein (GFP) can be used as a reporter to detect extracellular levels of neurotransmitters.
Description B: Green fluorescent protein (GFP) is used to detect intracellular enzymes but cannot act as a reporter for neurotransmitter levels.

Description A: Catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) degrades biogenic amines and plays a critical role in regulating cortical dopamine levels.
Description B: Catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) synthesizes biogenic amines and plays a critical role in increasing cortical dopamine levels.

Description A: Transporters in the neurotransmitter sodium symporters (NSS) family are powered by the Na+ electrochemical gradient in a symport mechanism.
Description B: Transporters in the neurotransmitter sodium symporters (NSS) family are powered by the H+ gradient in an antiport mechanism.

Description A: Unlike small-molecule transmitters, neuroactive peptide vesicles are not refilled at the terminal.
Description B: Neuroactive peptide vesicles, like small-molecule transmitter vesicles, can be refilled at the terminal.

Description A: Plasma membrane transporters move neurotransmitters in the same direction as Na+ ions through a symport mechanism.
Description B: Plasma membrane transporters move neurotransmitters in the opposite direction to Na+ ions through an antiport mechanism.

Description A: The main mechanism for removing small-molecule transmitters from the synaptic cleft is reuptake at the plasma membrane.
Description B: The main mechanism for removing small-molecule transmitters from the synaptic cleft is degradation by extracellular enzymes.

Description A: Dopaminergic neurons often fire more intensely when a reward appears unexpectedly.
Description B: Dopaminergic neurons often pause their firing when a reward appears unexpectedly.

Description A: Research using functional magnetic resonance imaging has demonstrated that dopaminergic agonists can modulate reward learning signals in the nucleus accumbens.
Description B: Research using functional magnetic resonance imaging has demonstrated that dopamine release is completely unrelated to reward learning signals in the nucleus accumbens.

Description A: Cocaine enhances dopaminergic transmission by blocking dopamine reuptake transporters.
Description B: Cocaine enhances dopaminergic transmission by directly releasing dopamine from the presynaptic neuron without affecting transporters.

Description A: Repeated exposure to addictive substances can induce long-term potentiation in nucleus accumbens neurons after prolonged withdrawal.
Description B: Repeated exposure to addictive substances completely blocks long-term potentiation in nucleus accumbens neurons during prolonged withdrawal.

Description A: ∆FosB accumulates in neurons with repeated exposure to drugs due to its unusual stability among transcription factors.
Description B: ∆FosB rapidly degrades in neurons after a single exposure to drugs, making it less relevant to addiction.

Description A: Drug addiction affects circuits related to both reward and motivation in the brain.
Description B: Drug addiction exclusively affects circuits related to motor control, not reward or motivation.

Description A: Opiates inhibit nearby GABAergic interneurons to activate ventral tegmental area dopamine neuron cell bodies.
Description B: Opiates increase dopamine release by directly exciting GABAergic interneurons near the ventral tegmental area.

Description A: The cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-CREB pathway is upregulated after repeated exposure to drugs of abuse.
Description B: The cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-CREB pathway completely shuts down after repeated exposure to drugs of abuse.

Description A: In animal models, self-administration behaviors are considered well-validated models of human addiction.
Description B: In animal models, self-administration behaviors are irrelevant to understanding human addiction.

Description A: Understanding dopamine’s role in addiction involves investigating both goal-directed behaviors and learning processes.
Description B: Understanding dopamine’s role in addiction focuses exclusively on its effect on reflexive motor responses.
