Description A: The axon initial segment has a lower threshold for action potential generation compared to the cell body because it has a higher density of voltage-dependent Na+ channels.
Description B: The axon initial segment has a higher threshold for action potential generation compared to the cell body because it has a lower density of voltage-dependent Na+ channels.

Description A: Temporal summation occurs more effectively in neurons with a large membrane time constant because consecutive synaptic potentials persist longer and overlap.
Description B: Temporal summation occurs more effectively in neurons with a short membrane time constant because consecutive synaptic potentials persist longer and overlap.

Description A: Basket cells target the soma and proximal dendrites of postsynaptic neurons, while chandelier cells target the axon initial segment.
Description B: Basket cells target the axon initial segment of postsynaptic neurons, while chandelier cells target the soma and proximal dendrites.

Description A: Neurons with a large length constant are more likely to achieve spatial summation because synaptic signals decrease less as they travel along the dendrite.
Description B: Neurons with a short length constant are more likely to achieve spatial summation because synaptic signals decrease less as they travel along the dendrite.

Description A: Dendrites in most neurons contain voltage-gated Na+, K+, and Ca2+ channels that can amplify local EPSPs.
Description B: Dendrites in most neurons contain only resting channels and do not amplify local EPSPs.

Description A: Inhibitory synaptic actions are more effective at the soma or axon initial segment compared to distal dendrites due to stronger shunting effects at these locations.
Description B: Inhibitory synaptic actions are more effective at distal dendrites compared to the soma or axon initial segment due to stronger shunting effects at these locations.

Description A: NMDA receptors act as coincidence detectors that require both glutamate release and membrane depolarization to remove the Mg2+ block from their pore.
Description B: NMDA receptors require only glutamate release, but not membrane depolarization, to remove the Mg2+ block from their pore.

Description A: Backpropagating action potentials in dendrites are generated largely by voltage-gated Na+ channels and attenuate as they travel further.
Description B: Backpropagating action potentials in dendrites are large regenerative signals that do not attenuate as they travel further.

Description A: GABAergic inhibitory neurons like basket cells and chandelier cells express the calcium-binding protein parvalbumin.
Description B: GABAergic inhibitory neurons like basket cells and chandelier cells express the neuropeptide somatostatin.

Description A: Martinotti cells specifically target distal dendrites of pyramidal neurons and release somatostatin in addition to GABA.
Description B: Martinotti cells specifically target the axon initial segment of pyramidal neurons and release parvalbumin in addition to GABA.

Description A: The brain's analysis of visual scenes begins in the retinas, which transform visual input using a strategy of parallel processing.
Description B: The brain's analysis of visual scenes begins in the optic chiasm, which transforms visual input using a strategy of signal splitting.

Description A: Nociceptors use glutamate as an excitatory neurotransmitter, and many also express excitatory neuropeptides such as substance P or CGRP.
Description B: Nociceptors use dopamine as an excitatory neurotransmitter, and many also express inhibitory neuropeptides such as GABA or serotonin.

Description A: Placebo analgesia involves endorphin release and can be reversed by naloxone.
Description B: Placebo analgesia involves serotonin release and cannot be reversed by naloxone.

Description A: The principle of good continuation is used to perceptually link collinear line segments into unified shapes.
Description B: The principle of good continuation is used to randomly group dissimilar line segments into arbitrary patterns.

Description A: Tolerance to opioids can result from the uncoupling of the opioid receptor from its G protein transducer.
Description B: Tolerance to opioids is caused solely by the lack of endorphin production.

Description A: The geniculostriate pathway ensures that visual information from each hemifield is processed in the contralateral hemisphere.
Description B: The geniculostriate pathway ensures that visual information from each hemifield is only processed in ipsilateral hemispheres.

Description A: Peripheral sensitization occurs when tissue injury and inflammation lower the activation threshold of nociceptors.
Description B: Peripheral sensitization occurs spontaneously and raises the activation threshold of nociceptors.

Description A: Central sensitization contributes to neuropathic pain by amplifying nociceptive signals in the dorsal horn.
Description B: Central sensitization alleviates neuropathic pain by reducing nociceptive signals in the dorsal horn.

Description A: The anterior cingulate gyrus plays a role in the affective component of the pain experience.
Description B: The anterior cingulate gyrus is responsible for motor coordination rather than pain processing.

Description A: Gestalt principles suggest that the interpretation of visual objects depends on the properties of the stimulus and its context.
Description B: Gestalt principles suggest that the interpretation of visual objects depends solely on the absolute properties of the stimulus.

Description A: The basal ganglia exercise influence over external structures by the fundamental processes of inhibition and disinhibition.
Description B: The basal ganglia exercise influence over external structures solely by excitatory signals.

Description A: GABAergic neurons in the basal ganglia output nuclei typically have high tonic firing rates (40–80 Hz).
Description B: GABAergic neurons in the basal ganglia output nuclei typically have low tonic firing rates (10–15 Hz).

Description A: The selected channel will be the one with the strongest inhibitory input from the striatum.
Description B: The selected channel will be the one with the strongest excitatory input from the striatum.

Description A: The basal ganglia are highly conserved across vertebrates, having been retained for more than 500 million years.
Description B: The basal ganglia show significant variation across vertebrate species and are not conserved across evolution.

Description A: The disinhibition mechanism of the basal ganglia allows selected external targets to direct movement while nonselected targets remain inhibited.
Description B: The disinhibition mechanism of the basal ganglia involves activating all external targets simultaneously.

Description A: The striatal medium spiny neurons play key roles in direct and indirect pathways involved in selecting actions.
Description B: The striatal medium spiny neurons are only involved in sensory processing and not in motor selection.

Description A: A higher activity in direct pathway neurons corresponds to promoting movement in vertebrates.
Description B: A higher activity in indirect pathway neurons always corresponds to promoting movement in vertebrates.

Description A: William James described selection as the foundation ('keel') of mental functions in his 1890 work, 'Principles of Psychology.'
Description B: William James dismissed the importance of selection in mental functions in his 1890 work, 'Principles of Psychology.'

Description A: The basal ganglia operate as a selection mechanism and are involved in reinforcement learning.
Description B: The basal ganglia serve only to perform routine tasks and do not play a role in reinforcement learning.

Description A: Diseases of the basal ganglia, like Parkinson's disease and Huntington's disease, can be interpreted as disorders of selection or reinforcement malfunctions.
Description B: Diseases of the basal ganglia do not relate to selection or reinforcement malfunctions.

Description A: Congenital myasthenia results from the absence of acetylcholinesterase in the synaptic cleft, leading to prolonged end-plate potentials.
Description B: Congenital myasthenia results from an excess of acetylcholinesterase in the synaptic cleft, leading to diminished end-plate potentials.

Description A: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by mutations in the DMD gene that introduce premature stop codons, preventing synthesis of full-length dystrophin.
Description B: Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by mutations in the DMD gene that increase dystrophin production to abnormal levels.

Description A: Becker muscular dystrophy is characterized by partially functional dystrophin, resulting from mutations that do not introduce stop codons.
Description B: Becker muscular dystrophy is characterized by completely absent dystrophin, similar to Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

Description A: The slow channel syndrome is characterized by prolonged channel opening and slow decay of end-plate currents.
Description B: The slow channel syndrome is characterized by rapid channel opening and quick decay of end-plate currents.

Description A: Mutations in sarcoglycan proteins are associated with limb-girdle muscular dystrophy (LGMD).
Description B: Mutations in sarcoglycan proteins are associated with Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

Description A: Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis is caused by missense mutations in a voltage-gated Na+ channel, leading to inactivation defects.
Description B: Hyperkalemic periodic paralysis is caused by mutations in a Cl- channel, leading to hyperactivation of the channel.

Description A: The muscle stiffness seen in myotonia congenita is due to mutations in the ClC-1 chloride channel gene.
Description B: The muscle stiffness seen in myotonia congenita is caused by mutations in the voltage-gated Na+ channel gene.

Description A: In Lambert-Eaton syndrome, the amplitude of evoked potentials increases with repetitive nerve stimulation.
Description B: In Lambert-Eaton syndrome, the amplitude of evoked potentials decreases with repetitive nerve stimulation.

Description A: The proximal muscles are more affected in limb-girdle muscular dystrophy due to their chronic contractile activity as antigravity muscles.
Description B: The distal muscles are predominantly affected in limb-girdle muscular dystrophy because they experience higher levels of chronic contractile activity.

Description A: ASO-mediated exon skipping therapy for Duchenne muscular dystrophy can restore the reading frame of mutated DMD mRNA, producing a partially functional dystrophin protein.
Description B: ASO-mediated exon skipping therapy for Duchenne muscular dystrophy eliminates the mutated DMD mRNA, preventing any dystrophin production.

Description A: Central chemoreceptors in the medulla control ventilatory motor output to maintain normal blood CO2.
Description B: Central chemoreceptors in the medulla regulate blood oxygen levels exclusively.

Description A: Absence of glutamatergic neurons in the retrotrapezoid nucleus due to a mutation in the phox2b gene causes congenital central hypoventilation syndrome.
Description B: Absence of serotonergic neurons in the retrotrapezoid nucleus due to a mutation in the phox2b gene causes congenital central hypoventilation syndrome.

Description A: Congenital central hypoventilation syndrome can lead to failure to breathe adequately, particularly during sleep.
Description B: Congenital central hypoventilation syndrome enhances breathing sensitivity to CO2 during sleep.

Description A: Serotonergic neurons are closely associated with large arteries in the ventral medulla where they monitor local changes in PCO2.
Description B: Serotonergic neurons in the ventral medulla exclusively monitor oxygen levels (PO2).

Description A: Cheyne-Stokes respiration is characterized by repeated cycles of increasing and decreasing ventilation, alternating with apnea.
Description B: Cheyne-Stokes respiration is characterized by stable ventilation patterns without any apnea.

Description A: The Back to Sleep campaign significantly reduced the incidence of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) by 50%.
Description B: The Back to Sleep campaign significantly increased the incidence of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) by 50%.

Description A: Monoaminergic neurons can release neurotransmitters diffusely to multiple targets at once.
Description B: Monoaminergic neurons form conventional synaptic connections exclusively, targeting one neuron at a time.

Description A: Electrical stimulation of serotonergic neurons in the medullary raphe nuclei increases heart rate and blood pressure.
Description B: Electrical stimulation of serotonergic neurons in the medullary raphe nuclei decreases heart rate and blood pressure.

Description A: The locus ceruleus (A6) provides most of the noradrenergic input to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
Description B: The A1 cell group provides most of the noradrenergic input to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

Description A: Parkinson’s disease stems from the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta.
Description B: Parkinson’s disease stems from the overproduction of dopamine in the substantia nigra pars compacta.

Description A: The hippocampus plays a role in episodic memory, future thinking, and goal-directed behavior.
Description B: The hippocampus primarily supports non-associative learning and reflexive responses but has minimal involvement in episodic memory or future thinking.

Description A: Intracranial electroencephalography (iEEG) can reveal neural activity in the hippocampus during memory retrieval, showing connections to patterns initially encoded.
Description B: Intracranial electroencephalography (iEEG) primarily measures activity in brainstem reflexes and does not detect cortical memory patterns.

Description A: Patients with damage to the hippocampus often exhibit deficits in episodic memory and imagining future events.
Description B: Patients with damage to the hippocampus often retain intact episodic memory and retain their ability to imagine future events.

Description A: fMRI has shown overlapping brain regions, including the hippocampus, are active during both memory retrieval and future event simulation.
Description B: fMRI shows that memory retrieval and future event simulation activate entirely non-overlapping brain networks, excluding the hippocampus.

Description A: The anticipation of a reward can enhance memory encoding by activating dopamine-rich midbrain regions.
Description B: The anticipation of a reward diminishes memory encoding by suppressing activity in dopamine-rich midbrain regions.

Description A: Episodic memory is crucial for constructing mental simulations of possible future events.
Description B: Episodic memory plays no role in constructing mental simulations of future events, focusing solely on past retrieval.

Description A: Lesions in the left hippocampus are associated with deficits in verbal memory, while lesions in the right hippocampus impair spatial orientation.
Description B: Lesions in the right hippocampus are associated with deficits in verbal memory, while lesions in the left hippocampus impair spatial orientation.

Description A: Classical conditioning requires association between a conditioned stimulus and an unconditioned stimulus to elicit a learned response.
Description B: Classical conditioning requires association between a conditioned stimulus and a neutral stimulus to elicit a learned response.

Description A: Non-associative learning, such as habituation and sensitization, involves learning about the properties of one stimulus without associations.
Description B: Non-associative learning, such as habituation and sensitization, involves forming complex associations between stimuli.

Description A: Taste-aversion conditioning is unique because it develops even when there is a significant delay between the conditioned stimulus and the unconditioned response.
Description B: Taste-aversion conditioning requires immediate pairing of the conditioned stimulus and unconditioned response to form associations.

Description A: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) can help people with Parkinson disease by delivering electrical pulses to targeted areas in the brain to disrupt aberrant neural activity.
Description B: Deep brain stimulation (DBS) can help people with Parkinson disease by delivering electrical pulses to the spinal cord to disrupt aberrant neural activity.

Description A: Cochlear implants send signals to electrically stimulate spiral ganglion cells in the cochlear modiolus, enabling auditory signals to reach the brain.
Description B: Cochlear implants send signals directly to the primary auditory cortex, bypassing the cochlear nerve and spiral ganglion cells.

Description A: Retinal prostheses capture images via a camera and stimulate retinal ganglion cells with electrical signals to restore partial vision in blindness.
Description B: Retinal prostheses capture images via a microphone and stimulate cochlear ganglion cells to restore partial hearing in blindness.

Description A: Obsessive-compulsive disorder symptoms can result from an abnormally dominant input salience of relevant functional channels, making behavioral switches difficult.
Description B: Obsessive-compulsive disorder symptoms can result from insufficient input salience of relevant functional channels, encouraging frequent behavioral switches.

Description A: Huntington disease is associated with early neuronal degeneration in striatal medium spiny neurons, causing dysfunction in the indirect pathway to the globus pallidus.
Description B: Huntington disease is associated with early neuronal degeneration in motor cortex pyramidal neurons, causing dysfunction exclusively in the direct pathways.

Description A: Basal ganglia output is largely GABAergic, acting as an inhibitory influence on targeted structures, impairing movement initiation in Parkinson disease.
Description B: Basal ganglia output is largely glutamatergic, acting as an excitatory influence on targeted structures, facilitating movement initiation in Parkinson disease.

Description A: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) symptoms may stem from a failure to suppress competing nonselected sensory options, hindering attention focus.
Description B: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) symptoms stem from enhanced suppression of nonselected sensory options, facilitating excessive attention focus.

Description A: Motor BMIs use intracortical electrodes to decode movement intentions and guide prosthetic devices in real-time.
Description B: Motor BMIs use scalp EEG electrodes to decode movement intentions and directly stimulate muscles in real-time.

Description A: Addiction-related stimuli gain exaggerated salience due to dysregulated reinforcement mechanisms in the basal ganglia, driving compulsive behaviors.
Description B: Addiction-related stimuli lose salience due to enhanced reinforcement mechanisms in the basal ganglia, reducing compulsive behaviors.

Description A: Schizophrenia may involve a failure to suppress nonselected options, leading to interruptions in selected actions or thoughts within basal ganglia circuits.
Description B: Schizophrenia may involve an over-suppression of nonselected options, enhancing stability of selected actions or thoughts within basal ganglia circuits.

Description A: The sarcomere is the basic functional unit of muscle.
Description B: The sarcomere is the basic functional unit of the nervous system.

Description A: The thin filament includes polymerized actin along with tropomyosin and troponin.
Description B: The thin filament includes polymerized actin along with titin and nebulin.

Description A: The thick filament is composed of myosin molecules with stems terminating in globular heads.
Description B: The thick filament is composed of actin molecules with stems terminating in globular heads.

Description A: Titin maintains the position of each thick filament in the middle of the sarcomere.
Description B: Nebulin maintains the position of each thick filament in the middle of the sarcomere.

Description A: Muscle force is at a maximum when the sarcomere is at its intermediate length (Lo).
Description B: Muscle force is at maximum when the sarcomere is at its shortest length.

Description A: During lengthening contraction, the myosin heads spend more time stretched beyond their angle of attachment.
Description B: During shortening contraction, the myosin heads spend more time stretched beyond their angle of attachment.

Description A: The pennation angle of the vastus medialis is around 30°.
Description B: The pennation angle of the vastus medialis is around 1°.

Description A: The rate of cross-bridge cycling increases after a brief isometric contraction.
Description B: The rate of cross-bridge cycling decreases after a brief isometric contraction.

Description A: Muscle stiffness depends on both intracellular cytoskeletal proteins and the extracellular matrix.
Description B: Muscle stiffness depends only on intracellular cytoskeletal proteins.

Description A: The vastus lateralis has a larger cross-sectional area than the rectus femoris.
Description B: The rectus femoris has a larger cross-sectional area than the vastus lateralis.

Description A: J-RGC dendrites in the mouse retina preferentially respond to ventral motion due to their ventrally pointing orientation.
Description B: J-RGC dendrites in the mouse retina preferentially respond to dorsal motion due to their ventrally pointing orientation.

Description A: Ramón y Cajal used light microscopic analysis of fixed tissue to deduce developmental principles of the nervous system.
Description B: Ramón y Cajal used electron microscopy to deduce developmental principles of the nervous system.

Description A: The first epoch of neural development involves the generation and differentiation of neurons and glia.
Description B: The first epoch of neural development involves the remodeling of neural circuits through experience.

Description A: The human nervous system is particularly unique due to a prolonged period of postnatal sculpting through experience.
Description B: The human nervous system undergoes little postnatal sculpting compared to other mammals.

Description A: The neural tube arises from the ectoderm, which is the outermost embryonic layer.
Description B: The neural tube arises from the mesoderm, which is the middle embryonic layer.

Description A: Signals from the organizer region induce the development of the neural plate.
Description B: Signals from the neural groove induce the development of the neural plate.

Description A: Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) pattern the dorsal portion of the neural tube.
Description B: Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) pattern the ventral portion of the neural tube.

Description A: Fruit flies and nematode worms have contributed significantly to understanding neural development across species.
Description B: Fruit flies and nematode worms are irrelevant to the study of neural development in vertebrates.

Description A: The ectoderm is responsible for the formation of both the skin and the neural plate.
Description B: The mesoderm is responsible for the formation of both the skin and the neural plate.

Description A: The ventral neural tube is influenced by Sonic Hedgehog protein secreted by the notochord.
Description B: The dorsal neural tube is influenced by Sonic Hedgehog protein secreted by the notochord.

Description A: CA3 pyramidal neurons in the hippocampus make strong excitatory connections with one another through recurrent collaterals.
Description B: CA3 pyramidal neurons in the hippocampus do not form excitatory connections with one another and lack recurrent collaterals.

Description A: The indirect pathway of the entorhinal cortex to the CA1 region is often referred to as the trisynaptic pathway.
Description B: The direct pathway of the entorhinal cortex to the CA1 region is often referred to as the trisynaptic pathway.

Description A: Synaptic connections in the hippocampal circuit are important for memory storage and recall.
Description B: Synaptic connections in the hippocampal circuit are unrelated to memory storage and recall.

Description A: CA1 neurons serve as the major output area of the hippocampus.
Description B: The dentate gyrus serves as the major output area of the hippocampus.

Description A: The entorhinal cortex connects to the hippocampus via two pathways: one direct and one indirect.
Description B: The entorhinal cortex connects to the hippocampus via only a single direct pathway.

Description A: The entorhinal cortex sends axons to the CA3 region as part of the hippocampal circuitry.
Description B: The entorhinal cortex does not send axons to the CA3 region in hippocampal circuitry.

Description A: The perforant pathway in the indirect hippocampal circuit first excites granule cells of the dentate gyrus.
Description B: The perforant pathway in the indirect hippocampal circuit first excites the CA1 pyramidal cells.

Description A: The hippocampal circuit involves excitatory synaptic connections that are critical for long-term memory formation.
Description B: The hippocampal circuit primarily involves inhibitory synaptic connections for long-term memory formation.

Description A: Memory loss has been observed in patients with lesions isolated to the CA1 region of the hippocampus.
Description B: Memory loss has never been linked to lesions isolated to the CA1 region of the hippocampus.

Description A: The temporoammonic pathway connects the entorhinal cortex to the distal apical dendrites of CA1 neurons.
Description B: The temporoammonic pathway connects the entorhinal cortex to the proximal apical dendrites of CA1 neurons.

Description A: Pyramidal neurons are the major projection neurons in the cerebral cortex, with apical dendrites oriented perpendicular to the cortical surface.
Description B: Pyramidal neurons are the major projection neurons in the midbrain, with apical dendrites oriented parallel to the cortical surface.

Description A: Thalamocortical axons primarily terminate in cortical layer IV, while excitatory axons from the contralateral hemisphere terminate in layers II and III.
Description B: Thalamocortical axons primarily terminate in cortical layer II, while excitatory axons from the contralateral hemisphere terminate in layers V and VI.

Description A: Current sinks occur where ionic current enters the dendrite during an excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP).
Description B: Current sinks occur where ionic current exits the dendrite during an inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP).

Description A: The polarity of surface EEG depends on the location of the synaptic activity within the cortex.
Description B: The polarity of surface EEG is independent of the location of synaptic activity within the cortex.

Description A: Excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) in superficial layers appear as upward (negative) deflections on surface EEG recordings.
Description B: Excitatory postsynaptic potentials (EPSPs) in superficial cortical layers appear as downward (positive) deflections on surface EEG recordings.

Description A: The paroxysmal depolarizing shift is associated with large depolarizations and trains of action potentials followed by afterhyperpolarization.
Description B: The paroxysmal depolarizing shift is characterized only by prolonged hyperpolarizations and the absence of action potentials.

Description A: The loss of afterhyperpolarization and inhibitory surround leads to the propagation of focal onset seizures.
Description B: The loss of depolarizing potentials and inhibitory surround inhibits the propagation of focal onset seizures.

Description A: Thalamocortical and transcallosal pathways are key routes for the spread of seizure activity from a focus.
Description B: Thalamocortical and transcallosal pathways block the spread of seizure activity from a focus.

Description A: Vagal nerve stimulation requires implantation of a device that provides chronic intermittent stimulation to reduce seizure frequency.
Description B: Vagal nerve stimulation involves administering medication orally to reduce seizure frequency without any implantable device.

Description A: Responsive neurostimulation (RNS) detects epileptiform activity and delivers targeted electrical stimulation to the seizure focus.
Description B: Responsive neurostimulation (RNS) detects epileptiform activity but cannot deliver targeted electrical stimulation to the seizure focus.

Description A: The sympathetic system promotes arousal, defense, and escape, whereas the parasympathetic system promotes eating and procreation.
Description B: The sympathetic system promotes eating and procreation, whereas the parasympathetic system promotes arousal, defense, and escape.

Description A: Approximately one-half of magnocellular neurons synthesize and secrete vasopressin into the general circulation, while the other half synthesize and secrete oxytocin.
Description B: Approximately one-half of magnocellular neurons synthesize and secrete oxytocin into the general circulation, while the other half synthesize and secrete a hormone controlling blood sugar.

Description A: The baroreceptor reflex prevents orthostatic hypotension and fainting by compensating for rapid hydrostatic effects produced by changes in posture.
Description B: The baroreceptor reflex prevents orthostatic hypertension and fainting by compensating for rapid hydroelectric effects produced by changes in posture.

Description A: Parasympathetic activity increases in the heart during hypertension and decreases during hypotension as part of the baroreceptor reflex.
Description B: Parasympathetic activity decreases in the heart during hypertension and increases during hypotension as part of the baroreceptor reflex.

Description A: The nucleus of the solitary tract projects visceral sensory information to the ventrolateral medulla and forebrain for autonomic control.
Description B: The nucleus of the solitary tract projects visceral sensory information solely to the forebrain for autonomic control, bypassing the medulla.

Description A: The hypothalamus controls the pituitary gland directly through the posterior pituitary and indirectly through the anterior pituitary.
Description B: The hypothalamus controls the pituitary gland directly through the anterior pituitary and indirectly through the posterior pituitary.

Description A: Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) neurons control the release of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which in turn regulates cortisol secretion.
Description B: Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) neurons control the release of prolactin, which in turn regulates cortisol secretion.

Description A: Visceral sensory information reaches the brain primarily through cranial nerves IX and X and abdominal splanchnic nerves.
Description B: Visceral sensory information reaches the brain primarily through cranial nerves VIII and IX, bypassing the abdominal splanchnic nerves.

Description A: Vasopressin secreted by magnocellular neurons controls blood pressure and water reabsorption by the kidneys.
Description B: Vasopressin secreted by magnocellular neurons controls muscle contraction and glucose metabolism in the liver.

Description A: The micturition reflex involves coordination between parasympathetic and sympathetic systems to regulate bladder emptying and filling.
Description B: The micturition reflex involves coordination between central nervous systems exclusively for bladder emptying.

Description A: Taste aversion develops even if nausea occurs hours after the specific taste, reflecting the ill effects typically associated with infected foods or toxins.
Description B: Taste aversion develops only if nausea occurs immediately after the specific taste, reflecting the ill effects typically associated with infected foods or toxins.

Description A: Memory imperfections like misattribution help highlight that memory reshapes itself over time, making it a non-perfect recall system.
Description B: Memory imperfections like misattribution highlight that memory is a perfect system of recalling experiences as they occurred.

Description A: Blocking refers to a temporary inability to access stored information, often accompanied by partial awareness of the sought-after word or image.
Description B: Blocking refers to a permanent inability to access stored information, often leading individuals to forget words and images entirely.

Description A: Frederic Bartlett showed that memory distortion often aligns with people's expectations about what should have happened.
Description B: Frederic Bartlett showed that memory distortion occurs randomly and does not align with people's expectations about what should have happened.

Description A: Persistence refers to obsessive memory of events that can intrude into consciousness but may also serve adaptive survival purposes.
Description B: Persistence refers to the loss of memories over time and does not involve obsessive recollection or adaptive purposes.

Description A: Implicit memory involves automatic processes that do not require conscious awareness and includes skills, habits, and motor reflex conditioning.
Description B: Implicit memory involves conscious processes and primarily deals with storing general knowledge and episodic events.

Description A: Habituation results from a decrease in the release of neurotransmitters at synaptic connections, leading to diminished motor responses.
Description B: Habituation results from an increase in synaptic connections, leading to amplified motor responses over time.

Description A: Sensitization enhances reflex responses when an animal encounters harmful stimuli, sometimes causing defensive reactions to harmless stimuli.
Description B: Sensitization reduces reflex responses when an animal encounters harmful stimuli, making defensive reactions less likely over time.

Description A: Long-term storage of explicit memory begins in the hippocampus and medial temporal lobe before being transferred to other neocortical regions.
Description B: Long-term storage of explicit memory does not involve the hippocampus or medial temporal lobe but relies solely on neocortical regions.

Description A: Adaptive flexibility of memory allows experiences separated across time to integrate into networks guiding future behavior.
Description B: Adaptive flexibility of memory prevents the integration of experiences across time and limits its ability to guide future behavior.

Description A: The stretch reflex is a reflex muscle contraction elicited by the lengthening of the muscle, and it requires sensory input from muscle to the spinal cord and a return path to the muscle.
Description B: The stretch reflex is a reflex muscle contraction triggered by the shortening of the muscle, and it does not require sensory input from muscle to the spinal cord.

Description A: Muscle spindles signal changes in the length of the muscle within which they reside, and they are activated when a muscle is stretched.
Description B: Muscle spindles signal changes in the force of muscle contraction and remain inactive during muscle stretching.

Description A: Gamma motor neurons adjust muscle spindle sensitivity by shortening intrafusal fibers in response to changes in muscle length.
Description B: Gamma motor neurons reduce muscle spindle sensitivity by relaxing the intrafusal fibers and lengthening them.

Description A: Ia sensory axons from muscle spindles make direct excitatory connections with alpha motor neurons that innervate the same muscle.
Description B: Ia sensory axons from muscle spindles make direct inhibitory connections with alpha motor neurons that innervate the same muscle.

Description A: The stretch reflex helps to counteract muscle lengthening and contributes to the spring-like properties of muscles.
Description B: The stretch reflex causes further muscle lengthening and inhibits the spring-like properties of muscles.

Description A: Static gamma motor neurons increase the tonic activity in sensory endings of muscle spindles and reduce their dynamic sensitivity.
Description B: Static gamma motor neurons decrease tonic activity in sensory endings of muscle spindles and enhance their dynamic sensitivity.

Description A: Neuronal networks in the spinal cord integrate descending motor commands with sensory feedback signals to shape motor responses.
Description B: Neuronal networks in the spinal cord exclusively process descending motor commands without incorporating sensory feedback signals.

Description A: The stretch reflex neural circuit includes direct synaptic connections between Ia sensory fibers and motor neurons.
Description B: The stretch reflex neural circuit requires multiple synaptic relays and does not include direct connections between Ia sensory fibers and motor neurons.

Description A: Contraction of the intrafusal fibers does not significantly contribute to the force of muscle contraction.
Description B: Contraction of the intrafusal fibers significantly contributes to the force of muscle contraction.

Description A: Primary sensory endings of muscle spindles are highly sensitive to the velocity of stretch, providing information about the speed of movements.
Description B: Primary sensory endings of muscle spindles are insensitive to the velocity of stretch and provide no information about movement speed.

Description A: Unipolar cells have a single process emanating from the cell, and they are characteristic of the invertebrate nervous system.
Description B: Unipolar cells have two processes emanating from the cell, and they are characteristic of the mammalian nervous system.

Description A: Bipolar cells have two types of processes: dendrites for receiving electrical signals and axons for transmitting signals.
Description B: Bipolar cells have three types of processes: dendrites for receiving electrical signals, axons for transmitting signals, and a third specialized segment for processing.

Description A: Pseudo-unipolar cells carry somatosensory information to the spinal cord and have a single fused process with two distinct functionally axonal segments.
Description B: Pseudo-unipolar cells carry somatosensory information to the spinal cord and have three functionally distinct segments: two axonal and one dendritic.

Description A: Multipolar cells, the most common type of neuron in the mammalian nervous system, have a single axon and many dendrites.
Description B: Multipolar cells, the most common type of neuron in the mammalian nervous system, have multiple axons and a single dendrite.

Description A: Glial cells outnumber neurons in the vertebrate central nervous system by a factor of 2 to 10.
Description B: Neurons outnumber glial cells in the vertebrate central nervous system by a factor of 2 to 10.

Description A: The cell bodies of sensory neurons in the knee-jerk reflex are located in the dorsal root ganglia near the spinal cord.
Description B: The cell bodies of sensory neurons in the knee-jerk reflex are located within the quadriceps muscle.

Description A: The Na+-K+ pump maintains low intracellular sodium levels and high intracellular potassium levels in resting neurons.
Description B: The Na+-K+ pump maintains low intracellular potassium levels and high intracellular sodium levels in resting neurons.

Description A: Sensory neurons generate receptor potentials that are graded in amplitude and duration based on stimulus strength.
Description B: Sensory neurons generate receptor potentials that are all-or-none, regardless of stimulus strength.

Description A: Feedforward inhibition enhances the activity of active pathways by suppressing opposing pathways.
Description B: Feedforward inhibition suppresses active pathways by enhancing opposing pathways.

Description A: Divergence describes how one neuron sends signals to multiple target cells, commonly seen in sensory systems.
Description B: Divergence describes how multiple neurons send signals to one shared target cell, commonly seen in motor systems.

Description A: Motor neuron pathophysiology in ALS is influenced by reactions of nonneural cells to motor neuron degeneration.
Description B: Motor neuron pathophysiology in ALS is solely influenced by genetic mutations without involvement of nonneural cells.

Description A: Progressive bulbar palsy affects muscles innervated by cranial nerves and can result in dysarthria and dysphagia.
Description B: Progressive bulbar palsy affects limb muscles and cannot result in dysarthria or dysphagia.

Description A: The SMN2 gene produces reduced amounts of full-length SMN protein due to alternative splicing that excludes exon 7.
Description B: The SMN2 gene consistently produces large amounts of full-length SMN protein without any splicing variations.

Description A: Antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) can promote exon inclusion or skipping, depending on their function.
Description B: Antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) only promote exon skipping and cannot promote exon inclusion.

Description A: ALS is limited to motor neurons and does not affect sensory or autonomic neurons.
Description B: ALS affects both motor neurons and sensory neurons equally.

Description A: In peripheral neuropathy, sensory deficits often follow a glove-and-stocking pattern due to the susceptibility of distal nerves.
Description B: In peripheral neuropathy, sensory deficits always occur symmetrically without any glove-and-stocking pattern.

Description A: Guillain-Barré syndrome often follows respiratory infections or infectious diarrhea and is treated with plasmapheresis or gamma globulin.
Description B: Guillain-Barré syndrome is unrelated to infections and does not respond to plasmapheresis or gamma globulin therapy.

Description A: Myasthenia gravis involves antibodies targeting nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, impairing synaptic transmission.
Description B: Myasthenia gravis occurs due to decreased production of acetylcholine in the synapse.

Description A: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease can involve either axonal or demyelinating neuropathy depending on the subtype.
Description B: Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease exclusively involves demyelinating neuropathy in all cases.

Description A: The fast channel syndrome leads to accelerated decay of end-plate currents due to mutations in ACh receptor subunits.
Description B: The fast channel syndrome results in prolonged end-plate potentials due to slow closing of ACh channels.

Description A: The visual system relies on contrast at edges to calculate surface brightness, and neurons gradually 'fill in' stabilized images to match surrounding areas.
Description B: The visual system calculates surface brightness by directly responding to uniform areas of the surface without needing contrast at its edges.

Description A: Neurons in the primary visual cortex exhibit plastic changes during perceptual learning, becoming more sensitive to specific tasks with practice.
Description B: Neurons in the primary visual cortex retain fixed response properties and do not change during perceptual learning.

Description A: Perceptual learning is task-specific, meaning improvement on one visual task, like orientation discrimination, does not transfer to others.
Description B: Perceptual learning universally improves all visual tasks, regardless of specific training focus.

Description A: Horizontal connections in the primary visual cortex mediate contour integration across large areas of the visual field.
Description B: Horizontal connections in the visual cortex exclusively link neurons within a small localized region of the visual field.

Description A: Feedback connections from higher cortical areas influence early visual processing, such as attention and expectations.
Description B: Feedback connections from higher cortical areas are unrelated to attention and expectations, focusing solely on feedforward sensory input.

Description A: Top-down mechanisms like spatial attention allow focused visual analysis of objects without moving the eyes.
Description B: Top-down mechanisms like spatial attention require eye movements to analyze objects effectively.

Description A: Color constancy enables the visual system to perceive an object's color consistently, despite differences in reflected light based on illumination.
Description B: Color constancy fails when the illumination changes, causing the visual system to misperceive an object's color.

Description A: Some neurons respond to surface boundaries rather than uniform areas, and changes in surrounding brightness influence these responses.
Description B: All neurons respond equally to uniform surface areas and are unaffected by surrounding brightness changes.

Description A: Visual signals processed in the inferior temporal cortex are essential for recognizing complex visual stimuli like faces and objects.
Description B: Visual signals processed in the inferior temporal cortex are unrelated to recognizing complex visual stimuli like faces.

Description A: Perceptual learning consists of implicit learning without the necessity of error feedback for improvement.
Description B: Perceptual learning requires explicit feedback on errors to drive improvement.

Description A: The primary sensory neurons from the trunk and limbs are pseudo-unipolar in shape and clustered in the dorsal root ganglia.
Description B: The primary sensory neurons from the trunk and limbs are multipolar in shape and clustered in the ventral root ganglia.

Description A: The ventral horn in the spinal cord contains motor neurons whose axons exit the spinal cord to innervate skeletal muscles.
Description B: The dorsal horn in the spinal cord contains motor neurons whose axons exit the spinal cord to innervate skeletal muscles.

Description A: In the spinal cord, the proportion of gray matter to white matter is greater at sacral levels than at cervical levels.
Description B: In the spinal cord, the proportion of white matter to gray matter is greater at sacral levels than at cervical levels.

Description A: The medial geniculate nucleus is part of the auditory system and conveys information to the primary auditory cortex in the temporal lobe.
Description B: The medial geniculate nucleus is part of the visual system and conveys information to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe.

Description A: The thalamus acts as a gatekeeper for sensory information, modulating its passage depending on behavioral state.
Description B: The thalamus acts as a passive relay station where sensory information is simply passed on to the neocortex.

Description A: Touch and limb proprioception signals from the lower body ascend toward the brain in the gracile fascicle of the spinal cord.
Description B: Touch and limb proprioception signals from the lower body ascend toward the brain in the cuneate fascicle of the spinal cord.

Description A: The lateral columns of the spinal cord include both ascending and descending fiber bundles from the brain stem and neocortex.
Description B: The dorsal columns of the spinal cord include both ascending and descending fiber bundles from the brain stem and neocortex.

Description A: The ventral horn is larger in regions of the spinal cord that innervate the arms and legs due to the complexity of motor control required.
Description B: The dorsal horn is larger in regions of the spinal cord that innervate the arms and legs due to the complexity of motor control required.

Description A: In the dorsal columns, axons from the lower body are located medially, while those from the upper body are located laterally.
Description B: In the dorsal columns, axons from the upper body are located medially, while those from the lower body are located laterally.

Description A: The somatosensory cortex representation is proportional to the density of sensory receptors rather than the mass of the body part.
Description B: The somatosensory cortex representation is proportional to the mass of the body part rather than the density of sensory receptors.

Description A: Hox6 activities control the identity of cells in the brachial lateral motor column (LMC), Hox9 controls the identity of cells in the preganglionic column (PGC), and Hox10 controls the identity of cells in the lumbar column (LMC).
Description B: Hox6 activities control the identity of cells in the caudal lateral motor column (LMC), Hox9 controls the identity of cells in the pectoralis column (PCC), and Hox10 controls the identity of cells in the brachial column (BMC).

Description A: The binding of Delta to Notch results in proteolytic cleavage of the Notch cytoplasmic domain, which then enters the nucleus.
Description B: The binding of Delta to Notch results in the suppression of the Notch cytoplasmic domain, which prevents it from entering the nucleus.

Description A: RNA interference (RNAi) knock-down of Hox6 suppresses innervation of the Pec muscle so that motor axons innervate the FCU muscle only.
Description B: RNA interference (RNAi) knock-down of Hox6 enhances innervation of the Pec muscle so that motor axons exclusively target both the Pec and FCU muscles.

Description A: Cortical barrels in the somatosensory cortex receive somatosensory information from a specific whisker on the snout.
Description B: Cortical barrels in the somatosensory cortex receive somatosensory information from multiple whiskers across the entire body surface.

Description A: The anterior region of the forebrain develops into the motor areas, while the posterior region develops into visual areas.
Description B: The anterior region of the forebrain develops into visual areas, while the posterior region develops into motor areas.

Description A: Motor neurons in the lateral LMC project axons into the dorsal limb mesenchyme, guided by EphA receptors and ephrin A ligands.
Description B: Motor neurons in the lateral LMC project axons into the ventral limb mesenchyme, guided by EphA receptors and ephrin B ligands.

Description A: Neural plate induction involves mesodermal cells secreting factors that prevent ectoderm-derived BMPs from suppressing a neural fate.
Description B: Neural plate induction involves BMPs secreted by ectodermal cells directly promoting the neural fate through activation mechanisms.

Description A: The barrel field in the rodent somatosensory cortex depends on afferent input during a critical period of development.
Description B: The barrel field in the rodent somatosensory cortex develops independently of afferent input and is fixed genetically.

Description A: Anterior-posterior patterning of the neural tube is influenced by gradients of Wnt signaling.
Description B: Anterior-posterior patterning of the neural tube is influenced by gradients of BMP signaling exclusively.

Description A: Radial glial cells serve as progenitors for both neurons and astrocytes and provide scaffolding for neuronal migration.
Description B: Radial glial cells serve as progenitors exclusively for neurons but do not provide scaffolding for neuronal migration.

Description A: Postural control requires the nervous system to dynamically adapt sensory weighting based on environmental conditions and movement goals.
Description B: Postural control relies exclusively on visual sensory inputs to regulate balance under all environmental conditions.

Description A: The cerebellum plays a critical role in adapting postural responses based on previous experiences during repeated trials.
Description B: The cerebellum is not involved in adapting postural responses based on previous experiences during repeated trials.

Description A: Lesions of the spinocerebellum result in excessive postural sway that worsens with eyes closed.
Description B: Lesions of the spinocerebellum have no impact on postural sway regardless of eye condition.

Description A: Visual inputs provide spatial orientation and motion information for postural control.
Description B: Visual inputs are never used for spatial orientation in postural control.

Description A: The basal ganglia are important for anticipatory postural control and adapting responses based on initial conditions.
Description B: The basal ganglia are exclusively involved in sensory input integration and do not contribute to anticipatory postural control.

Description A: Subjects rely on vestibular and visual inputs when standing on an unstable surface.
Description B: Subjects rely primarily on somatosensory inputs when standing on an unstable surface.

Description A: A sudden displacement of the body’s center of mass triggers ankle, hip, or stepping strategies.
Description B: A sudden displacement of the body’s center of mass triggers only stepping strategies.

Description A: Patients with Parkinson’s disease have difficulty switching postural response sets when conditions change suddenly.
Description B: Patients with Parkinson’s disease can easily switch postural response sets when conditions change suddenly.

Description A: Postural control involves many brain areas, but circuits for different types of control have yet to be determined.
Description B: Postural control is exclusively regulated by the spinal cord with no involvement of other brain areas.

Description A: Fear of falling can increase postural tone and stiffness in response to disturbances.
Description B: Fear of falling has no impact on postural tone or stiffness in response to disturbances.

Description A: Motor units vary in contraction speed, maximal force, and fatigability, influencing muscle force during contraction.
Description B: Motor units are identical in contraction speed, maximal force, and fatigability, providing uniform muscle force during contraction.

Description A: The innervation number, which represents the number of muscle fibers innervated by a single motor neuron, determines the precision of muscle control.
Description B: The innervation number, which represents the total number of motor neurons in a muscle, determines the precision of muscle control.

Description A: Slow-contracting motor units achieve maximal force at lower action potential rates compared to fast-contracting motor units.
Description B: Slow-contracting motor units achieve maximal force at higher action potential rates compared to fast-contracting motor units.

Description A: Motor units with long twitch contraction times produce smaller forces but are less fatigable.
Description B: Motor units with long twitch contraction times produce larger forces but fatigue more quickly.

Description A: Electromyograms (EMG) detect compound action potentials during muscle contractions and are useful for studying movement control.
Description B: Electromyograms (EMG) detect only single action potentials during muscle contractions and are limited for studying movement control.

Description A: Each fiber in most vertebrate muscles is innervated by a single motor neuron.
Description B: Each fiber in most vertebrate muscles is innervated by multiple motor neurons.

Description A: Motor unit fibers can be scattered across a significant portion of a muscle's volume and intermingle with other units.
Description B: Motor unit fibers are strictly clustered together and do not intermingle with other units.

Description A: The size of a motor unit determines the fineness of muscle control at low forces.
Description B: The size of a motor unit does not affect the fineness of muscle control at low forces.

Description A: Motor units in multitendon muscles often belong to compartments with distinct nerve innervation.
Description B: Motor units in multitendon muscles usually overlap across compartments with no distinct nerve innervation.

Description A: The properties of motor units, such as contraction speed, can change over time or due to neuromuscular disorders.
Description B: The properties of motor units, such as contraction speed, remain constant throughout a person's life and are unaffected by neuromuscular disorders.

Description A: Silent nociceptors are found in the viscera and are not normally activated by noxious stimulation; instead, inflammation and various chemical agents reduce their firing threshold.
Description B: Silent nociceptors are found in the skin and are activated by mild noxious stimulation without the need for inflammation.

Description A: The TRPV1 channel is activated by noxious thermal stimuli and mediates the pain-producing actions of capsaicin.
Description B: The TRPV1 channel is activated exclusively by light touch and contributes to the sense of pressure in object manipulation.

Description A: First pain is transmitted by Aδ fibers, while second pain is transmitted by C fibers.
Description B: First pain is transmitted by C fibers, while second pain is transmitted by Aδ fibers.

Description A: The perception of pain is subjective and influenced by factors such as context and prior experiences.
Description B: The perception of pain is universally objective and remains consistent across individuals.

Description A: Neuropathic pain often involves burning or electric sensations and does not typically respond well to NSAIDs.
Description B: Neuropathic pain commonly responds well to NSAIDs and is rarely associated with burning or electric sensations.

Description A: TRPM8 is a menthol-responsive channel that contributes to cold sensitivity, including hypersensitivity induced by certain chemotherapeutic drugs.
Description B: TRPM8 is exclusively responsible for detecting heat sensitivity and is unaffected by chemotherapeutic drugs.

Description A: Hyperalgesia often involves sensitization of peripheral nociceptors due to the chemical release during tissue injury.
Description B: Hyperalgesia is unaffected by peripheral tissue damage and is solely generated by psychological factors.

Description A: Pain signals from visceral organs can result in referred pain due to the convergence of somatic and visceral nociceptive inputs.
Description B: Pain signals from visceral organs are never referred and remain localized in the viscera.

Description A: Nav1.7 channels are crucial for pain perception and mutations in SCN9A can lead to either insensitivity or hyper-sensitivity to pain.
Description B: Nav1.7 channels are critical exclusively for touch perception, and mutations have no impact on pain sensitivity.

Description A: Patients with allodynia experience pain in response to normally innocuous stimuli, such as light stroking over sensitive skin.
Description B: Patients with allodynia only experience pain in response to intense pressure or direct tissue damage.

Description A: Cortical interneurons arise from medial and caudal ganglionic eminences and migrate tangentially to the cerebral cortex.
Description B: Cortical interneurons arise from the lateral ganglionic eminence and migrate radially to the cerebral cortex.

Description A: Neurogenin-1 and Neurogenin-2 are essential for the differentiation of glutamatergic pyramidal neurons in the cerebral cortex.
Description B: Neurogenin-1 and Neurogenin-2 are essential for the differentiation of GABAergic interneurons in the cerebral cortex.

Description A: Neurons generated in the lateral ganglionic eminence migrate rostrally and contribute to the olfactory bulb's periglomerular and granule interneurons.
Description B: Neurons generated in the lateral ganglionic eminence migrate dorsally and contribute to the hippocampus' interneurons.

Description A: In mice lacking Dlx1 and Dlx2 activity, there is a profound reduction in the number of GABAergic interneurons in the cortex.
Description B: In mice lacking Dlx1 and Dlx2 activity, there is an increase in the number of GABAergic interneurons in the cortex.

Description A: Neural crest cell migration does not rely on scaffolding and is referred to as free migration.
Description B: Neural crest cell migration relies on preexisting scaffolding like radial glial cells and axon tracts.

Description A: BMPs promote epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition, enabling neural crest cells to delaminate and migrate.
Description B: BMPs inhibit epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition, forcing neural crest cells to remain localized in the neural tube.

Description A: Ephrin proteins concentrated in the posterior half of somites provide repellent signals to guide neural crest migration.
Description B: Ephrin proteins in the anterior half of somites attract neural crest cells to guide migration.

Description A: Outer radial glial cells, abundant in primates, lack contact with the ventricular surface but generate neurons for the cerebral cortex.
Description B: Outer radial glial cells, abundant in primates, primarily migrate to populate the hippocampus rather than generating neurons for the cerebral cortex.

Description A: Sympathetic neurons' neurotransmitter phenotype can switch from noradrenergic to cholinergic based on signals from sweat gland targets.
Description B: Sympathetic neurons' neurotransmitter phenotype is fixed as noradrenergic and cannot switch to cholinergic.

Description A: In the developing cerebellum, Math-1 plays a critical role in the differentiation of glutamatergic granule neurons.
Description B: In the developing cerebellum, Math-1 specifically regulates the differentiation of GABAergic Purkinje neurons.

Description A: Neurons in the posterior parietal cortex (PPC) estimate the relative location of objects with respect to the body and retain information in working memory to facilitate limb coordination.
Description B: Neurons in the posterior parietal cortex (PPC) estimate the absolute location of objects, independent of the body, but do not retain information for limb coordination.

Description A: Inputs from the cerebellum and basal ganglia are used to correct motor errors and select appropriate motor activity patterns.
Description B: Inputs from the cerebellum and basal ganglia are primarily responsible for generating new motor patterns and are not involved in correcting motor errors.

Description A: The neural control mechanisms determined from animal experiments, including the existence of a central pattern generator (CPG), are used to control locomotion in humans.
Description B: The neural control mechanisms determined from animal experiments, including the absence of a central pattern generator (CPG), differ significantly from those used in human locomotion.

Description A: Recent technological advances enable detailed study of the contributions of brainstem and spinal circuits to locomotion.
Description B: Recent technological advances primarily focus on the cortex and bypass studying contributions of brainstem and spinal circuits to locomotion.

Description A: The primary motor cortex includes a detailed map of the motor periphery and plays a key role in motor execution.
Description B: The primary motor cortex lacks a detailed map of the motor periphery and plays a secondary role in motor execution.

Description A: Theoretical models like optimal feedback control suggest that movements are generated through context- and time-dependent real-time adjustments.
Description B: Theoretical models like optimal feedback control suggest that movements are pre-calculated completely before their execution.

Description A: Proprioceptive input can reset the central locomotor rhythm and influence spinal motor neuron activity.
Description B: Proprioceptive input is unrelated to the central locomotor rhythm and does not influence spinal motor neuron activity.

Description A: The ventral premotor cortex (PMv) is primarily involved in hand-control regions in motor planning.
Description B: The ventral premotor cortex (PMv) is primarily involved in foot-control regions in motor planning.

Description A: The supplementary motor area (SMA) is split into two regions: a supplementary motor area proper (SMA) and a presupplementary motor area (pre-SMA).
Description B: The supplementary motor area (SMA) is a single undivided region without any subdivisions.

Description A: Primary somatosensory cortex (S-I) processes cutaneous and muscle mechanoreceptor signals and transmits them to motor regions for planning and guiding actions.
Description B: Primary somatosensory cortex (S-I) processes visual signals and transmits them to motor regions for planning and guiding actions.

Description A: Stretch reflexes are elicited by sharply tapping the tendon of a muscle with a reflex hammer and involve the muscle spindle receptor located in the muscle.
Description B: Stretch reflexes are elicited by sharply tapping the tendon of a muscle with a reflex hammer and involve the tendon receptor located in the tendon.

Description A: Hyperactive stretch reflexes always indicate a lesion in the central nervous system.
Description B: Hyperactive stretch reflexes always indicate a lesion in the peripheral nervous system.

Description A: Spasticity is characterized by hyperactive tendon jerks and an increase in resistance to rapid muscle stretching.
Description B: Spasticity is characterized by hypoactive tendon jerks and a decrease in resistance to rapid muscle stretching.

Description A: Spinal shock following a spinal cord transection leads to a temporary suppression of spinal reflexes below the site of the injury.
Description B: Spinal shock following a spinal cord transection leads to a permanent suppression of spinal reflexes below the site of the injury.

Description A: The cerebellum regulates the timing and intensity of descending signals during locomotion.
Description B: The cerebellum regulates the initiation of rhythmic locomotion at the spinal level.

Description A: Interruption of descending pathways to the spinal cord often produces spasticity characterized by hyperactive tendon jerks.
Description B: Interruption of descending pathways to the spinal cord often produces spasticity characterized by hypoactive tendon jerks.

Description A: Proprioceptive feedback is essential for regulating stride length and adjusting locomotion to unexpected obstacles.
Description B: Proprioceptive feedback plays no role in regulating stride length or locomotion adjustments.

Description A: The central pattern generators in the spinal cord produce rhythmic locomotor activity independent of sensory feedback.
Description B: The central pattern generators in the spinal cord produce rhythmic locomotor activity only with sensory feedback.

Description A: Feedforward input from supraspinal systems allows for anticipatory modifications of locomotion based on goals and environmental factors.
Description B: Anticipatory modifications of locomotion do not involve supraspinal systems.

Description A: The spinal circuits responsible for locomotion can be modified by experience such as locomotor training after injury.
Description B: The spinal circuits responsible for locomotion are fixed and cannot be altered by experience or training.

Description A: Shh signaling is necessary for the induction of neuronal classes generated in the ventral half of the spinal cord, acting as a morphogen that directs different cell fates at different concentration thresholds.
Description B: Shh signaling is unnecessary for the induction of neuronal classes generated in the ventral half of the spinal cord, with differentiation occurring independently of morphogen concentration thresholds.

Description A: Neurons involved in the processing of cutaneous sensory information are located in the dorsal half of the spinal cord, while neurons controlling motor output are mainly located in the ventral half.
Description B: Neurons involved in the processing of cutaneous sensory information are located in the ventral half of the spinal cord, while neurons controlling motor output are mainly located in the dorsal half.

Description A: BMP signals from epidermal cells contribute to the differentiation of roof plate cells at the dorsal midline of the neural tube.
Description B: BMP signals from notochord cells contribute to the differentiation of roof plate cells at the dorsal midline of the neural tube.

Description A: Motor neurons that innervate forelimb and hindlimb muscles are found in the lateral motor columns at cervical and lumbar levels of the spinal cord.
Description B: Motor neurons that innervate forelimb and hindlimb muscles are found in the preganglionic motor column at cervical and lumbar levels of the spinal cord.

Description A: Graded Shh signaling generates a corresponding gradient of Gli transcription factor activity that specifies ventral neuronal subtypes.
Description B: Graded Shh signaling generates a corresponding gradient of BMP transcription factor activity that specifies ventral neuronal subtypes.

Description A: The spatial distribution of Hox genes determines many aspects of neuronal diversity, including motor neuron subtype identity.
Description B: The spatial distribution of Pax genes determines many aspects of neuronal diversity, including motor neuron subtype identity.

Description A: Mutations in Shh pathway genes can lead to defects such as spina bifida, limb deformities, and certain cancers.
Description B: Mutations in Shh pathway genes can lead to defects such as enhanced neuronal growth and reduced cancer risk.

Description A: Motor neurons are generated along the rostrocaudal axis of the neural tube, with distinct types developing at each level.
Description B: Motor neurons are generated at the dorsal midline of the neural tube, with identical types developing at all levels.

Description A: Pax6 and Emx2 gradients help establish the initial regional pattern of the neocortex.
Description B: Hox6 and Emx2 gradients help establish the initial regional pattern of the neocortex.

Description A: Homeodomain transcription factors induced or repressed by Shh signaling sharpen boundaries in progenitor domains through cross-repressive interactions.
Description B: Homeodomain transcription factors induced or repressed by BMP signaling sharpen boundaries in progenitor domains through cross-repressive interactions.

Description A: The monosynaptic stretch reflex drives contraction of a stretched muscle and has a response time of around 25 ms.
Description B: The monosynaptic stretch reflex drives relaxation of a stretched muscle and has a response time of around 25 ms.

Description A: Sensory prediction error can drive learning of internal models and also initiate reactive motor responses.
Description B: Sensory prediction error does not contribute to the learning of internal models but can initiate reactive motor responses.

Description A: Feedforward control does not monitor sensory feedback during movement and relies on an inverse model to predict motor commands.
Description B: Feedforward control extensively monitors sensory feedback during movement to adjust motor commands.

Description A: Visual inputs can take around 60 ms to be processed in the retina and transmitted to the visual cortex.
Description B: Visual inputs take approximately 25 ms to be processed in the retina and transmitted to the visual cortex.

Description A: The vestibulo-ocular reflex stabilizes gaze during head rotation in the absence of visual guidance, such as in darkness.
Description B: The vestibulo-ocular reflex requires visual guidance to stabilize gaze during head rotation.

Description A: The advantage of spinal reflexes like the withdrawal reflex is their speed, though they are less flexible than voluntary control systems.
Description B: The advantage of spinal reflexes like the withdrawal reflex is their flexibility, though they are slower than voluntary control systems.

Description A: Smooth pursuit eye movement minimizes velocity error on the retina by using feedback control.
Description B: Smooth pursuit eye movement minimizes positional error on the retina by using feedforward control.

Description A: Proprioception and vision can provide complementary information about limb position, with vision often more reliable for azimuth estimation.
Description B: Proprioception and vision can provide complementary information about limb position, with proprioception often more reliable for azimuth estimation.

Description A: Actions like predictive saccades distinguish skilled performers by their shorter latency when compared to amateurs.
Description B: Actions like predictive saccades distinguish skilled performers by their longer latency when compared to amateurs.

Description A: Internal models allow organisms to contemplate potential actions without committing to them by simulating their consequences.
Description B: Internal models commit organisms to actions without providing an opportunity to simulate their consequences.

Description A: Muscle spindles signal changes in the length of the muscle in which they reside, providing information to the central nervous system about body segment positions.
Description B: Muscle spindles signal changes in the tension of the muscle in which they reside, providing information to the central nervous system about body segment positions.

Description A: Gamma motor neurons innervate the contractile polar regions of intrafusal muscle fibers, thereby adjusting the sensitivity of muscle spindles.
Description B: Gamma motor neurons innervate the noncontractile central regions of intrafusal muscle fibers, thereby adjusting the sensitivity of muscle spindles.

Description A: The primary sensory endings are highly sensitive to the velocity of stretch, providing information about speed and sudden changes in muscle length.
Description B: The secondary sensory endings are highly sensitive to the velocity of stretch, providing information about speed and sudden changes in muscle length.

Description A: Dynamic gamma motor neurons enhance the dynamic sensitivity of primary sensory endings but do not affect secondary sensory endings.
Description B: Dynamic gamma motor neurons enhance the dynamic sensitivity of secondary sensory endings but do not affect primary sensory endings.

Description A: Muscle spindles contain intrafusal fibers, which are arranged parallel to extrafusal fibers, allowing them to change length as the whole muscle changes.
Description B: Muscle spindles contain intrafusal fibers, which are arranged perpendicular to extrafusal fibers, allowing them to change length as the whole muscle changes.

Description A: Golgi tendon organs signal minute changes in muscle tension and provide the nervous system with information about muscle contraction force.
Description B: Golgi tendon organs signal minute changes in muscle length and provide the nervous system with information about joint angles.

Description A: The Ia sensory axons from muscle spindles connect monosynaptically to alpha motor neurons within the spinal cord, enabling rapid reflexes.
Description B: The Ia sensory axons from muscle spindles connect disynaptically to alpha motor neurons within the spinal cord, enabling rapid reflexes.

Description A: Static gamma motor neurons increase the tonic level of activity in both primary and secondary sensory endings while decreasing the dynamic sensitivity of primary endings.
Description B: Static gamma motor neurons increase the tonic level of activity in both primary and secondary sensory endings while increasing the dynamic sensitivity of primary endings.

Description A: In mammals, beta axons can innervate both extrafusal and intrafusal muscle fibers, providing a coupling equivalent to alpha-gamma coactivation.
Description B: In mammals, beta axons exclusively innervate extrafusal muscle fibers, providing a coupling equivalent to alpha-gamma coactivation.

Description A: The dynamic and static gamma motor neurons adjust spindle sensitivity independently to optimize reflex and voluntary movement responses for specific tasks.
Description B: The dynamic and static gamma motor neurons adjust spindle sensitivity uniformly without differentiation to optimize reflex and voluntary movement responses.

Description A: The medial prefrontal cortex is primarily activated during distant threats, while the periaqueductal gray is activated during close, immediate threats.
Description B: The medial prefrontal cortex is primarily activated during close threats, while the periaqueductal gray is activated during distant, anticipatory threats.

Description A: Direct electrical stimulation of the subgenual anterior cingulate cortex (Brodmann's area 25) can enhance mood in patients with severe depression.
Description B: Direct electrical stimulation of the insular cortex (Brodmann's area 25) is traditionally used to treat severe depression and enhance mood.

Description A: Functional imaging studies show that social feelings engage the insular cortices and primary and secondary somatosensory cortices.
Description B: Functional imaging studies show that social feelings engage only the primary somatosensory cortex (S-I), and not the insular cortices or secondary somatosensory cortices.

Description A: Functional imaging supports the idea that the insular cortex processes both interoceptive and emotional information.
Description B: Functional imaging suggests that the insular cortex processes emotional information only, uninvolved in interoceptive processing.

Description A: Fear-related neural circuitry involves the amygdala but includes other brain regions due to its distributed nature.
Description B: Fear-related neural circuitry is exclusively processed within the amygdala without contributions from other brain regions.

Description A: The reward system can involve activation of dopaminergic neurons originating from the ventral tegmental area (VTA).
Description B: The reward system exclusively involves non-dopaminergic pathways and is unrelated to ventral tegmental area activity.

Description A: Cocaine and nicotine amplify dopaminergic transmission, enhancing effects of brain stimulation reward.
Description B: Cocaine and nicotine suppress dopaminergic transmission, reducing effects of brain stimulation reward.

Description A: Brain stimulation reward activates dopaminergic neurons, sometimes leading to the neglect of biological needs like eating.
Description B: Brain stimulation reward exclusively induces biological need fulfillment and does not lead to neglecting basic needs like eating.

Description A: Dopamine release in the forebrain serves as a prediction error signal, modulating responses based on reward expectations.
Description B: Dopamine release in the forebrain serves purely as a hedonic signal responsible for the subjective feeling of pleasure.

Description A: Functional imaging studies link the medial prefrontal cortex and basal ganglia to processing the hedonic component of positive emotions.
Description B: Functional imaging studies suggest that only the medial prefrontal cortex, not the basal ganglia, is involved in processing the hedonic component of positive emotions.

Description A: The primary visual cortex (V1) is identical to Brodmann's area 17.
Description B: The primary visual cortex (V1) corresponds to Brodmann's area 18.

Description A: The dorsal pathway connects the primary visual cortex with the parietal lobe and is involved in guiding movement based on spatial information.
Description B: The dorsal pathway connects the primary visual cortex with the temporal lobe and is involved in object recognition.

Description A: Magno, parvo, and koniocellular layers in the lateral geniculate nucleus receive inputs from different retinal ganglion cells and transmit distinct types of visual information.
