Description B: Magno, parvo, and koniocellular layers in the lateral geniculate nucleus receive inputs from all retinal ganglion cells uniformly and transmit identical visual information.

Description A: The lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) organizes retinal inputs into parvocellular, magnocellular, and koniocellular layers for distinct processing streams.
Description B: The lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) organizes retinal inputs into only parvocellular and magnocellular layers, excluding koniocellular layers.

Description A: Lesions of the optic chiasm cause loss of vision in the temporal half of each visual hemifield, a condition called bitemporal hemianopsia.
Description B: Lesions of the optic chiasm cause loss of vision in the central visual field only, sparing the temporal field.

Description A: The visual areas V1, V2, and V3 are retinotopically organized, meaning they contain continuous maps of the visual field.
Description B: The visual areas V1, V2, and V3 are randomly organized without continuity in visual field mapping.

Description A: The ventral pathway is crucial for object recognition and extends into the temporal lobe of the brain.
Description B: The ventral pathway is crucial for directing eye movements and extends into the parietal lobe of the brain.

Description A: The receptive fields of neurons get larger as they progress higher along the visual pathway beyond the retina and LGN.
Description B: The receptive fields of neurons remain identical in size as signals move through the visual pathway from the retina to the cortex.

Description A: The central region of the visual field has the greatest spatial resolution due to a larger amount of cortex dedicated to it.
Description B: The peripheral region of the visual field has the greatest spatial resolution due to a larger amount of cortex dedicated to it.

Description A: The lateral intraparietal area (LIP) in the parietal cortex is involved in representing spatial targets for eye and limb movements.
Description B: The lateral intraparietal area (LIP) in the temporal cortex is involved in representing spatial targets for auditory perception.

Description A: Muscle afferent feedback to the Primary Motor Cortex (M1) is surprisingly rapid, taking only as little as 20 milliseconds for M1 neurons to respond following a mechanical disturbance to the limb.
Description B: Muscle afferent feedback to the Primary Motor Cortex (M1) is surprisingly slow, taking over 200 milliseconds for M1 neurons to respond following a mechanical disturbance to the limb.

Description A: The long-latency motor corrections (50–100 ms) are influenced by multiple behavioral factors, including urgency and the physics of the limb.
Description B: The long-latency motor corrections (50–100 ms) are only influenced by a single factor: urgency of the behavioral goal.

Description A: Neural activity in primary motor cortex can be rapidly altered to correct movement errors or compensate for limb displacements.
Description B: Neural activity in primary motor cortex remains static and cannot adjust to correct movement errors or limb displacements.

Description A: Visual feedback from a computer monitor rotated 90° clockwise results in movements adapting gradually through practice.
Description B: Visual feedback from a computer monitor rotated 90° clockwise causes immediate adaptation without the need for practice.

Description A: Short-latency stretch responses (20–40 ms) to mechanical disturbances are generated at the spinal level.
Description B: Short-latency stretch responses (20–40 ms) to mechanical disturbances are generated in the cerebral cortex.

Description A: Posterior parietal cortex plays a prominent role in state estimation of the body and sensory guidance of motor actions.
Description B: Posterior parietal cortex is primarily responsible for executing motor actions rather than guiding them.

Description A: The cortical motor system is adaptive and can change its functional architecture to acquire new motor skills.
Description B: The cortical motor system is rigid and unable to adapt or change its functional architecture over time.

Description A: Motor-error signals in the precentral cortex play an important role in trial-by-trial motor adaptation through feedback learning.
Description B: Motor-error signals in the precentral cortex do not contribute to motor adaptation or feedback learning processes.

Description A: Primary Motor Cortex in primates has representations of the entire body, but with larger cortical territories associated with hands and face.
Description B: Primary Motor Cortex in primates has equal cortical representation for all parts of the body, with no emphasis on hands or face.

Description A: Activity in the supplementary motor area often dominates motor planning when internal desires are critical in initiating actions.
Description B: Activity in the supplementary motor area is unrelated to motor planning or internal desires.

Description A: Filopodia project from the body of the growth cone and give it its characteristic ruffled appearance.
Description B: Lamellipodia project from the body of the growth cone and give it its characteristic ruffled appearance.

Description A: The growth cone's motility is influenced by actin polymerization and depolymerization at its base.
Description B: The growth cone's motility is influenced by actin polymerization and depolymerization at its tip.

Description A: Integrin receptors couple to actin in growth cones when they bind molecules associated with the extracellular matrix.
Description B: Integrin receptors couple to microtubules in growth cones when they bind molecules associated with the extracellular matrix.

Description A: Filopodia surface membranes bear receptors for molecules that serve as directional cues for the axon.
Description B: Lamellipodia surface membranes bear receptors for molecules that serve as directional cues for the axon.

Description A: Calcium concentration in growth cones provides a possible basis for changes in the direction of growth.
Description B: Magnesium concentration in growth cones provides a possible basis for changes in the direction of growth.

Description A: Retinal ganglion axons form a precise retinotopic map on the tectal surface.
Description B: Retinal ganglion axons form a precise retinotopic map on the lateral geniculate nucleus.

Description A: High levels of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) cause the growth cone to be attracted to netrin.
Description B: Low levels of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) cause the growth cone to be attracted to netrin.

Description A: Pioneer axons are the first axons to exit the retina and navigate using molecular cues.
Description B: Intermediate axons are the first axons to exit the retina and navigate using molecular cues.

Description A: Intermediate targets like the optic chiasm act as decision regions where retinal axons diverge.
Description B: Intermediate targets like the optic tectum act as decision regions where retinal axons diverge.

Description A: Ephrin molecules presented by midline chiasm cells influence the trajectory of retinal axons.
Description B: Semaphorin molecules presented by midline chiasm cells influence the trajectory of retinal axons.

Description A: The action potential is conducted without decrement and maintains a constant amplitude over great distances.
Description B: The action potential is conducted with decrement and diminishes in amplitude as it travels over great distances.

Description A: The refractory period of an action potential limits the frequency at which a nerve can fire, affecting its information-carrying capacity.
Description B: The refractory period of an action potential increases the frequency at which a nerve can fire, enhancing its information-carrying capacity.

Description A: The Hodgkin-Huxley model accurately describes the properties of the channels responsible for generating and propagating the action potential.
Description B: The Hodgkin-Huxley model was unable to describe the properties of the channels responsible for generating and propagating the action potential.

Description A: Sodium (Na+) influx is responsible for the rising phase of the action potential.
Description B: Potassium (K+) influx is responsible for the rising phase of the action potential.

Description A: The voltage clamp allows researchers to control the membrane potential, enabling measurements of ion channel conductance.
Description B: The voltage clamp prevents researchers from controlling the membrane potential, making it impossible to measure ion channel conductance.

Description A: Tetrodotoxin selectively blocks voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels, preventing the inward sodium current.
Description B: Tetrodotoxin selectively blocks voltage-gated potassium (K+) channels, preventing the outward potassium current.

Description A: The Na+ current reverses direction and becomes outward when the membrane potential exceeds +55 mV.
Description B: The Na+ current continues to increase inwardly as the membrane potential exceeds +55 mV.

Description A: Potassium (K+) channels remain open during prolonged depolarization because they lack a fast inactivation process.
Description B: Potassium (K+) channels close rapidly during prolonged depolarization due to a fast inactivation process.

Description A: The voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels have two gates: an activation gate and an inactivation gate.
Description B: The voltage-gated sodium (Na+) channels have only one gate that controls both activation and inactivation.

Description A: Positive feedback in sodium channels during depolarization drives the membrane potential to the peak of the action potential.
Description B: Negative feedback in sodium channels during depolarization drives the membrane potential to the peak of the action potential.

Description A: Simple cells in the visual cortex have receptive fields divided into ON and OFF subregions, where a bar of light entering the ON subregion causes the cell to fire.
Description B: Simple cells in the visual cortex have receptive fields that respond equally to light and dark stimuli across all locations within their receptive fields.

Description A: Complex cells fire continuously as a stimulus traverses their receptive field, irrespective of whether it is light or dark.
Description B: Complex cells are highly selective for the stationary position of a stimulus within their receptive fields and do not respond to movement.

Description A: Neurons in V1 can signal both oriented receptive fields and global contour characteristics through contextual modulation mechanisms.
Description B: Neurons in V1 can only process unoriented receptive fields and lack contextual integration of contour information.

Description A: In primates, lateral geniculate nucleus neurons project to layer 4C, which contains unoriented receptive fields.
Description B: In primates, the lateral geniculate nucleus neurons project to cortical layers with already fully oriented receptive fields.

Description A: End-inhibited neurons in the visual cortex respond effectively to corners as well as short line segments that fit within their excitatory subfields.
Description B: End-inhibited neurons in the visual cortex are only responsive to long straight lines with no curvature.

Description A: Depth perception is mediated by the integration of binocular input and is significantly influenced by binocular disparity.
Description B: Depth perception is solely determined by monocular cues and is not influenced by binocular disparity.

Description A: Neurons in V2 are able to detect illusory edges created by binocular disparity cues.
Description B: Neurons in V2 are unable to detect illusory edges and only respond to well-defined physical contours.

Description A: Horizontal connections between V1 neurons with similar orientation selectivity mediate contour saliency and the perceptual grouping of elements.
Description B: Horizontal connections in V1 primarily inhibit any neural responses and reduce the detection of contours.

Description A: The barber-pole illusion demonstrates that global scene segmentation determines perceived motion direction.
Description B: The barber-pole illusion demonstrates that local motion signals alone provide complete directional information about movement.

Description A: Neurons in area MT (V5) specialize in integrating local motion signals to produce perception of global motion direction.
Description B: Neurons in area MT (V5) specialize in detecting static edges rather than integrating motion signals.

Description A: Grid cells in the medial entorhinal cortex fire when an animal crosses the vertices of a hexagonal grid-like lattice of spatial locales.
Description B: Grid cells in the medial entorhinal cortex fire randomly at any location regardless of spatial context.

Description A: Hippocampal place cells exhibit remapping, where their spatial firing patterns change completely in response to even subtle alterations in the environment.
Description B: Hippocampal place cells maintain identical firing patterns across environments regardless of changes in sensory or spatial context.

Description A: Speed cells in the medial entorhinal cortex have a high correspondence between their firing rate and an animal's running speed.
Description B: Speed cells in the medial entorhinal cortex show no correlation between their firing rate and an animal's running speed.

Description A: Medial entorhinal cortex grid cells maintain rigid firing relationships across all environments.
Description B: Medial entorhinal cortex grid cells change their firing relationships unpredictably depending on the environment.

Description A: Place fields of hippocampal neurons become unstable when long-term potentiation is disrupted.
Description B: Place fields of hippocampal neurons remain perfectly stable even when long-term potentiation is disrupted.

Description A: Explicit memory depends on the hippocampus and is defined as the conscious recall of facts about people, places, and events.
Description B: Explicit memory is unrelated to the hippocampus and involves unconscious recall of procedural tasks.

Description A: Attentional mechanisms involving the prefrontal cortex and dopamine receptors are required for stable long-term place fields in the hippocampus.
Description B: Stable long-term place fields in the hippocampus form independently of attention or dopamine receptor activation.

Description A: Hippocampal place cells replay prior firing sequences during sleep, a process thought to contribute to memory consolidation.
Description B: Hippocampal place cells are inactive during sleep and play no role in memory consolidation.

Description A: Alzheimer's disease is associated with alterations in both hippocampal place cell stability and entorhinal grid-cell function.
Description B: Alzheimer's disease does not affect either hippocampal place cell stability or entorhinal grid-cell function.

Description A: Grid cells and place cells differ in that grid cells form a universal map consistent across environments, while place cells form highly environment-specific maps.
Description B: Grid cells and place cells both form environment-specific maps that are entirely unrelated across contexts.

Description A: The noradrenergic locus ceruleus plays an important role in attention and has different firing patterns depending on the state of alertness.
Description B: The noradrenergic locus ceruleus is inactive during all states of alertness and does not influence attention patterns.

Description A: The firing rate of locus ceruleus neurons follows an inverted U curve, where both low and high baseline activity correspond to poor performance on attention tasks.
Description B: The firing rate of locus ceruleus neurons shows a linear increase in performance, with higher baseline activity always corresponding to better task performance.

Description A: Drugs that block monoamine reuptake, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, are effective in limiting pain caused by chronic conditions.
Description B: Drugs that enhance monoamine reuptake, rather than block it, are effective in treating chronic pain and migraine headaches.

Description A: Dopaminergic projections from the substantia nigra pars compacta to the striatum are critical for normal motor performance.
Description B: Dopaminergic projections from the locus ceruleus to the striatum are critical for normal motor performance.

Description A: Serotonergic neurons are implicated in motor modulation and repetitive activities such as feeding and grooming.
Description B: Serotonergic neurons are exclusively involved in sensory processing and have no role in motor modulation.

Description A: Monoaminergic systems fire fastest during wakefulness and slow down significantly during non-REM sleep.
Description B: Monoaminergic systems maintain a consistent rate of firing regardless of wakefulness or sleep states.

Description A: Lesions restricted to individual monoaminergic cell groups do not cause a profound loss of wakefulness due to redundancy in these pathways.
Description B: Lesions in monoaminergic cell groups result in immediate and irreversible loss of wakefulness without any compensatory mechanisms.

Description A: During REM sleep, the firing of both serotonergic raphe and noradrenergic locus ceruleus neurons practically ceases.
Description B: During REM sleep, serotonergic raphe and noradrenergic locus ceruleus neurons increase their firing rate significantly.

Description A: Dopamine levels influence the balance between direct and indirect pathways in the striatum, adjusting motor behaviors.
Description B: Dopamine levels have no influence on the striatum or motor behaviors.

Description A: Drugs that block β-adrenergic receptors are clinically used to reduce certain types of tremor, such as those experienced by musicians before performances.
Description B: Drugs that activate β-adrenergic receptors are commonly used to reduce tremor before performances.

Description A: Most type I synapses are glutamatergic and excitatory.
Description B: Most type I synapses are glutamatergic and inhibitory.

Description A: Type II synapses are typically symmetric in appearance because of their less prominent presynaptic and postsynaptic densities.
Description B: Type II synapses are typically asymmetric in appearance because of their prominent presynaptic and postsynaptic densities.

Description A: Excitatory synapses are typically axodendritic and occur mostly on dendritic spines.
Description B: Excitatory synapses are typically axosomatic and occur mostly on dendritic shafts.

Description A: The proximity of a synapse to the axon initial segment determines its effectiveness.
Description B: Synapse proximity to dendritic spines solely determines its effectiveness.

Description A: The ionotropic NMDA receptor is highly permeable to Ca2+ and is voltage-dependent.
Description B: The ionotropic NMDA receptor is highly permeable to K+ and not voltage-dependent.

Description A: Glutamate receptors are clustered at postsynaptic sites, including NMDA and AMPA receptors.
Description B: Glutamate receptors, such as NMDA and AMPA receptors, are clustered exclusively at presynaptic terminals.

Description A: The AMPA receptor's GluA2 subunit prevents Ca2+ conductance due to the presence of arginine.
Description B: The AMPA receptor's GluA2 subunit facilitates Ca2+ conductance due to the presence of glutamine.

Description A: NMDA receptors act as molecular coincidence detectors and require both glutamate presence and depolarization to open.
Description B: NMDA receptors do not require depolarization to open and are only dependent on glutamate presence.

Description A: Excess glutamate can lead to glutamate excitotoxicity caused by high intracellular Ca2+ levels.
Description B: Excess glutamate protects neurons by removing harmful intracellular Ca2+.

Description A: AMPA receptors are tetramers containing subunits encoded by GluA1–GluA4 genes.
Description B: AMPA receptors are tetramers containing subunits encoded by GluN1–GluN5 genes.

Description A: Vestibular signals processed in the hippocampal regions are crucial for spatial location and navigation functions.
Description B: Vestibular signals processed in the hippocampal regions are exclusively responsible for all navigation functions.

Description A: Humans can resolve the location of a sound source directly ahead to within approximately 1 degree.
Description B: Humans can resolve the location of a sound source directly ahead to within approximately 10 degrees.

Description A: The mnemonic 'COWS' refers to Cold water producing nystagmus beating to the Opposite side and Warm water producing nystagmus beating to the Same side.
Description B: The mnemonic 'COWS' refers to Cold water producing nystagmus beating to the Same side and Warm water producing nystagmus beating to the Opposite side.

Description A: High-frequency sounds interact with the external ears to produce destructive and constructive interference, aiding sound localization.
Description B: High-frequency sounds bypass the external ears and are localized through purely mechanoreceptor signals in cochlear neurons.

Description A: Projections from the vestibular nuclei to the thalamus and cortex ensure spatial orientation and influence spatial perception more generally.
Description B: Projections from the vestibular nuclei to the thalamus and cortex are limited to regulating blood pressure and respiration.

Description A: Damage to head direction, place, and grid cell systems impairs a variety of spatial and directional abilities.
Description B: Damage to head direction, place, and grid cell systems enhances navigational abilities due to compensatory neural systems.

Description A: The visual-vertical perception is modified by vestibular and proprioceptive signals indicating body orientation.
Description B: The visual-vertical perception is independent of vestibular and proprioceptive signals, relying solely on visual input.

Description A: Multisensory integration in vestibular nuclei neurons allows discrimination between active and passive movements.
Description B: Multisensory integration in vestibular nuclei neurons prevents discrimination between active and passive movements, leading to confusion in motion detection.

Description A: Patients with vestibular system lesions often report episodes of vertigo and spatial disorientation.
Description B: Patients with vestibular system lesions typically experience enhanced spatial orientation due to cortical compensation.

Description A: The vestibulo-ocular reflex is adaptable, allowing compensatory eye movements to match visual conditions.
Description B: The vestibulo-ocular reflex lacks adaptability, making compensatory eye movements impossible in changing visual conditions.

Description A: The expression of plateau properties mediated by L-type Ca2+ channels in motor neurons is controlled by neuromodulatory neurotransmitters, such as serotonin and norepinephrine.
Description B: The expression of plateau properties mediated by L-type Ca2+ channels in motor neurons is independent of neuromodulatory neurotransmitters, such as serotonin and norepinephrine.

Description A: Voltage-gated A-type transient K+ channels are inactivated at resting membrane potential and require hyperpolarization to remove the inactivation.
Description B: Voltage-gated A-type transient K+ channels are activated at resting membrane potential without requiring hyperpolarization.

Description A: HCN channels are activated during hyperpolarization and promote rebound excitation by limiting sustained inhibitory inputs.
Description B: HCN channels are activated during depolarization and promote prolonged inhibitory effects on neurons.

Description A: Glutamatergic neurons in both the pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN) and cuneiform nucleus (CNF) are sufficient for supporting alternating locomotion at slower speeds.
Description B: Glutamatergic neurons in both the pedunculopontine nucleus (PPN) and cuneiform nucleus (CNF) are only involved in high-speed locomotion.

Description A: Reciprocal inhibition between neurons in locomotor circuits is regulated by multiple types of voltage-gated ion channels, including transient low-threshold Ca2+ channels.
Description B: Reciprocal inhibition between neurons in locomotor circuits does not involve voltage-gated ion channels such as transient low-threshold Ca2+ channels.

Description A: GABAergic descending pathways can terminate locomotor activity in response to obstacle contact in Xenopus tadpoles.
Description B: Glutamatergic descending pathways can terminate locomotor activity in response to obstacle contact in Xenopus tadpoles.

Description A: Plateau properties amplify and prolong the effect of synaptic excitatory inputs and are generated by activation of slowly inactivating L-type Ca2+ channels or Na+ channels.
Description B: Plateau properties diminish synaptic excitatory effects and are linked to fast-inactivating ion channels.

Description A: Lesions to the pontomedullary reticular formation (PMRF) in the spinal cord lead to disrupted interlimb coordination during locomotion.
Description B: Lesions to the pontomedullary reticular formation (PMRF) in the spinal cord improve interlimb coordination during locomotion.

Description A: Group I sensory fibers from ankle extensors provide feedback that influences stance phase duration during walking.
Description B: Group I sensory fibers from ankle extensors are unrelated to stance phase duration during walking.

Description A: The mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) contains glutamatergic neurons responsible for initiating locomotion in vertebrates.
Description B: The mesencephalic locomotor region (MLR) lacks glutamatergic neurons responsible for initiating locomotion in vertebrates.

Description A: Bradykinin is one of the most active pain-producing agents, directly activating Aδ and C nociceptors and increasing the synthesis and release of prostaglandins from nearby cells.
Description B: Bradykinin is one of the least active pain-producing agents and reduces the synthesis of prostaglandins in nearby cells.

Description A: Substance P acts on mast cells to evoke degranulation and the release of histamine, which directly excites nociceptors.
Description B: Substance P acts on mast cells to inhibit degranulation and suppress the release of histamine, reducing nociceptor excitation.

Description A: Central sensitization of pain transmission circuitry in the dorsal horn can decrease pain thresholds and lead to spontaneous pain.
Description B: Central sensitization in the dorsal horn increases pain thresholds, reducing spontaneous pain.

Description A: Peripheral injury induces COX-2, leading to increased prostaglandin synthesis and enhanced pain sensitivity.
Description B: Peripheral injury suppresses COX-2, reducing prostaglandin synthesis and decreasing pain sensitivity.

Description A: Neuropeptides such as CGRP and Substance P contribute to neurogenic inflammation by causing vasodilation and plasma extravasation.
Description B: Neuropeptides such as CGRP and Substance P suppress neurogenic inflammation by reducing vasodilation and preventing plasma extravasation.

Description A: Antibodies targeting CGRP are a promising treatment for migraine therapy as they counteract vasodilation.
Description B: Antibodies targeting CGRP exacerbate migraines by promoting vasodilation.

Description A: Spinothalamic tract axons cross the midline of the spinal cord near their segment of origin and ascend in the anterolateral white matter.
Description B: Spinothalamic tract axons remain ipsilateral and ascend through the posterior white matter of the spinal cord without crossing the midline.

Description A: The convergence of visceral and somatic afferent fibers on the same dorsal horn neurons can cause referred pain.
Description B: The convergence of visceral and somatic afferent fibers on separate dorsal horn neurons prevents the occurrence of referred pain.

Description A: Mechanical allodynia can arise from inappropriate engagement of dorsal horn nociceptive circuits by Aβ myelinated afferents.
Description B: Mechanical allodynia arises exclusively from primary nociceptor activation and cannot involve Aβ myelinated afferents.

Description A: Substance P and neurokinin-1 receptor interactions elicit slow excitatory postsynaptic potentials that prolong depolarization.
Description B: Substance P and neurokinin-1 receptor interactions inhibit depolarization, leading to reduced excitatory potentials.

Description A: Some neurons in the supplementary motor complex (SMC) of monkeys encode specific sequences of motor acts, and their activity is context-dependent based on the sequence being performed.
Description B: Some neurons in the supplementary motor complex (SMC) of monkeys randomly fire regardless of the sequence or motor acts being performed.

Description A: The readiness potential, observed in the supplementary motor area (SMA), arises in the frontal cortex roughly 0.8 to 1.0 seconds before the onset of self-paced movement.
Description B: The readiness potential, observed in the premotor cortex, arises in the parietal cortex roughly 2.0 seconds before the onset of self-paced movement.

Description A: Lesions in the supplementary motor area (SMA) can result in deficits in self-initiated movements and speech, even though prompted movement capabilities remain intact.
Description B: Lesions in the supplementary motor area (SMA) improve capabilities for self-initiated movements and speech without the need for external prompts.

Description A: Utilization behavior involves compulsively grabbing objects and using them without considering need or social context.
Description B: Utilization behavior involves thoughtfully choosing objects and using them based on social or environmental necessity.

Description A: Focal lesions in the ventral premotor cortex disrupt the ability to shape the hand for the size and orientation of an object before grasping.
Description B: Focal lesions in the ventral premotor cortex enhance the ability to shape the hand more precisely before grasping objects of varying sizes and orientations.

Description A: Neurons in the premotor cortex actively signal decisions to refrain from movement based on instructional cues.
Description B: Neurons in the premotor cortex are incapable of signaling decisions related to refraining from movement based on instructional cues.

Description A: The PMd neurons can prepare multiple potential motor actions prior to a final decision, and this process may be limited to three or four simultaneous options.
Description B: The PMd neurons can prepare up to ten simultaneous motor actions prior to any final decisions.

Description A: Some PMv neurons encode the goal of a motor act rather than individual movements forming the act.
Description B: PMv neurons exclusively encode individual movements with no correlation to the goal of the motor act.

Description A: The prefrontal cortex shows weaker and later correlates of behavioral rules and decisions compared to the PMd in decision-making tasks.
Description B: The prefrontal cortex shows stronger and earlier correlates of behavioral rules and decisions compared to PMd in decision-making tasks.

Description A: Premotor neurons contribute to sensory-guided motor actions as well as perceptual decision-making, such as discriminating vibratory frequencies applied to a finger.
Description B: Premotor neurons contribute only to motor actions, having no role in perceptual decision-making or sensory discrimination tasks.

Description A: Postural equilibrium refers to the ability to actively stabilize the upper body by resisting external forces acting on the body.
Description B: Postural equilibrium refers to the ability to passively stabilize the upper body without resisting external forces acting on the body.

Description A: The center of mass in a standing adult is located about 2 cm in front of the second lumbar vertebra.
Description B: The center of mass in a standing adult is fixed directly at the second lumbar vertebra regardless of posture.

Description A: To maintain balance, the nervous system must control the position and motion of the body’s center of mass.
Description B: To maintain balance, the nervous system only controls the body's rotational movements and ignores the center of mass.

Description A: Postural orientation refers to the ability to actively align body segments with respect to each other and to the environment.
Description B: Postural orientation refers to the inability to align body segments with respect to each other or the environment.

Description A: The biomechanical requirements of postural control depend on anatomy and postural orientation, varying among species.
Description B: The biomechanical requirements of postural control are identical across all species regardless of anatomy.

Description A: Maintaining balance while standing requires keeping the downward projection of the center of mass within the base of support.
Description B: Maintaining balance while standing requires ignoring the projection of the center of mass and focusing solely on muscle resistance.

Description A: Balance control differs in certain pathological conditions such as spasticity after stroke, where antigravity support becomes excessive.
Description B: Balance control remains normal in all pathological conditions such as spasticity after a stroke.

Description A: Visual, vestibular, and somatosensory inputs provide the postural system with coherent orientation and motion information.
Description B: Only visual inputs, excluding vestibular and somatosensory signals, are responsible for coherent orientation and motion information.

Description A: Postural equilibrium emphasizes resisting both gravitational and inertial forces.
Description B: Postural equilibrium focuses solely on resisting gravitational forces, ignoring inertial perturbations.

Description A: Postural instability depends on how fast the center of mass accelerates towards the boundary of its base of support.
Description B: Postural instability is unaffected by the center of mass's acceleration or its proximity to the boundary of the base of support.

Description A: The resting potential of a cell is determined by the proportions of different types of ion channels that are open, together with the value of their equilibrium potentials.
Description B: The resting potential of a cell is determined exclusively by the number of Na+ channels that are open.

Description A: During intense neuronal activity, the increased influx of Na+ leads to an increase in Na+-K+ pump activity that generates a prolonged outward current, leading to hyperpolarizing after-potential.
Description B: During intense neuronal activity, the increased influx of Na+ decreases Na+-K+ pump activity causing depolarization instead.

Description A: The Na+-K+ pump is a member of a large family of pumps known as P-type ATPases, which temporarily transfer the phosphoryl group of ATP to the pump.
Description B: The Na+-K+ pump is a member of a large family of pumps known as F-type ATPases, which do not rely on ATP hydrolysis.

Description A: The Na+-Ca2+ exchanger transports three or four Na+ ions into the cell for each Ca2+ ion it removes.
Description B: The Na+-Ca2+ exchanger transports one Na+ ion into the cell for every two Ca2+ ions it removes.

Description A: Most neurons have comparatively few Ca2+ pumps in their membranes, and Ca2+ is transported out mainly by the Na+-Ca2+ exchanger.
Description B: Most neurons primarily rely on Ca2+ pumps for transporting calcium out of the cell, with minimal reliance on the Na+-Ca2+ exchanger.

Description A: The Na+-K+-Cl− cotransporter is electroneutral because it transports two Cl− ions along with one Na+ and one K+ ion.
Description B: The Na+-K+-Cl− cotransporter generates a net charge because it transports one Cl− ion along with one Na+ and two K+ ions.

Description A: In early nervous system development, cells express primarily the Na+-K+-Cl− cotransporter, making GABA excitatory in immature neurons.
Description B: In early nervous system development, GABA is inhibitory in neurons because the Na+-K+-Cl− cotransporter actively decreases intracellular chloride levels.

Description A: The Goldman equation shows that the resting membrane potential is determined by the relative permeability of the membrane to multiple ions.
Description B: The Goldman equation shows that the resting membrane potential is determined by the osmotic gradients across the membrane, independent of ion permeability.

Description A: At the peak of the action potential, the membrane potential approaches the Na+ equilibrium potential but does not reach it due to continuing K+ efflux.
Description B: At the peak of the action potential, the membrane potential exceeds the Na+ equilibrium potential because K+ channels are entirely inactive.

Description A: The Na+-K+ pump actively transports three Na+ ions out of the cell for every two K+ ions it pumps in.
Description B: The Na+-K+ pump actively transports two Na+ ions out of the cell for every three K+ ions it pumps in.

Description A: Monozygotic twins share nearly all genes and have a high (but not 100%) risk of sharing the disease state.
Description B: Monozygotic twins share exactly 50% of their genes, and have a low risk of sharing the disease state.

Description A: Schizophrenia risk in family members suggests complex genetic and environmental factors are involved.
Description B: Schizophrenia risk in family members suggests it is caused entirely by a single gene without environmental influence.

Description A: DNA is composed of nucleotide bases adenine, thymine, cytosine, and guanine assembled on a sugar-phosphate backbone.
Description B: DNA is composed of nucleotide bases uracil, adenine, cytosine, and guanine assembled without a sugar-phosphate backbone.

Description A: The human genome contains approximately 20,000 protein-coding genes and over 40,000 noncoding transcripts.
Description B: The human genome contains over 40,000 protein-coding genes and approximately 20,000 noncoding transcripts.

Description A: Humans have 46 chromosomes, including 22 pairs of autosomes and two sex chromosomes.
Description B: Humans have 46 chromosomes, including 46 pairs of autosomes and no sex chromosomes.

Description A: Mitochondrial DNA is maternally inherited and can cause disorders such as neuromuscular diseases and deafness.
Description B: Mitochondrial DNA is paternally inherited and exclusively linked to eye color variation.

Description A: A dominant mutation can occur if the expression of a wild-type gene product acts antagonistically to the normal protein.
Description B: A dominant mutation cannot involve antagonistic interactions of the wild-type gene product.

Description A: Humans share 99% of their protein-coding genes with chimpanzees.
Description B: Humans only share 10% of their protein-coding genes with chimpanzees.

Description A: Genetic disorders can involve simple Mendelian mutations or complex genetic contributions influenced by environment.
Description B: Genetic disorders are entirely caused by simple Mendelian mutations and never influenced by the environment.

Description A: CRISPR allows researchers to target and modify specific DNA sequences using components of a bacterial immune system.
Description B: CRISPR exclusively destroys RNA sequences without targeting DNA in genetic editing.

Description A: Generalized onset seizures typically begin abruptly and disrupt normal brain activity in both hemispheres simultaneously.
Description B: Generalized onset seizures gradually build up and only affect one hemisphere of the brain initially.

Description A: Focal onset seizures can rapidly generalize if they originate in the neocortex rather than the limbic system.
Description B: Focal onset seizures are less likely to generalize rapidly if they originate in the neocortex rather than the limbic system.

Description A: Absence seizures are characterized by a distinct 3-Hz spike-and-wave EEG pattern and are not preceded by an aura.
Description B: Absence seizures often display a 10-Hz spike pattern and are preceded by an aura.

Description A: Thalamocortical circuits play a critical role in the generation of typical absence seizures.
Description B: Thalamocortical circuits are unrelated to the generation of typical absence seizures.

Description A: Mesial temporal sclerosis is commonly associated with atrophy and cell loss in the hippocampal formation.
Description B: Mesial temporal sclerosis typically results in the enlargement and hyperactivity of the hippocampal formation.

Description A: Status epilepticus, if not controlled, can lead to serious systemic complications and brain damage.
Description B: Status epilepticus has no long-term effects and typically resolves on its own without treatment.

Description A: Excitotoxicity can result from excessive activation of glutamate receptors leading to neuronal death.
Description B: Excitotoxicity is caused by a shortage of glutamate in the brain, leading to neuronal inactivity.

Description A: Functional MRI can be used to map seizure foci when anatomical MRI scans show no abnormalities.
Description B: Functional MRI is incapable of detecting seizure foci when anatomical MRI scans appear normal.

Description A: T-type calcium channels are important in the generation of absence seizures and are targeted by certain anticonvulsant drugs.
Description B: T-type calcium channels have no role in the generation of absence seizures and are not targeted by medications.

Description A: EEG patterns in typical absence seizures show synchronous activity occurring across all brain regions simultaneously.
Description B: EEG patterns in typical absence seizures show localized activity confined to a small region of the brain.

Description A: Conscious awareness may arise when the nonconscious brain reaches a decision to report an item to another mind.
Description B: Conscious awareness may arise when the nonconscious brain decides to ignore all evidence of an item during processing.

Description A: Color constancy allows the perception of 'red' to remain invariant despite changes in illuminating light.
Description B: Color constancy disrupts the perception of 'red,' making it entirely dependent on light changes.

Description A: Theory of mind involves reasoning about the mental states or knowledge of others.
Description B: Theory of mind exclusively pertains to understanding the visual perspective of others, without considering mental states.

Description A: Some decisions benefit from multiple pieces of evidence accumulated over time.
Description B: Most decisions involve instantaneous conclusions based on singular, isolated pieces of evidence.

Description A: Neurons in the parietal cortex are capable of holding and updating firing rates, which represent evolving decision variables.
Description B: Neurons in the parietal cortex are incapable of holding firing rates or contributing to decision-making processes.

Description A: Narrative enriches knowledge states by incorporating memory, predictions, and consequences.
Description B: Narrative simplifies knowledge states by excluding history, predictions, and consequences.

Description A: The right temporal-parietal junction is active during tasks requiring theory of mind.
Description B: The right temporal-parietal junction is inactive during tasks requiring theory of mind.

Description A: Sleep, anesthesia, and coma represent different levels of arousal related to neurology-consciousness.
Description B: Sleep, anesthesia, and coma represent permanent states unrelated to consciousness or arousal levels.

Description A: The nonconscious brain processes sensory information and can influence decisions without conscious awareness.
Description B: The nonconscious brain is incapable of processing sensory information or influencing behavior.

Description A: The conscious brain does not rely on a special neuron type, brain region, or mechanism to bestow consciousness.
Description B: The conscious brain exclusively relies on a special neuron type and a dedicated brain region to bestow consciousness.

Description A: The polypeptides that become secretory and membrane proteins are translocated across the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum.
Description B: The polypeptides that become secretory and membrane proteins are synthesized completely in the cytosol without interaction with the rough endoplasmic reticulum membrane.

Description A: N-acylation involves the transfer of an acyl group to the N-terminus of the growing polypeptide chain.
Description B: N-acylation involves the transfer of a phosphate group to the N-terminus of the growing polypeptide chain.

Description A: Isoprenylation involves enzymatic steps that result in thioacylation by hydrophobic polyisoprenyl moieties.
Description B: Isoprenylation involves enzymatic steps that result in hydrophilic polyisoprenyl modifications at lysine residues.

Description A: Protein phosphorylation is catalyzed by protein kinases and reversible through protein phosphatases.
Description B: Protein phosphorylation is catalyzed exclusively by phosphatases and cannot be reversed.

Description A: Monoubiquitination tags a protein for degradation in the endosomal–lysosomal system.
Description B: Monoubiquitination tags a protein solely for recycling back to the endoplasmic reticulum.

Description A: Glycosylation can diversify protein function by increasing hydrophilicity and fine-tuning binding to macromolecular partners.
Description B: Glycosylation decreases hydrophilicity and prevents proteins from binding efficiently to macromolecular partners.

Description A: Proteins transported from the trans-Golgi network include secretory products and newly synthesized plasmalemmal proteins.
Description B: Proteins transported from the trans-Golgi network include only previously degraded organelles and damaged proteins.

Description A: Clathrin-coated vesicles are involved in receptor-mediated endocytosis.
Description B: Clathrin-coated vesicles are exclusively involved in protein synthesis.

Description A: Schwann cells in the peripheral nervous system myelinate individual axonal segments, forming nodes of Ranvier.
Description B: Schwann cells in the peripheral nervous system myelinate entire axons continuously without gaps.

Description A: Astrocytes regulate extracellular concentrations of ions and neurotransmitters and can buffer potassium at synaptic sites.
Description B: Astrocytes do not interact with ions or neurotransmitters and primarily serve as structural support for blood vessels.

Description A: The hippocampus comprises a loop of connections that process multimodal sensory and spatial information from the entorhinal cortex, passing through multiple synapses before arriving at the hippocampal CA1 region.
Description B: The hippocampus comprises a loop of connections that process multimodal sensory and spatial information from the prefrontal cortex, passing through multiple synapses before arriving at the hippocampal CA1 region.

Description A: Donald Hebb proposed the influential theory in 1949 that memory-encoding neural assemblies are generated when synaptic connections are strengthened based on experience.
Description B: Donald Hebb proposed the influential theory in 1949 that memory-encoding neural assemblies are generated when synaptic connections are weakened based on experience.

Description A: In the indirect pathway, axons of neurons in the entorhinal cortex excite granule cells of the dentate gyrus via the perforant pathway.
Description B: In the indirect pathway, axons of neurons in the entorhinal cortex excite CA1 pyramidal cells directly via the perforant pathway.

Description A: The Schaffer collateral pathway involves connections between CA3 pyramidal neurons and CA1 pyramidal neurons.
Description B: The Schaffer collateral pathway involves connections between dentate granule cells and CA3 pyramidal neurons.

Description A: Long-term potentiation (LTP) at Schaffer collateral synapses requires activation of NMDA receptor channels in the postsynaptic neurons.
Description B: Long-term potentiation (LTP) at Schaffer collateral synapses does not require activation of NMDA receptor channels in the postsynaptic neurons.

Description A: The mossy fiber pathway mediates long-term potentiation (LTP) through presynaptic mechanisms that enhance transmitter release via protein kinase A (PKA) activation.
Description B: The mossy fiber pathway mediates long-term potentiation (LTP) through postsynaptic mechanisms reliant on NMDA receptor activation.

Description A: The direct perforant pathway sends excitatory signals from neurons in layer III of the entorhinal cortex to the distal regions of CA1 apical dendrites.
Description B: The direct perforant pathway sends excitatory signals from neurons in layer II of the entorhinal cortex to the proximal regions of CA1 apical dendrites.

Description A: The process of synaptic tagging during late LTP allows activated synapses to capture newly synthesized proteins for long-lasting synaptic plasticity.
Description B: The process of synaptic tagging during late LTP prevents activated synapses from utilizing newly synthesized proteins for long-lasting synaptic plasticity.

Description A: Calcium influx through NMDA receptor channels is critical for the induction of long-term potentiation at CA1 neurons.
Description B: Calcium influx through AMPA receptor channels is critical for the induction of long-term potentiation at CA1 neurons.

Description A: Most isoforms of protein kinase C (PKC) require regulatory domains, whereas PKMζ is constitutively active and lacks regulatory control.
Description B: Most isoforms of protein kinase C (PKC) lack regulatory domains, whereas PKMζ is regulated by calcium signaling.

Description A: Stretch reflex pathways act as negative feedback systems that regulate muscle length by counteracting deviations from a reference length.
Description B: Stretch reflex pathways act as positive feedback systems that amplify deviations from a reference length.

Description A: The Ia inhibitory interneurons receive both excitatory and inhibitory signals from descending pathways to modulate reciprocal inhibition of muscles.
Description B: The Ia inhibitory interneurons receive only inhibitory signals from descending pathways to modulate reciprocal inhibition of muscles.

Description A: During locomotion, Ib sensory fibers from extensor muscles reverse their action from inhibition to excitation of motor neurons.
Description B: During locomotion, Ib sensory fibers from extensor muscles maintain an inhibitory effect on motor neurons.

Description A: Renshaw cells provide recurrent inhibition to motor neurons, stabilizing firing rates and regulating excitability.
Description B: Renshaw cells provide recurrent excitation to motor neurons, destabilizing firing rates and increasing excitability.

Description A: Damage to descending motor pathways can lead to spasticity, characterized by hyperactive tendon jerks and increased resistance to rapid muscle stretching.
Description B: Damage to descending motor pathways can lead to flaccidity, characterized by hypoactive tendon jerks and decreased resistance to rapid muscle stretching.

Description A: Propriospinal neurons in the C3-C4 spinal segments relay motor commands between corticospinal fibers and cervical motor neurons.
Description B: Propriospinal neurons in the C3-C4 spinal segments directly activate thoracic motor neurons bypassing corticospinal fibers.

Description A: Presynaptic inhibition reduces sensory feedback predicted by motor commands while enabling unexpected feedback to reach motor circuits.
Description B: Presynaptic inhibition amplifies sensory feedback predicted by motor commands while suppressing unexpected feedback to motor circuits.

Description A: Humans and Old World monkeys have direct corticomotor connections to spinal motor neurons unlike most other vertebrates.
Description B: Humans and Old World monkeys rely entirely on propriospinal neurons for corticomotor connections to spinal motor neurons.

Description A: State-dependent reflex reversal facilitates extensor muscles during locomotion by favoring excitatory pathways from load-sensitive Golgi tendon organs.
Description B: State-dependent reflex reversal inhibits extensor muscles during locomotion by favoring inhibitory pathways from load-sensitive Golgi tendon organs.

Description A: Spinal reflex pathways can adapt based on individual motor experience, such as improved coordination of agonist and antagonist muscle activity.
Description B: Spinal reflex pathways are entirely fixed and do not adapt based on individual motor experience or training.

Description A: The action potential is continually regenerated and does not attenuate as it moves down the axon.
Description B: The action potential attenuates as it moves down the axon but can be regenerated at specific points.

Description A: The refractory period limits the frequency at which a nerve can fire action potentials.
Description B: The refractory period is necessary for amplifying the frequency at which a nerve can fire action potentials.

Description A: Voltage-gated sodium channels select for sodium on the basis of size, charge, and energy of hydration of the ion.
Description B: Voltage-gated calcium channels select for sodium on the basis of size, charge, and energy of hydration of the ion.

Description A: Myelinated axons increase conduction velocity by decreasing membrane capacitance.
Description B: Myelinated axons increase conduction velocity by decreasing axial resistance alone.

Description A: The membrane length constant is proportional to the square root of the radius of the neuronal process.
Description B: The membrane length constant is directly proportional to the radius of the neuronal process.

Description A: Thicker axons and dendrites have longer length constants than do narrower processes.
Description B: Thicker axons and dendrites have shorter length constants than do narrower processes.

Description A: Saltatory conduction occurs in myelinated axons due to nodes of Ranvier.
Description B: Saltatory conduction occurs in unmyelinated axons due to nodes of Ranvier.

Description A: The refractory period limits the ability of successive adjacent regions of the axon membrane to depolarize immediately.
Description B: The refractory period enables immediate and successive depolarization of adjacent regions of the axon membrane.

Description A: The time constant τ for neurons is given by the product of membrane resistance and capacitance (RmCm).
Description B: The time constant τ for neurons is given by the sum of membrane resistance and capacitance (RmCm).

Description A: In neurons, the inward current through voltage-gated ion channels contributes to action potential propagation.
Description B: In neurons, extracellular fluid alone contributes to action potential propagation.

Description A: Place cells in the hippocampus tile the entire environment, and any given location is encoded by a unique ensemble of cells.
Description B: Place cells in the hippocampus encode random locations that are not mapped to a unique ensemble of cells.

Description A: Activity of principal excitatory neurons in the hippocampus is modulated by local circuit GABAergic interneurons.
Description B: Activity of principal excitatory neurons in the hippocampus is independent of any modulation by local circuit interneurons.

Description A: Sharp-wave ripples in the hippocampus are prominent during resting periods after recent learning, such as after exploration of an environment.
Description B: Sharp-wave ripples in the hippocampus are unrelated to resting periods and do not occur after exploration of an environment.

Description A: Feedforward circuits process information in a single direction from one neuron population to another, such as from the retina to the visual cortex.
Description B: Feedforward circuits process information in multiple directions simultaneously through a looping pathway.

Description A: Hebbian plasticity strengthens synapses when presynaptic input and postsynaptic activity cooperate to cause a neuron to fire an action potential.
Description B: Hebbian plasticity weakens synapses regardless of presynaptic input and postsynaptic activity cooperation.

Description A: The cerebellum plays a crucial role in motor learning, including delay eyeblink conditioning where animals learn to close their eye in response to a conditioned stimulus.
Description B: The cerebellum is unrelated to motor learning and does not participate in conditioning tasks like delay eyeblink responses.

Description A: Granule cells in the cerebellum receive inputs that often originate from distinct brain regions, allowing for diverse combinations of stimuli.
Description B: Granule cells in the cerebellum receive inputs exclusively from a single brain region without combining stimuli.

Description A: Recurrent circuits in the oculomotor system enable sustained neural activity required for maintaining eye position after movements.
Description B: Recurrent circuits in the oculomotor system only provide transient signals and cannot maintain eye position after movements.

Description A: Visual processing follows a hierarchical structure, with neurons in higher areas responding selectively to complex objects, such as faces.
Description B: Visual processing occurs randomly without a hierarchical structure, and neurons do not respond selectively to complex objects like faces.

Description A: Purkinje cells in the cerebellum receive input from hundreds of thousands of granule cells via parallel fibers, demonstrating convergent connectivity.
Description B: Purkinje cells in the cerebellum receive inputs randomly without specific connectivity patterns to granule cells.

Description A: The KcsA bacterial potassium channel is composed of four identical subunits arranged symmetrically around a central pore.
Description B: The KcsA bacterial potassium channel is composed of four non-identical subunits arranged asymmetrically around a central pore.

Description A: The selectivity filter of the KcsA channel is formed by the P-loop of the subunits.
Description B: The selectivity filter of the KcsA channel is formed by the outer helix of the subunits.

Description A: The KcsA channel’s selectivity filter provides optimal electrostatic interactions with K+ ions, making it impervious to smaller Na+ ions.
Description B: The KcsA channel’s selectivity filter permits both K+ and Na+ ions equally due to its width.

Description A: The crystal structure of the KcsA channel indicates that its cytoplasmic pore in the closed state is too narrow to allow passage of K+ ions.
Description B: The crystal structure of the KcsA channel indicates that its cytoplasmic pore in the closed state is wide enough to allow passage of ions.

Description A: In the selectivity filter of the KcsA channel, potassium ions are stabilized by interactions with eight oxygen atoms.
Description B: In the selectivity filter of the KcsA channel, potassium ions are stabilized by interactions with six oxygen atoms.

Description A: The KcsA channel minimizes energy differences by filling its inner chamber with water, creating a polar environment.
Description B: The KcsA channel minimizes energy differences by expelling water from its inner chamber, creating a non-polar environment.

Description A: The KcsA channel accommodates at most three K+ ions at any instant, as demonstrated by X-ray analysis.
Description B: The KcsA channel can accommodate up to five K+ ions simultaneously, as demonstrated by X-ray analysis.

Description A: Mutual electrostatic repulsion between two K+ ions in the KcsA selectivity filter ensures a high permeation rate.
Description B: Mutual electrostatic attraction between two K+ ions in the KcsA selectivity filter ensures they remain tightly bound in the channels.

Description A: The amino acid sequence of the KcsA channel subunits is homologous to the S5-P-S6 region of vertebrate voltage-gated K+ channels.
Description B: The amino acid sequence of the KcsA channel subunits is homologous to the S1-S2 region of vertebrate voltage-gated K+ channels.

Description A: The KcsA channel’s selectivity filter width excludes Na+ ions while allowing K+ ions optimal electrostatic interaction.
Description B: The KcsA channel’s selectivity filter width allows Na+ ions optimal electrostatic interaction while excluding K+ ions.

Description A: Long-term depression (LTD) occurs when AMPA receptors are removed from the postsynaptic membrane by endocytosis, and it is blocked when NMDA receptors are blocked by the drug APV.
Description B: Long-term depression (LTD) occurs when AMPA receptors are added to the postsynaptic membrane by exocytosis, and it is blocked when NMDA receptors are blocked by the drug APV.

Description A: Protein phosphatase 2A is required for LTD, as demonstrated in transgenic mice expressing a phosphatase inhibitor.
Description B: Protein phosphatase 2A is not required for LTD, as demonstrated in transgenic mice expressing a phosphatase inhibitor.

Description A: LTD in the amygdala may be important for reversing learned fear in fear conditioning studies.
Description B: LTD in the amygdala is primarily responsible for amplifying learned fear in fear conditioning studies.

Description A: Transgenic mice expressing a phosphatase inhibitor showed impaired learning when the platform location in the Morris maze was changed, indicating reduced behavioral flexibility.
Description B: Transgenic mice expressing a phosphatase inhibitor showed improved learning when the platform location in the Morris maze was changed, indicating enhanced behavioral flexibility.

Description A: LTD is normal in transgenic mice when transgene expression suppressing phosphatase activity is turned off with doxycycline.
Description B: LTD is still inhibited in transgenic mice even when transgene expression suppressing phosphatase activity is turned off with doxycycline.

Description A: CA3 neurons with NMDA receptor deletion exhibit impaired pattern completion when fewer spatial cues are available.
Description B: CA3 neurons with NMDA receptor deletion exhibit improved pattern completion when fewer spatial cues are available.

Description A: The dentate gyrus is important for pattern separation by expanding neural activity patterns through projection to a larger population of granule neurons.
Description B: The dentate gyrus is important for pattern completion by compressing neural activity patterns through projection to a smaller population of granule neurons.

Description A: Place cells in the hippocampus fire when an animal is in specific spatial locations, forming an allocentric map of the environment.
Description B: Place cells in the hippocampus fire randomly without regard to specific spatial locations, forming a random map of the environment.

Description A: Grid cells in the entorhinal cortex fire at regularly spaced positions that form a hexagonal grid.
Description B: Grid cells in the entorhinal cortex fire randomly at irregularly spaced positions.

Description A: Head direction cells in the entorhinal cortex fire selectively based on the direction an animal is facing.
Description B: Head direction cells in the entorhinal cortex fire based on the speed at which an animal is moving.

Description A: During an action potential, the Na+ channels open in an all-or-none fashion and are rapidly inactivated shortly afterwards.
Description B: During an action potential, the Na+ channels open gradually in a graded fashion and remain open for an extended period of time.

Description A: The threshold for generating an action potential is the specific value of Vm at which the net ionic current (INa + IK + Il) changes from outward to inward.
Description B: The threshold for generating an action potential is the specific value of Vm at which outward current completely stops while inward Na+ currents instantly maximize.

Description A: The absolute refractory period is the time after an action potential during which it is impossible to generate another action potential due to Na+ channels remaining inactivated.
Description B: The absolute refractory period is the time after an action potential during which action potentials are easier to generate because of the residual activation of Na+ channels.

Description A: During the relative refractory period, Vm is slightly more negative than its resting value due to residual K+ conductance, making it harder to reach threshold.
Description B: During the relative refractory period, Vm is slightly more positive than its resting value due to residual K+ conductance, making it easier to reach threshold.

Description A: Voltage-gated Na+ channel gating currents are produced by the movement of positively charged residues in the S4 regions through the membrane electric field.
Description B: Voltage-gated Na+ channel gating currents are produced by the movement of negatively charged residues in the S4 regions through the membrane electric field.

Description A: The voltage dependence of sodium channel activation follows a sigmoid curve, as described by the Boltzmann function.
Description B: The voltage dependence of sodium channel activation follows a linear relationship rather than a sigmoid curve.

Description A: The selectivity of Na+ channels is determined by their ability to accommodate Na+ with some hydration, unlike K+ channels that require full dehydration.
Description B: The selectivity of Na+ channels is determined by their ability to fully dehydrate Na+ ions, unlike K+ channels which allow hydrated ions.

Description A: Nav1.1 channels are particularly strongly expressed in inhibitory GABAergic interneurons, and their loss-of-function mutations are associated with epilepsy.
Description B: Nav1.1 channels are primarily expressed in excitatory neurons, and their loss-of-function mutations are commonly associated with muscular dystrophy.

Description A: Cav1.2 and Cav1.3 channels, also known as L-type channels, are members of the high-voltage activated (HVA) Ca2+ channel family.
Description B: Cav1.2 and Cav1.3 channels, also known as L-type channels, are members of the low-voltage activated (LVA) Ca2+ channel family.

Description A: Kv3 family channels are activated by large depolarizations near the action potential peak and inactivate rapidly afterward.
Description B: Kv3 family channels are activated by small depolarizations at resting membrane potential and remain open during the entire action potential cycle.

Description A: Inferior temporal cortex cells maintain selectivity across position, size, and even rotation, supporting perceptual constancy.
Description B: Inferior temporal cortex cells change their selectivity drastically with position, size, and rotation, disrupting perceptual constancy.

Description A: Face-specific cells in the inferior temporal cortex respond similarly to a range of faces and exhibit selectivity within specialized face areas.
Description B: Face-specific cells in the inferior parietal cortex respond similarly to a range of faces and exhibit selectivity within general areas.

Description A: The inferior temporal cortex is interconnected with the medial temporal lobe for memory formation and with the prefrontal cortex for categorization and working memory.
Description B: The inferior temporal cortex is interconnected with the cerebellum for memory formation and with the occipital cortex for categorization and working memory.

Description A: Dorsolateral prefrontal cortex neurons exhibit categorical selectivity and simplify behavior by grouping similar visual objects.
Description B: Inferior temporal cortex neurons exhibit categorical selectivity and simplify behavior by grouping similar auditory objects.

Description A: Lesions to the inferior temporal cortex cause visual agnosia, impairing object recognition capabilities.
Description B: Lesions to the anterior temporal cortex cause auditory agnosia, impairing speech recognition capabilities.

Description A: Face recognition relies on multiple face areas interconnected as a selective face-processing network in the temporal lobe.
Description B: Face recognition relies on isolated neurons scattered randomly across the occipital lobe.

Description A: Object recognition depends on visual past experiences, and perceptual learning improves discrimination between complex objects.
Description B: Object recognition focuses only on innate capabilities, and learning does not improve discrimination or neural selectivity.

Description A: Working memory involves neurons in temporal and prefrontal cortexes that exhibit delay-period activity during the disappearance of a stimulus.
Description B: Working memory involves neurons in occipital and parietal cortexes showing random periodic spikes irrelevant to stimuli.

Description A: The sensory experience of an image and its recall involve similar neuronal activity in the inferior temporal cortex.
Description B: The sensory experience of an image and its recall involve entirely different pathways in the cerebellum.

Description A: Object recognition is processed in the inferior temporal cortex, which handles meaning and function of objects.
Description B: Object recognition is processed in the occipital cortex, which handles only the peripheral view of objects.

Description A: NMDA receptors act as molecular coincidence detectors, opening during the concurrent activation of presynaptic and postsynaptic cells when glutamate is present and the cell is depolarized.
Description B: NMDA receptors act as molecular coincidence detectors, opening during the activation of only presynaptic cells, regardless of whether the postsynaptic cell is depolarized.

Description A: Excessively high concentrations of glutamate can result in neuronal toxicity by causing an overload of Ca2+ influx through NMDA receptor channels.
Description B: High concentrations of glutamate are protective against neuronal toxicity due to Ca2+ influx through NMDA receptor channels.

Description A: APV, a drug that blocks NMDA receptors, prevents long-term potentiation (LTP) in CA1 neurons during tetanic stimulation.
Description B: APV, a drug that blocks AMPA receptors, prevents long-term potentiation (LTP) in CA1 neurons during tetanic stimulation.

Description A: During normal synaptic transmission, AMPA receptors mediate sodium and potassium ion flow in CA1 neurons, but NMDA receptor pores are blocked by Mg2+ at resting potentials.
Description B: During normal synaptic transmission, NMDA receptors mediate sodium and potassium ion flow in CA1 neurons constantly, unaffected by Mg2+.

Description A: The insertion of additional AMPA receptors into the postsynaptic membrane enhances synaptic transmission and is a key mechanism of LTP.
Description B: The removal of AMPA receptors from the postsynaptic membrane enhances synaptic transmission and is a key mechanism of LTP.

Description A: Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis can lead to psychosis and seizures due to reduced NMDA receptor function caused by autoimmune antibody production.
Description B: Anti-NMDA receptor encephalitis leads to an increased NMDA receptor function caused by autoimmune antibody production.

Description A: Activation of NMDA receptors during development plays a critical role in refining synaptic connections and neural circuits critical for long-term memory.
Description B: Activation of NMDA receptors during development destabilizes synaptic connections, impairing the formation of neural circuits related to long-term memory.

Description A: The prolonged firing required to induce LTP is unlikely in physiological conditions, but spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) offers a more relevant model in paired presynaptic and postsynaptic activity.
Description B: The prolonged firing required to induce LTP is commonly observed under physiological conditions, and STDP is not a significant model for synaptic plasticity.

Description A: LTP at Schaffer collateral synapses requires a strong postsynaptic depolarization to relieve Mg2+ block of NMDA receptors.
Description B: LTP at Schaffer collateral synapses occurs independently of postsynaptic depolarization and Mg2+ block of NMDA receptors.

Description A: NMDA receptor activation produces a rise in intracellular Ca2+, which activates calcium-dependent signaling cascades and protein kinases.
Description B: NMDA receptor activation prevents intracellular Ca2+ accumulation, effectively suppressing calcium-dependent signaling cascades and protein kinases.

Description A: Excitatory synapses in the vertebrate central nervous system typically release glutamate, which acts on ionotropic receptors to produce EPSPs.
Description B: Excitatory synapses in the vertebrate central nervous system typically release GABA, which acts on ionotropic receptors to produce EPSPs.

Description A: Type I synapses in the brain often have round synaptic vesicles and asymmetric appearance due to a prominent postsynaptic density, and are usually excitatory.
Description B: Type I synapses in the brain often have flattened synaptic vesicles and symmetric appearance due to a modest postsynaptic density, and are usually excitatory.

Description A: Synapse formation is a selective process where neurons can choose specific target cells for synaptic connections.
Description B: Synapse formation is a random process where neurons form connections with all nearby target cells indiscriminately.

Description A: The neuromuscular junction has been used as a model system to study synapse formation due to its simplicity.
Description B: The neuromuscular junction has been avoided as a model system for studying synapse formation due to its complexity.

Description A: Laminar specificity refers to the tendency of axons to confine their terminals to specific layers in structured regions like the cerebral cortex.
Description B: Laminar specificity allows axons to freely terminate across all layers in structured regions like the cerebral cortex.

Description A: Neurofascin is an adhesion molecule that directs basket cell axons to form synapses at specific domains of Purkinje neurons.
Description B: Neurofascin directs basket cell axons to form synapses arbitrarily across all domains of Purkinje neurons.

Description A: Neural activity refines synaptic specificity by influencing synapse elimination and sharpening connectivity patterns.
Description B: Neural activity has no role in refining synaptic specificity and does not influence connectivity patterns.

Description A: Olfactory sensory neurons use odorant receptors to match their axons with specific glomeruli in the olfactory bulb.
Description B: Olfactory sensory neurons use odorant receptors to avoid glomeruli in the olfactory bulb and remain unconnected.

Description A: Retinal ganglion cells form a crude retinotopic map on the optic tectum, which is refined by neural activity.
Description B: Retinal ganglion cells form precise retinotopic maps on the optic tectum entirely independent of neural activity.

Description A: Recognition molecules, like Sidekick 2, help interneurons connect with specific ganglion cells in the retina.
Description B: Recognition molecules, like Sidekick 2, prevent interneurons from connecting with any ganglion cells in the retina.

Description A: In skeletal muscle, neural activity can transform muscle fiber properties to match the motor nerve’s pattern.
Description B: Skeletal muscle properties are fixed at birth and cannot be influenced by neural activity or motor nerve patterns.

Description A: Electrical activity in retinal ganglion cells affects the remodeling of axonal arbors to refine their specificity.
Description B: Electrical activity in retinal ganglion cells does not affect the remodeling of axonal arbors or their specificity.

Description A: Aβ field receptors respond to stroking or stretching of the skin in their receptive fields and have the largest receptive fields in hairy skin.
Description B: Aβ field receptors respond to hair movement or air puffs and have the smallest receptive fields in hairy skin.

Description A: The Golgi tendon organ measures the forces generated by muscle contraction but contributes little to conscious sensations of muscle activity.
Description B: The Golgi tendon organ measures the forces generated by muscle contraction and is the primary contributor to conscious sensations of muscle activity.

Description A: TRPA1 receptors bind pungent substances such as horseradish and garlic, which may produce pain or itch through covalent modification of cysteines.
Description B: TRPA1 receptors bind pungent substances such as mint and lemon juice, which may produce pain or itch through covalent modification of cysteines.

Description A: Cold receptors are approximately 100 times more sensitive to sudden drops in skin temperature than to gradual changes.
Description B: Cold receptors are approximately 100 times more sensitive to gradual changes in skin temperature than to sudden drops.

Description A: TRPV1 receptors respond to temperatures exceeding 45°C and mediate sensations of burning pain.
Description B: TRPV1 receptors respond to temperatures below 25°C and mediate sensations of cooling.

Description A: Mechanical nociceptors respond to sharp objects that puncture the skin and can also respond to temperatures above 45°C.
Description B: Mechanical nociceptors respond to blunt objects that apply pressure to the skin and temperatures below 15°C.

Description A: Warm receptors are located in C fiber terminals and act more like simple thermometers.
Description B: Warm receptors are located in Aδ fiber terminals and respond exclusively to sudden temperature changes.

Description A: Capsaicin is the active ingredient in chili peppers, and it activates nociceptive C fiber afferents that mediate sensations of burning pain.
Description B: Capsaicin is the active ingredient in chili peppers, and it activates mechanosensory Aβ fibers that mediate sensations of gentle touch.

Description A: TRPM8 receptors respond to menthol applied to the skin and are activated by temperatures below 25°C.
Description B: TRPM8 receptors respond to warm stimuli above 35°C and are deactivated by menthol applied to the skin.

Description A: Large diameter Aα and Aβ fibers express NaV1.1 and NaV1.6 channels, enabling them to fire action potentials at high rates.
Description B: Large diameter Aα and Aβ fibers express NaV1.9 channels, which prevent them from firing action potentials at high rates.

Description A: The hippocampus plays a key role in encoding spatial maps, with place cells firing at specific locations in an environment.
Description B: The hippocampus plays no role in encoding spatial maps, and place cells are unrelated to specific locations in an environment.

Description A: Place cells in the hippocampus fire only when the animal traverses a specific area, termed the cell's place field.
Description B: Place cells in the hippocampus fire randomly and are not associated with specific areas or place fields in the environment.

Description A: Distinct sets of place cells in the hippocampus are activated by distinct locations, enabling the encoding of unique spatial maps.
