Description B: Distinct sets of place cells in the hippocampus are activated in a uniform manner across all locations, preventing unique spatial map encoding.

Description A: The full population of hippocampal place cells tiles the entire environment, allowing the encoding of any given location.
Description B: The full population of hippocampal place cells covers only small regions of the environment, limiting spatial encoding capabilities.

Description A: Place cells represent relatively small spatial areas but collectively help the hippocampus encode complete spatial maps.
Description B: Place cells in the hippocampus represent large spatial areas individually, removing the need for collective spatial encoding.

Description A: Edward Tolman postulated the existence of cognitive maps, which are supported by hippocampal place cell activity.
Description B: Edward Tolman argued against the existence of cognitive maps, denying the role of hippocampal place cell activity.

Description A: The hippocampus creates spatial maps using ensembles of place cells, each encoding specific areas within the environment.
Description B: The hippocampus creates spatial maps without the use of place cells or any specific neuronal ensembles.

Description A: Place cells are activated in bats, monkeys, humans, and other mammals, demonstrating the hippocampus's universal spatial coding function.
Description B: Place cells are only activated in rodents, excluding bats, monkeys, and humans from hippocampal spatial coding functions.

Description A: Place cells in the hippocampus allow animals to form cognitive maps that enable navigation and memory recall.
Description B: Place cells prevent animals from forming cognitive maps, hindering navigation and memory recall abilities.

Description A: Place cells collectively provide spatial coverage that compensates for occasional noise in individual cell firing.
Description B: Place cells fail to provide collective spatial coverage due to noise in individual cell firing.

Description A: Leptin is secreted by adipocytes in proportion to the amount of fat stores.
Description B: Leptin is secreted by the pancreas in proportion to the amount of fat stores.

Description A: AgRP neurons release γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA), neuropeptide Y (NPY), and AgRP to promote hunger.
Description B: AgRP neurons release insulin, GLP-1, and GABA to promote hunger.

Description A: POMC neurons release α-melanocyte-stimulating hormone (αMSH) to activate melanocortin-4 receptors (MC4R) and promote satiety.
Description B: POMC neurons release ghrelin to activate melanocortin-4 receptors (MC4R) and promote satiety.

Description A: Fasting activates AgRP neurons and inhibits POMC neurons.
Description B: Fasting activates POMC neurons and inhibits AgRP neurons.

Description A: Ghrelin is released from the stomach and promotes eating.
Description B: Ghrelin is released from the pancreas and promotes eating.

Description A: Optogenetic stimulation of AgRP neurons in mice results in extreme hyperphagia even when mice are calorically replete.
Description B: Optogenetic stimulation of POMC neurons in mice results in extreme hyperphagia even when mice are calorically replete.

Description A: MC4R-expressing neurons in the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus (PVH) promote satiety.
Description B: MC4R-expressing neurons in the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus (PVH) promote hunger.

Description A: Leptin reduces food intake and increases energy expenditure.
Description B: Leptin increases food intake and decreases energy expenditure.

Description A: CCK, released by intestinal endocrine cells, plays a key role in satiation.
Description B: CCK, released by the hypothalamus, plays a key role in satiation.

Description A: Environmental cues predicting food can inhibit AgRP neuron activity in fasted mice.
Description B: Environmental cues predicting food can activate POMC neuron activity in fasted mice.

Description A: The C2A domain of synaptotagmin binds three Ca2+ ions and the C2B domain binds two Ca2+ ions.
Description B: The C2A domain of synaptotagmin binds two Ca2+ ions and the C2B domain binds three Ca2+ ions.

Description A: Wild-type mice demonstrate rapid synchronous transmitter release, while mutant mice lacking synaptotagmin-1 only show asynchronous release.
Description B: Wild-type mice demonstrate asynchronous transmitter release, while mutant mice lacking synaptotagmin-1 only show synchronous release.

Description A: Synaptotagmin forms a protein complex that mediates Ca2+-dependent transmitter release and favors vesicle fusion.
Description B: Synaptotagmin inhibits Ca2+-dependent transmitter release and prevents vesicle fusion.

Description A: Synapses with an initially low probability of release undergo facilitation due to Ca2+ buildup during repetitive firing.
Description B: Synapses with an initially high probability of release undergo facilitation due to Ca2+ buildup during repetitive firing.

Description A: RIM proteins tether vesicles to the active zone and recruit Ca2+ channels to the presynaptic terminal.
Description B: RIM proteins inhibit vesicle tethering to the active zone and prevent Ca2+ channel recruitment to the presynaptic terminal.

Description A: The SNARE complex mediates vesicle fusion through interactions with proteins like syntaxin and synaptobrevin.
Description B: The SNARE complex prevents vesicle fusion by inhibiting interactions with proteins such as syntaxin and synaptobrevin.

Description A: Munc13 plays an essential role in priming synaptic vesicles for exocytosis at the active zone.
Description B: Munc13 inhibits the priming of synaptic vesicles for exocytosis at the active zone.

Description A: Posttetanic potentiation can last for minutes or hours after a high-frequency tetanus is terminated.
Description B: Posttetanic potentiation only lasts for a few milliseconds after a high-frequency tetanus is terminated.

Description A: Synaptic vesicles dock along the presynaptic membrane at active zones, ready to fuse.
Description B: Synaptic vesicles randomly drift in the cytoplasm and never dock at active zones.

Description A: Presynaptic inhibition reduces the amplitude of the excitatory postsynaptic potential by lowering Ca2+ influx.
Description B: Presynaptic inhibition increases the amplitude of the excitatory postsynaptic potential by raising Ca2+ influx.

Description A: Synapse elimination at the neuromuscular junction generally occurs after the period of naturally occurring cell death, and involves competitive processes among motor axons.
Description B: Synapse elimination at the neuromuscular junction generally occurs before the period of naturally occurring cell death, and does not involve competitive processes among motor axons.

Description A: Activity plays a significant role in synapse elimination, with increased neural activity enhancing synapse elimination and muscle paralysis reducing it.
Description B: Activity plays no significant role in synapse elimination, as synapse elimination is independent of neural activity or muscle conditions.

Description A: Astrocytes provide signals that promote both presynaptic and postsynaptic maturation in synapse formation.
Description B: Astrocytes play no role in promoting either presynaptic or postsynaptic maturation in synapse formation.

Description A: Microglia use complement components like C1q and C3 to phagocytose synaptic terminals during elimination, with targeting being activity-dependent.
Description B: Microglia eliminate synaptic terminals during pruning but do not rely on complement components or activity-dependent targeting.

Description A: Glial cells, including astrocytes and microglia, contribute to both synapse formation and elimination at different stages of development.
Description B: Glial cells, such as astrocytes and microglia, are only involved in synapse formation, but not in the elimination process.

Description A: At the neuromuscular junction, synaptic elimination ensures that each muscle fiber is innervated by a single motor axon, which strengthens its connection.
Description B: At the neuromuscular junction, synaptic elimination allows each muscle fiber to be innervated by multiple motor axons that maintain equal connections.

Description A: Synaptic connections at the neuromuscular junction are refined through competitive, activity-dependent interactions that strengthen selective synapses.
Description B: Synaptic connections at the neuromuscular junction are refined through entirely random, non-competitive processes irrespective of activity.

Description A: The mechanism of synaptic pruning by microglia may play a role in some neurodegenerative diseases, such as Alzheimer disease and schizophrenia.
Description B: The mechanism of synaptic pruning by microglia has no implications for neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer disease or schizophrenia.

Description A: Neurons form significantly fewer synapses when cultured in isolation but form many synapses in the presence of astrocytes.
Description B: Neurons form the same number of synapses when cultured in isolation as they do in the presence of astrocytes.

Description A: The trophic competition hypothesis suggests that muscles produce limited trophic substances, which more active axons can take up more effectively than less active axons.
Description B: The trophic competition hypothesis suggests that muscles produce abundant trophic substances that all axons take up equally, regardless of activity.

Description A: VMAT1 is primarily expressed in peripheral cells, while VMAT2 is mainly expressed in the central nervous system.
Description B: VMAT1 is primarily expressed in the central nervous system, while VMAT2 is mainly expressed in peripheral cells.

Description A: Glutamate is converted to GABA by the enzyme glutamic acid decarboxylase.
Description B: Glutamate is converted to glycine by the enzyme glutamic acid decarboxylase.

Description A: Glycine serves as the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the spinal cord.
Description B: Glycine serves as the major excitatory neurotransmitter in the spinal cord.

Description A: ATP acts as a transmitter by binding to G-protein-coupled P1 and P2Y receptors.
Description B: ATP acts as a transmitter by binding exclusively to ionotropic NMDA receptors.

Description A: The vesicular monoamine transporter (VMAT2) can transport a wide range of biogenic amines.
Description B: The vesicular monoamine transporter (VMAT2) exclusively transports dopamine and serotonin.

Description A: The enzyme glutamine synthase converts glutamate to glutamine inside astrocytes.
Description B: The enzyme glutamine synthase converts glutamate to glycine inside astrocytes.

Description A: Dense-core vesicles release their contents slower compared to small synaptic vesicles due to their dependence on high stimulation frequencies.
Description B: Dense-core vesicles release their contents rapidly compared to small synaptic vesicles due to their dependence on low stimulation frequencies.

Description A: Acetylcholinesterase hydrolyzes acetylcholine into choline and acetate within the synaptic cleft, ensuring termination of the synaptic signal.
Description B: Acetylcholinesterase hydrolyzes acetylcholine into glutamate and acetate within the synaptic cleft, ensuring termination of the synaptic signal.

Description A: Synaptic vesicles can accumulate neurotransmitters like dopamine and glutamate through specific transport mechanisms.
Description B: Synaptic vesicles can accumulate neurotransmitters like dopamine and glycine through specific transport mechanisms.

Description A: Neuropeptides are formed in the cell body and transported to axonal terminals in large dense-core vesicles.
Description B: Neuropeptides are formed at axonal terminals and locally synthesized within small synaptic vesicles.

Description A: The sex-determining activity of the Y chromosome is encoded primarily by the SRY gene, which plays a crucial role in masculinizing embryonic gonads.
Description B: The sex-determining activity of the X chromosome is encoded primarily by the SRY gene, which plays a crucial role in masculinizing embryonic gonads.

Description A: Testosterone can be converted into estrogen by the enzyme aromatase, which is expressed in specific regions of the brain.
Description B: Testosterone can be converted into progesterone by the enzyme aromatase, which is expressed in specific regions of the brain.

Description A: Females with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) may experience virilization due to excess androgen production, a condition that can often be treated with corticosteroids.
Description B: Females with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) may experience feminization due to a lack of androgen production, a condition that can often be treated with corticosteroids.

Description A: The Wolffian duct differentiates into male structures such as the vas deferens and seminal vesicles, under the influence of testosterone.
Description B: The Wolffian duct differentiates into female structures such as the oviduct and uterus, under the influence of testosterone.

Description A: Estrogen and testosterone are derived from cholesterol, and testosterone can serve as a precursor to estrogen within the body.
Description B: Estrogen and testosterone are derived from cholesterol, and estrogen can serve as a precursor to testosterone within the body.

Description A: The Müllerian duct develops into female structures such as the oviduct, uterus, and upper vagina in the absence of Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS).
Description B: The Müllerian duct develops into male structures such as the seminal vesicles and vas deferens in the absence of Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS).

Description A: In androgen insensitivity syndrome, individuals are chromosomally male (XY) but develop feminized external genitalia due to a loss of function in the androgen receptor.
Description B: In androgen insensitivity syndrome, individuals are chromosomally female (XX) but develop masculinized external genitalia due to a loss of function in the androgen receptor.

Description A: The robust nucleus of the archistriatum (RA) in male zebra finches contains more neurons than in the same nucleus in females, a difference influenced by steroid hormones.
Description B: The robust nucleus of the archistriatum (RA) in female zebra finches contains more neurons than in the same nucleus in males, a difference influenced by steroid hormones.

Description A: SRY is a gene located on the Y chromosome that determines male differentiation by initiating a cascade leading to testis development.
Description B: SRY is a gene located on the X chromosome that determines male differentiation by initiating a cascade leading to testis development.

Description A: The spinal nucleus of the bulbocavernosus (SNB) plays a key role in penile reflexes in males and contains more neurons compared to females.
Description B: The spinal nucleus of the bulbocavernosus (SNB) plays a key role in vaginal reflexes in males and contains fewer neurons compared to females.

Description A: Plato's 'Allegory of the Cave' describes prisoners whose experience is limited to shadows cast upon the wall of the cave, representing fleeting and incoherent sensations.
Description B: Plato's 'Allegory of the Cave' describes prisoners whose experience includes direct observation of the fire and the objects casting shadows, representing clear and coherent perceptions.

Description A: Modern neuroscience is metaphorically represented by the freed prisoner in Plato's Cave, shedding light on the relationship between shadowy sensations and rich perceptual experiences.
Description B: Modern neuroscience is metaphorically represented by the prisoners still shackled in Plato's Cave, unable to interpret the relationship between shadowy sensations and perceptual experiences.

Description A: Vision as a sensory modality acquires information through properties of light reflected from objects, which is transduced into neuronal signals by photoreceptors.
Description B: Vision as a sensory modality acquires information through sound waves, which are transduced into neuronal signals by photoreceptors.

Description A: Auditory system detects compressions and rarefactions of air caused by sounds, converting mechanical energy into neuronal signals through hair cells.
Description B: Auditory system detects compressions and rarefactions of atmospheric pressure, converting chemical energy into neuronal signals through photoreceptors.

Description A: Taste and smell acquire information about the chemical composition of the world, utilizing hundreds of unique olfactory receptors for airborne molecules.
Description B: Taste and smell acquire information about the gravitational properties of the world, utilizing hundreds of unique olfactory receptors for airborne molecules.

Description A: Sensory receptors transform specific types of stimulus energy into electrical signals, enabling neural activity to represent sensory information.
Description B: Sensory receptors directly produce logical interpretations of stimuli without transforming energy into electrical signals.

Description A: Perception allows humans to generalize across different sensory manifestations of similar objects, creating perceptual constancies like recognizing faces.
Description B: Perception limits humans to specific sensory manifestations of objects, preventing generalization like recognizing faces from different angles.

Description A: Perception, as examined in neuroscience, links sensory signals within and between modalities to feedback from memory stores.
Description B: Perception, as examined in neuroscience, isolates sensory signals from memory stores and prevents cross-modal linking.

Description A: The somatosensory system detects physical stimuli like pressure, vibration, and temperature, converting them into neuronal signals via specialized detectors.
Description B: The somatosensory system detects magnetic stimuli like polarity and strength, converting them into neuronal signals via specialized detectors.

Description A: Sensory systems operate as selective filters, highlighting important forms of information while restricting others based on context and goals.
Description B: Sensory systems provide unrestricted information about all environmental stimuli, regardless of context and goals.

Description A: Pierre Paul Broca discovered that damage to the posterior portion of the left frontal lobe produces a specific deficit in language.
Description B: Pierre Paul Broca discovered that damage to the anterior portion of the left frontal lobe produces a specific deficit in language.

Description A: Short-term memory maintains transient representations of information relevant to immediate goals.
Description B: Short-term memory maintains durable and persistent representations of information relevant to lifelong goals.

Description A: The verbal subsystem of working memory consists of phonological storage and a rehearsal mechanism.
Description B: The verbal subsystem of working memory consists of visuospatial storage and a rehearsal mechanism.

Description A: Phonological storage depends on posterior parietal cortices.
Description B: Phonological storage depends on the occipital cortices.

Description A: The visuospatial subsystem of working memory retains mental images of visual objects and of the location of objects in space.
Description B: The visuospatial subsystem of working memory retains auditory information and the meaning of words in language context.

Description A: Executive control processes allocate attentional resources and update stored representations in working memory.
Description B: Executive control processes store speech-based and visuospatial information permanently.

Description A: The rehearsal of spatial and object information in working memory involves modulation of information by parietal, inferior temporal, and occipital cortices.
Description B: The rehearsal of spatial and object information in working memory is solely dependent on midbrain structures.

Description A: Working memory of spatial knowledge tends to involve neurons in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.
Description B: Working memory of spatial knowledge tends to involve neurons in the ventrolateral prefrontal cortex.

Description A: Prefrontal control signals in working memory are dependent on interaction with the striatum and ascending dopaminergic inputs from the midbrain.
Description B: Prefrontal control signals in working memory are independent of dopaminergic inputs from the midbrain.

Description A: Single-cell recordings in nonhuman primates indicate that specific neurons maintain spatial and object representations over a period of seconds.
Description B: Single-cell recordings in nonhuman primates indicate that neurons maintain durable representations that persist indefinitely.

Description A: Tau proteins form paired helical filaments in Alzheimer disease, which accumulate to create neurofibrillary tangles in neuronal cell bodies, dendrites, and axons.
Description B: Tau proteins form linear filaments in Alzheimer disease, which accumulate to create neurofibrillary tangles only in neuronal cell bodies.

Description A: Microtubules are composed of 13 protofilaments, each made up of alternating α- and β-tubulin subunits.
Description B: Microtubules are composed of 13 protofilaments, each made up solely of α-tubulin subunits.

Description A: In Parkinson disease, α-synuclein aggregates in spherical formations called Lewy bodies.
Description B: In Parkinson disease, α-synuclein aggregates in irregular linear formations in the cytoplasm.

Description A: Microfilaments are composed of polymerized actin monomers arranged in a helix and are polar structures due to the asymmetry of globular actin monomers.
Description B: Microfilaments are composed of polymerized actin monomers arranged in straight chains and are non-polar due to the symmetry of globular actin monomers.

Description A: Fast axonal transport moves organelles at rates up to 400 mm per day in warm-blooded animals.
Description B: Fast axonal transport moves organelles at rates up to 4 mm per day in warm-blooded animals.

Description A: Abnormal tau protein in Alzheimer disease interferes with tubulin polymerization and disrupts axonal transport.
Description B: Abnormal tau protein in Alzheimer disease enhances tubulin polymerization and strengthens axonal transport.

Description A: β-amyloid originates from the amyloid precursor protein, which is processed by β-secretase in Alzheimer's disease.
Description B: β-amyloid originates from tau protein, which is processed by proteasomes in Alzheimer's disease.

Description A: Microtubules in axons are arranged with plus ends pointing away from the cell body and minus ends facing the cell body.
Description B: Microtubules in axons are arranged with minus ends pointing away from the cell body and plus ends facing the cell body.

Description A: Fast retrograde axonal transport moves endosomes, mitochondria, and endoplasmic reticulum components back to the cell body.
Description B: Fast retrograde axonal transport moves neurotransmitters and secretory vesicles back to the cell body.

Description A: Slow axonal transport carries cytosolic and cytoskeletal proteins only in the anterograde direction.
Description B: Slow axonal transport carries cytosolic and cytoskeletal proteins in both anterograde and retrograde directions.

Description A: The human brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons, each arranged into anatomical circuits that determine the complexity of behavior.
Description B: The human brain contains roughly 8 billion neurons, and their arrangement into anatomical circuits is not crucial for behavior complexity.

Description A: Multipolar neurons typically have a single axon and many dendrites emerging from various points around the cell body.
Description B: Multipolar neurons typically have multiple axons and only a single dendrite emerging from the cell body.

Description A: Unipolar neurons are common in the nervous systems of invertebrates, while in vertebrates they occur in the autonomic nervous system.
Description B: Unipolar neurons are common in the nervous systems of vertebrates, while invertebrates rarely have such neurons.

Description A: Nerve cells are classified based on the number of processes as unipolar, bipolar, or multipolar.
Description B: Nerve cells are classified based solely on their functional roles, not on the number of processes they possess.

Description A: Sensory neurons carry information from the body's peripheral sensors to the central nervous system.
Description B: Sensory neurons carry information from the central nervous system to the body's peripheral sensors.

Description A: The myelin sheath increases the speed of action potential conduction by insulating axons.
Description B: The myelin sheath slows down the conduction of action potentials due to its insulating properties.

Description A: In pseudo-unipolar cells, two processes emerge from the cell body but fuse into a single continuous structure during development.
Description B: In pseudo-unipolar cells, two processes from the cell body remain distinct throughout the organism's development.

Description A: The principles of dynamic polarization and connectional specificity explain the direction and specificity of neuron connections.
Description B: The principles of dynamic polarization and connectional specificity do not concern the direction and specificity of neuron connections.

Description A: Action potentials maintain a constant amplitude of 100 mV as they propagate along the axon.
Description B: Action potentials decrease in amplitude as they propagate along the axon.

Description A: The neuron doctrine holds that each neuron is a discrete cell with distinctive processes and serves as a signaling unit in the nervous system.
Description B: The neuron doctrine states that neurons form a continuous, web-like reticulum with no discrete boundaries or individual signaling units.

Description A: SA1 fibers are sensitive to small objects that indent the skin as they focus more force at a single contact point.
Description B: SA1 fibers are highly responsive to large objects because they contact a broader area of the skin.

Description A: RA2 fibers are particularly sensitive to high-frequency vibrations, allowing them to detect vibrations in the range of 30-500 Hz.
Description B: RA2 fibers are most sensitive to low-frequency vibrations under 10 Hz.

Description A: The RA1 fibers detect how quickly a grasp is applied during object handling.
Description B: The RA1 fibers signal the amount of grip force applied by each finger during object handling.

Description A: SA2 fibers respond primarily to skin stretch and provide information about hand posture and finger movements.
Description B: SA2 fibers respond primarily to skin indentation and provide detailed information about object texture.

Description A: RA2 fibers, also known as Pacinian corpuscles, have low thresholds for vibrations above 50 Hz.
Description B: RA2 fibers, also known as Pacinian corpuscles, have low thresholds for vibrations below 5 Hz.

Description A: The primary role of SA1 fibers is to signal edges, corners, and small points with high sensitivity.
Description B: The primary role of SA1 fibers is to detect vibrations and motion over flat surfaces.

Description A: SA2 fibers help detect hand shape and finger joint movements through skin stretch over the knuckles.

Description A: Conscious awareness of touch originates in the primary somatosensory cortex in the parietal lobe.
Description B: Conscious awareness of touch originates in the brain stem rather than the somatosensory cortex.

Description A: SA1 fibers fire spike trains that replicate the spatial arrangement of Braille dots.
Description B: SA1 fibers fire spike trains that blur the spatial arrangement of Braille dots.

Description B: The Ruffini endings associated with SA2 fibers are aligned to sense fine textures on the surface of skin.

Description A: High-level visual processing integrates information from various sources and is the final stage in the visual pathway for visual perception.
Description B: High-level visual processing occurs independently of information from short-term working memory or long-term memory.

Description A: The inferior temporal cortex is part of a network involved in object recognition and includes connections to the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex.
Description B: The inferior temporal cortex only processes simple visual attributes such as color and orientation.

Description A: Object recognition relies on perceptual constancy, which allows recognition of objects despite changes in lighting, angle, position, or size.
Description B: Object recognition is hindered by any change in lighting, angle, position, or size due to the limitations of perceptual constancy.

Description B: Neurons in the temporal lobe function identically and are not involved in specific processes like facial recognition.

Description A: The notion of categorical perception allows the visual system to generalize objects within the same category.

Description B: Viewpoint invariance prevents neurons in the anterior inferior temporal cortex from recognizing objects at varying angles.

Description B: Prosopagnosia results in the inability to perceive faces entirely, including their features and emotional expressions.

Description B: Experimental lesions in the inferior temporal cortex eliminate all sensitivity to basic visual components such as motion and color.

Description B: The thalamus is only a passive relay station and simply relays somatosensory information directly to the motor cortex without processing.

Description B: Layer IV of the neocortex is least prominent in sensory areas and does not receive sensory input from the thalamus.

Description B: The neurons in Layer V of the primary motor cortex are exclusively involved in sensory input processing and do not contribute to cortical output pathways.

Description A: In the cortex, feedforward projections originate mainly in layer III and terminate in layer IV of target cortical areas.
Description B: Feedforward projections originate from deeper layers (V and VI) and terminate in the outermost layers (I and II).

Description A: Neurons within each cortical column generally have similar response properties and collectively form a local processing network.
Description B: Neurons within each cortical column have highly varied response properties and do not form localized networks.

Description A: The cortical areas involved in early sensory processing are primarily concerned with individual sensory modalities and are known as unimodal sensory association areas.
Description B: The cortical areas involved in early sensory processing combine information from multiple sensory modalities and are known as multimodal sensory association areas.

Description A: Modulatory systems in the brain stem, such as the locus coeruleus, influence attention and arousal by releasing norepinephrine.
Description B: Modulatory systems in the brain stem, such as the locus coeruleus, influence attention and arousal by releasing dopamine.

Description A: The human corticospinal tract primarily originates in the motor cortex, with approximately 40% of its axons deriving from this region.
Description B: The human corticospinal tract primarily originates in the sensory areas of the brain, with approximately 40% of its axons deriving from these regions.

Description A: Sensory information from the peripheral nervous system includes somatic inputs from the skin, muscles, and joints.
Description B: Sensory information from the peripheral nervous system includes somatic inputs exclusively from internal organs and the gut.

Description A: Sign language processing localizes primarily to the left hemisphere, similar to spoken language processing.
Description B: Sign language processing localizes to the right hemisphere, contrasting spoken language processing which localizes to the left hemisphere.

Description A: In the Minnesota Twin Study, identical twins raised apart often exhibited similar personality traits like extraversion due to genetic influences.
Description B: In the Minnesota Twin Study, identical twins raised apart exhibited entirely different personality traits, implying genetic factors have no influence on behavior.

Description A: Damage to Broca’s area in the left hemisphere affects language fluency in both spoken and sign languages.
Description B: Damage to Broca’s area in the left hemisphere has no impact on language fluency in sign language.

Description A: Auditory input is not necessary for the emergence and operation of language capabilities in the left hemisphere.
Description B: Auditory input is essential for the emergence and operation of language capabilities in the left hemisphere.

Description A: The dorsal visual stream is often referred to as the 'how' pathway as it constructs a state of knowing about spatial properties of objects.
Description B: The dorsal visual stream, also referred to as the 'what' pathway, is responsible primarily for identifying objects’ social desirability.

Description A: Psychiatric disorders often involve multigenic traits where multiple genes contribute to disease susceptibility.
Description B: Psychiatric disorders are solely determined by environmental factors, with no contribution from genetic traits.

Description A: Twin studies provide evidence that heritability for psychiatric disorders is generally lower than 100%, highlighting the role of environmental factors.
Description B: Twin studies suggest psychiatric disorders have 100% heritability due to exclusively genetic factors.

Description A: Modular functional organization of the brain indicates that mental functions involve interconnected pathways across multiple brain regions.
Description B: Modular functional organization of the brain suggests mental functions are mediated strictly by independent single brain regions.

Description A: The corpus callosum connects the two cerebral hemispheres and enables shared consciousness between them.
Description B: The corpus callosum, when severed, prevents the two cerebral hemispheres from functioning independently.

Description A: Genes do not directly control behavior but influence brain function through RNAs and proteins encoded by genes.
Description B: Genes directly control behavior without requiring any mediation by RNAs or proteins encoded by them.

Description A: Axonal specification is a key event in neuronal polarization, involving cytoskeletal reorganization driven by destabilized actin filaments.
Description B: Axonal specification occurs late in neuronal development, independent of cytoskeletal reorganization or actin filament destabilization.

Description A: The Tau protein is localized in axons, while the MAP2 protein is located in dendrites, contributing to their distinctive molecular profiles.
Description B: The Tau protein is exclusive to dendrites, while the MAP2 protein is predominantly found in axons, forming their molecular profiles.

Description A: In tissue culture, hippocampal neurons develop processes in a stereotyped sequence, with one becoming an axon and others forming dendrites.
Description B: In tissue culture, hippocampal neurons develop multiple axons simultaneously, and dendritic formation occurs at a later stage.

Description A: Cultured neurons lack extrinsic signals, making their polarity dependent primarily on intrinsic mechanisms and environmental variations within the culture.
Description B: Cultured neurons rely exclusively on extrinsic signals to form polarized structures, which cannot develop in random environments.

Description A: Semaphorin-3A attracts dendrites near the pial surface, aiding orientation and polarity in cortical pyramidal neurons.
Description B: Semaphorin-3A repels dendrites near the pial surface, disrupting polarity in cortical pyramidal neurons.

Description A: Growth cones are responsible for axonal pathfinding, guided by both environmental sensory signals and motor-driven elongation.
Description B: Growth cones play no role in axonal pathfinding, relying entirely on passive elongation through cytoskeletal dynamics.

Description A: Filopodia in growth cones contain actin-rich structures that sample directional cues and navigate obstacles.
Description B: Filopodia in growth cones are microtubule-rich structures that passively respond to environmental obstacles.

Description A: Calcium concentration gradients within growth cones influence directional growth and motility.
Description B: Calcium concentration gradients within growth cones impede motility and disrupt directional growth.

Description A: Inhibition of protein synthesis disrupts growth cone advancement and responsiveness to environmental signals.
Description B: Protein synthesis plays no role in growth cone advancement or responsiveness to environmental signals.

Description A: Tiling ensures dendrites cover a surface with minimal overlap, optimizing information reception.
Description B: Tiling increases dendritic overlap, reducing efficiency in information reception.

Description A: The lateral nucleus of the amygdala is thought to be a site of synaptic change during fear conditioning.
Description B: The central nucleus of the amygdala is thought to be a site of synaptic change during fear conditioning.

Description A: The medial amygdala processes unconditioned signals of predator odors, unlike visual threats processed by the lateral amygdala.
Description B: The lateral amygdala processes unconditioned signals of predator odors, unlike auditory threats processed by the medial amygdala.

Description A: Patients with bilateral amygdala lesions fail to show autonomic fear reactions to external stimuli but can experience panic with interoceptive cues.
Description B: Patients with bilateral amygdala lesions show autonomic fear reactions to external stimuli but fail to experience panic with interoceptive cues.

Description A: The ventromedial prefrontal cortex is activated during the anticipation of emotion-linked punishment or rewards.
Description B: The dorsolateral prefrontal cortex is activated during the anticipation of emotion-linked punishment or rewards.

Description A: Damage to the right somatosensory cortex impairs the ability to guess social feelings based on facial expressions.
Description B: Damage to the left somatosensory cortex impairs the ability to guess social feelings based on facial expressions.

Description A: The anterior cingulate cortex (area 25) is activated during experiences of sadness in neuroimaging studies.
Description B: The anterior cingulate cortex (area 12) is activated during experiences of sadness in neuroimaging studies.

Description A: Patients with pure autonomic failure exhibit blunted emotional responses and reduced activity in somatosensory brain areas.
Description B: Patients with pure autonomic failure exhibit heightened emotional responses and increased activity in somatosensory brain areas.

Description A: The mouse superior colliculus helps detect aerial predators like hawks.
Description B: The mouse amygdala helps detect aerial predators like hawks.

Description A: Humans can be conditioned to fear simply by observing someone else being conditioned.
Description B: Humans cannot be conditioned to fear by observing someone else being conditioned.

Description A: Emotionally relevant stimuli influence declarative memory consolidation through amygdala-hippocampal projections.
Description B: Emotionally relevant stimuli influence decision-making through amygdala-hippocampal projections.

Description A: Attention is the ability of the brain to select objects in the world for further analysis.
Description B: Attention is the ability of the brain to suppress objects in the world for further analysis.

Description A: Patients with lesions in the parietal cortex cannot adjust their grip width or wrist angle using visual information alone.
Description B: Patients with lesions in the parietal cortex can adjust their grip width and wrist angle independently of visual information.

Description A: Neurons in the medial intraparietal area describe the targets for reaching movements.
Description B: Neurons in the medial intraparietal area describe the targets for grasping movements.

Description A: Neurons in the ventral intraparietal area respond to objects coming toward the mouth.
Description B: Neurons in the ventral intraparietal area respond to objects moving away from the mouth.

Description A: Lesions in the right parietal lobe cause neglect of the contralateral visual world.
Description B: Lesions in the left parietal lobe cause neglect of the ipsilateral visual world.

Description A: Visual information provided by the parietal cortex enables the motor system to adjust hand grip to match the size of the object before it lands on the target.
Description B: Visual information provided by the parietal cortex is irrelevant to adjusting hand grip for object size.

Description A: Corollary discharge precedes the change in eye position and proprioception follows it.
Description B: Proprioception precedes the change in eye position and corollary discharge follows it.

Description A: There are at least four different visual maps in the intraparietal sulcus, each corresponding to a particular motor workspace.
Description B: There is only one unified visual map in the intraparietal sulcus corresponding to all motor workspaces.

Description A: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area respond to targets for grasping even in total darkness.
Description B: Neurons in the anterior intraparietal area only respond to targets for grasping under bright light conditions.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area can discharge before eye movements.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area discharge only after eye movements are completed.

Description A: Bipolar disorder has a prevalence of approximately 1% worldwide, with relatively constant symptoms across countries and cultures.
Description B: Bipolar disorder has a prevalence of approximately 10% worldwide, with symptoms varying significantly across countries and cultures.

Description A: Major depressive episodes are characterized by negative mood states such as sadness, anxiety, or irritability lasting most of the day, nearly every day.
Description B: Major depressive episodes are characterized by positive mood states such as euphoria, creativity, or optimism lasting most of the day, nearly every day.

Description A: A diagnosis of bipolar disorder requires at least one episode of mania, which is characterized by elevated or irritable mood and increased energy.
Description B: A diagnosis of bipolar disorder requires at least two episodes of hypomania without any history of mania.

Description A: The lifetime risk of major depressive disorder in the United States is approximately 19%.
Description B: The lifetime risk of major depressive disorder in the United States is approximately 50%.

Description A: Anxiety disorders are the most common psychiatric disorders worldwide, affecting 28.5% of the U.S. population in their lifetimes.
Description B: Anxiety disorders are the least common psychiatric disorders worldwide, affecting less than 5% of the U.S. population in their lifetimes.

Description A: Manic episodes can include impulsive behaviors such as excessive spending, drug use, or sexual indiscretions.
Description B: Manic episodes rarely include impulsive behaviors and primarily involve excessive sleep and inactivity.

Description A: In bipolar disorder, depressive episodes are often harder to treat and less responsive to antidepressant medications compared to unipolar depression.
Description B: In bipolar disorder, depressive episodes are generally easier to treat and more responsive to antidepressant medications compared to unipolar depression.

Description A: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is highly effective against depression, particularly for severe cases.
Description B: Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is rarely used and is considered ineffective against depression in severe cases.

Description A: Anxiety disorders are associated with a dysregulation of fear circuitry, involving regions like the amygdala and prefrontal cortex.
Description B: Anxiety disorders are unrelated to fear circuitry and involve peripheral body systems exclusively.

Description A: Approximately 70%-80% heritability is linked to bipolar disorder, making it the mood disorder with the highest genetic influence.
Description B: Approximately 10%-20% heritability is linked to bipolar disorder, indicating minimal genetic influence compared to environmental factors.

Description A: Sexual dimorphisms in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST) correlate with gender identity, showing fewer neurons in male-to-female transsexuals compared to men.
Description B: Sexual dimorphisms in the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis (BNST) correlate with gender identity, showing more neurons in male-to-female transsexuals compared to men.

Description A: Testosterone acts directly via its cognate hormone receptor to masculinize the neural substrates of behavior in humans and other primates.
Description B: Testosterone does not act via its cognate hormone receptor but only through conversion to estrogen to masculinize the neural substrates of behavior in humans and other primates.

Description A: The INAH3 nucleus in the anterior hypothalamus is significantly larger in men compared to women.
Description B: The INAH3 nucleus in the anterior hypothalamus is significantly larger in women compared to men.

Description A: Masculinization of the mouse brain during development is largely driven by the conversion of testosterone into estrogen.
Description B: Masculinization of the mouse brain during development is driven solely by testosterone without conversion to estrogen.

Description A: Sex hormones regulate sexually dimorphic behaviors through modular control by distributing specific behaviors across different neuronal populations.
Description B: Sex hormones regulate sexually dimorphic behaviors through a single central neuronal population responsible for all behaviors.

Description A: The sexually dimorphic molecular or anatomical features in key neurons represent the basis for male- or female-typical behaviors.
Description B: The sexually dimorphic molecular or anatomical features in neurons do not influence male- or female-typical behaviors.

Description A: During development, the absence of sex hormones in females enables differentiation of the nervous system along a female-typical pathway.
Description B: During development, the absence of sex hormones prevents differentiation of the nervous system along a female-typical pathway.

Description A: The fronto-orbital cortex and lingual gyri are significantly larger in adult women compared to men.
Description B: The fronto-orbital cortex and lingual gyri are significantly larger in adult men compared to women.

Description A: Children raised in orphanages with little individual care tend to exhibit long-lasting defects in social behaviors and lower oxytocin levels.
Description B: Children raised in orphanages with little individual care tend to exhibit enhanced social behaviors with higher oxytocin levels.

Description A: Neurons in the ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH) regulate mating and aggression in both sexes.
Description B: Neurons in the ventromedial hypothalamus (VMH) are only involved in feeding behaviors and not in mating or aggression.

Description A: Touch perception involves distinct groups of mechanoreceptors which help in reading Braille, identifying objects, and manipulating them efficiently.
Description B: Mechanoreceptors are designed only for sensing vibration and temperature, not for reading Braille or identifying objects.

Description A: Meissner corpuscles and Merkel cells are located in the superficial layers of the skin and contribute to tactile sensitivity.
Description B: Meissner corpuscles and Merkel cells are located in deep layers of the skin and are insensitive to tactile interactions.

Description A: Pacinian corpuscles specialize in detecting high-frequency vibrations and play a significant role in tool use.
Description B: Pacinian corpuscles specialize in detecting low-frequency vibrations and are unrelated to tool use.

Description A: Active touch involves goal-directed movements where users manipulate objects to gather specific information.
Description B: Active touch does not require user interaction; all sensory input comes from external forces on passive receptors.

Description A: Receptive fields in the fingertips are smaller than those in the palm, allowing for greater tactile acuity.
Description B: Receptive fields in the palms are smaller than those in the fingertips, providing the highest tactile acuity in palms.

Description A: The smallest receptive fields of type 1 fibers allow for detailed spatial perception of textures on surfaces.
Description B: Large receptive fields of type 1 fibers are specialized for detecting surface texture in detailed spatial acuity.

Description A: The Ruffini endings and their SA2 fibers detect the stretch of skin and are crucial for understanding hand shapes in three-dimensional tasks.
Description B: Ruffini endings are insensitive to skin stretch and irrelevant to three-dimensional object recognition.

Description A: Blind individuals use SA1 and RA1 fibers for reading Braille, enhancing the understanding of dot-based patterns through touch.
Description B: Reading Braille relies exclusively on Pacinian corpuscles as they detect all surface deformations and patterns.

Description A: Rapidly adapting (RA) fibers respond primarily to motion and stop firing once the stimulus becomes constant.
Description B: Rapidly adapting (RA) fibers respond to both steady and motion-related stimuli continuously without pause.

Description A: The tactile acuity threshold on the human fingertip measures approximately 1 mm in young adults but increases with age.
Description B: The tactile acuity threshold on the human fingertip always measures 1 mm regardless of age or other factors.

Description A: Slow-contracting motor units contain type I muscle fibers, and fast-contracting units include type II fibers.
Description B: Slow-contracting motor units contain type II muscle fibers, and fast-contracting units include type I fibers.

Description A: Endurance training may increase enzyme activities of oxidative metabolic pathways without notable changes in the proportions of type I and type II fibers.
Description B: Endurance training increases the cross-sectional area of type I and type II fibers but decreases enzyme activities of oxidative metabolic pathways.

Description A: The size principle states that contraction force is increased by recruiting the smallest motor neuron first and the largest motor neuron last.
Description B: The size principle states that contraction force is increased by recruiting the largest motor neuron first and the smallest motor neuron last.

Description A: Changes in physical activity affect the contractile properties but have little influence on the proportion of type I muscle fibers in a muscle.
Description B: Changes in physical activity strongly influence the proportion of type I muscle fibers in a muscle.

Description A: Recruitment of motor units begins with slower, low-force units and progresses to faster, high-force units.
Description B: Recruitment of motor units begins with faster, high-force units and progresses to slower, low-force units.

Description A: Space flight reduces the proportion of type I fibers in some leg muscles due to decreased gravity.
Description B: Space flight increases the proportion of type I fibers in leg muscles due to sustained microgravity exposure.

Description A: The sliding filament hypothesis suggests that thick and thin filaments slide relative to one another during contractions.
Description B: The sliding filament hypothesis suggests that thick and thin filaments remain stationary during contractions.

Description A: Ca2+ levels regulate the interaction between thick and thin filaments in the sarcomere.
Description B: Ca2+ has no role in regulating the interaction between thick and thin filaments in the sarcomere.

Description A: Strength training increases the cross-sectional area of type II fibers by 20% to 60%.
Description B: Strength training decreases the cross-sectional area of type II fibers by 20% to 60%.

Description A: Muscle force depends on the arrangement of fibers and the activity of motor neurons.
Description B: Muscle force depends solely on motor neuron activity, ignoring fiber arrangements.

Description A: The vestibular labyrinth in the inner ear contains five receptor organs: two otolith organs (the utricle and saccule) and three semicircular canals.
Description B: The vestibular labyrinth in the inner ear contains six receptor organs: two otolith organs and four semicircular canals.

Description A: The semicircular canals sense angular accelerations, such as head rotations and tilts.
Description B: The semicircular canals sense linear accelerations, such as walking and vertical motion.

Description A: The utricle and saccule detect linear motion and static orientation relative to gravity.
Description B: The utricle and saccule detect rotational motion but not static orientation relative to gravity.

Description A: Endolymph is a K+-rich fluid found within the membranous labyrinth, while perilymph is a high-Na+ fluid found between the membranous and bony labyrinths.
Description B: Endolymph is a Na+-rich fluid found within the membranous labyrinth, while perilymph is a K+-rich fluid found between the membranous and bony labyrinths.

Description A: Hair cells are mechanoreceptors that deflect stereocilia to produce receptor potentials based on the direction of motion.
Description B: Hair cells are mechanoreceptors that produce receptor potentials independent of the direction of motion.

Description A: The afferent fibers of the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII) carry vestibular signals to the brain stem and terminate in ipsilateral vestibular nuclei.
Description B: The afferent fibers of the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII) carry vestibular signals to the spinal cord and terminate in contralateral spinal nuclei.

Description A: The superior vestibular nerve innervates the horizontal and anterior canals and the utricle.
Description B: The superior vestibular nerve innervates the posterior canal and the saccule.

Description A: Otolithic membranes contain thousands of calcium carbonate particles called otoconia.
Description B: Otolithic membranes contain thousands of potassium carbonate particles called otoconia.

Description A: Head movements cause stereocilia to deflect toward the kinocilium, leading to depolarization of hair cells.
Description B: Head movements cause stereocilia to deflect away from the kinocilium, leading to depolarization of hair cells.

Description A: Vestibular nuclei integrate signals from the vestibular organs, spinal cord, cerebellum, and visual system.
Description B: Vestibular nuclei only integrate signals from the vestibular organs and spinal cord.

Description A: People with sleep apnea often experience brief awakenings due to airway obstructions during sleep.
Description B: People with sleep apnea experience deeper sleep due to improved airway patency during sleep.

Description A: Narcolepsy is caused by the selective loss of more than 90% of orexinergic neurons in the hypothalamus.
Description B: Narcolepsy is caused by excessive activation of orexinergic neurons in the hypothalamus.

Description A: During REM sleep, the body is essentially paralyzed, preventing movement while experiencing vivid dreams.
Description B: During REM sleep, muscle tone is increased, allowing movement while experiencing vivid dreams.

Description A: Sleep needs change throughout development, with newborns requiring up to 16 hours of sleep per day.
Description B: Sleep needs change throughout development, with newborns requiring less than 8 hours of sleep per day.

Description A: REM sleep behavior disorder can be an early sign of Parkinson disease or Lewy body dementia.
Description B: REM sleep behavior disorder usually indicates advanced immune disorders rather than neurodegenerative conditions.

Description A: Obstructive sleep apnea can impair cognition and lead to chronic sleep fragmentation.
Description B: Obstructive sleep apnea improves cognition due to compensatory respiratory efforts during sleep.

Description A: Restless legs syndrome often occurs in the evening and first half of the night, disrupting sleep.
Description B: Restless legs syndrome mostly occurs during the early morning hours and improves sleep quality.

Description A: Treating fragmented sleep may potentially improve cognition in Alzheimer patients.
Description B: Fragmented sleep improves cognition in Alzheimer patients due to increased synaptic activity.

Description A: The ventrolateral preoptic nucleus plays a key role in initiating sleep by inhibiting the ascending arousal system.
Description B: The ventrolateral preoptic nucleus promotes wakefulness by activating the ascending arousal system.

Description A: Sleep deprivation can lead to increased deposition of beta-amyloid peptides in the brain, possibly accelerating Alzheimer disease progression.
Description B: Sleep deprivation reduces deposition of beta-amyloid peptides in the brain, minimizing the risk of Alzheimer disease.

Description A: The T1R1-T1R3 complex is solely responsible for umami taste detection in mice.
Description B: The T1R1-T1R3 complex is solely responsible for bitter taste detection in mice.

Description A: Sweet receptors in mammals are composed of two subunits, T1R2 and T1R3.
Description B: Sweet receptors in mammals are composed of two subunits, T1R1 and T1R3.

Description A: Bitter taste is detected by approximately 30 G protein–coupled receptors called T2Rs.
Description B: Bitter taste is detected by approximately 30 receptor types unrelated to G protein–coupled receptors.

Description A: High salt concentrations activate bitter and sour taste cells.
Description B: High salt concentrations activate sweet taste cells.

Description A: The sour taste receptor in mice is the ion channel Otopetrin-1 (Otop1).
Description B: Sour taste is detected by the G protein–coupled receptor Otopetrin-1 (Otop1).

Description A: Insects have distinct taste cells for sugars, bitter compounds, pheromones, and water.
Description B: Insects share the same taste cells for detecting sugars, bitter compounds, pheromones, and water.

Description A: The gustatory cortex contains hot spots for sweet and bitter tastes which, when directly stimulated, can elicit behavioral responses.
Description B: The gustatory cortex contains hot spots for sour and salty tastes which, when directly stimulated, can elicit behavioral responses.

Description A: Taste signals travel through cranial nerves VII, IX, and X before reaching the gustatory cortex.
Description B: Taste signals bypass cranial nerves and directly travel to the gustatory cortex.

Description A: Domestic cats lack a functional sweet receptor.
Description B: Domestic cats and tigers lack functional sour receptors.

Description A: Humans have 28 T2R genes for bitter taste detection.
Description B: Humans have 50 T2R genes for bitter taste detection.

Description A: The human brain is a network of more than 80 billion individual nerve cells interconnected in neural circuits.
Description B: The human brain is a network of less than 10 billion individual nerve cells interconnected in neural circuits.

Description A: The medulla oblongata is directly rostral to the spinal cord and includes centers responsible for digestion, breathing, and the control of heart rate.
Description B: The cerebellum is directly rostral to the spinal cord and includes centers responsible for digestion, breathing, and the control of heart rate.

Description A: The hippocampus is critical for the storage of explicit memory, such as memory of people, places, things, and events.
Description B: The hippocampus is critical for the storage of implicit memory, such as motor habits and reflexes.

Description A: The occipital lobe is primarily responsible for vision and processing visual information.
Description B: The parietal lobe is primarily responsible for vision and processing visual information.

Description A: In humans, the brain’s rostral-caudal and dorsal-ventral axes are flexed by approximately 110 degrees in the brainstem region.
Description B: In humans, the brain’s rostral-caudal and dorsal-ventral axes are flexed by approximately 45 degrees in the brainstem region.

Description A: Neural science aims to elucidate how activities of nerve cells within defined circuits mediate complex mental processes.
Description B: Neural science aims to elucidate how activities of nerve cells within defined circuits are entirely isolated from mental processes.

Description A: Modern brain imaging techniques allow scientists to identify specific regions of the brain associated with distinct modes of thinking and feeling.
Description B: Modern brain imaging techniques allow scientists to map only the spinal cord but are unable to identify specific brain regions.

Description A: The amygdala coordinates the autonomic and endocrine responses of emotional states, such as memory of threats.
Description B: The amygdala is primarily involved in processing motor tasks and spatial awareness.

Description A: The cerebrum includes two cerebral hemispheres, each consisting of a heavily wrinkled outer layer called the cerebral cortex.
Description B: The cerebrum includes two cerebral hemispheres, each consisting of a smooth outer layer called the cerebral cortex.

Description A: The principles of neural science aim to appreciate the complexity of the brain without reducing thought to merely molecules or axioms.
Description B: The principles of neural science reduce the complexity of thought to just molecules and mathematical formulas.

Description A: Interaural time differences are detected by an array of neurons using delay lines from both ears, as proposed by Lloyd Jeffress.
Description B: Interaural time differences are detected by an array of neurons using delay lines from only one ear, as proposed by Lloyd Jeffress.

Description A: The lateral superior olive balances ipsilateral excitation with contralateral inhibition to localize sounds.
Description B: The lateral superior olive balances contralateral excitation with ipsilateral inhibition to localize sounds.

Description A: In humans, interaural intensities can differ in sounds that have frequencies greater than about 2 kHz.
Description B: In humans, interaural intensities can differ in sounds that have frequencies less than about 2 kHz.

Description A: The inferior colliculus serves as a convergence point for ascending auditory pathways.
Description B: The inferior colliculus serves as a divergence point for descending auditory pathways.

Description A: The auditory cortex is tonotopically organized with low frequencies represented anteriorly.
Description B: The auditory cortex is tonotopically organized with high frequencies represented anteriorly.

Description A: The medial olivocochlear neurons' axons terminate on the outer hair cells bilaterally.
Description B: The lateral olivocochlear neurons' axons terminate on the outer hair cells bilaterally.

Description A: Sound from the right generates synchronous EPSPs in the 'yellow' neuron due to a longer conduction delay.
Description B: Sound from the left generates synchronous EPSPs in the 'yellow' neuron due to a longer conduction delay.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral superior olive are activated more strongly by sounds from the ipsilateral than from the contralateral hemifield.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral superior olive are activated more strongly by sounds from the contralateral than from the ipsilateral hemifield.

Description A: Binaural sound cues and monaural spectral cues converge to create a spatial map of sound in the superior colliculus.
Description B: Only monaural spectral cues create a spatial map of sound in the superior colliculus.

Description A: The lateral olivocochlear neurons send their axons exclusively to the ipsilateral cochlea, terminating on the afferent fibers from inner hair cells.
Description B: The lateral olivocochlear neurons send their axons exclusively to the contralateral cochlea, terminating on the afferent fibers from outer hair cells.

Description A: When a subject generates a similar load profile by pulling down on the fixed object, the load force can be anticipated, and thus, the grip force is lower and also tracks the load force without delay.
Description B: When a subject generates a similar load profile by pulling down on the fixed object, the load force cannot be anticipated, and thus, the grip force is higher and does not track the load force without delay.

Description A: The size–weight illusion does not lessen when a person is informed that the objects are of equal weight and does not weaken with repeated lifting.
Description B: The size–weight illusion lessens when a person is informed that the objects are of equal weight and weakens with repeated lifting.

Description A: Subjects initially generate larger grip and load forces for the larger object because they assume it is heavier.
Description B: Subjects initially generate smaller grip and load forces for the larger object because they assume it is lighter.

Description A: The motor system is more concerned with controlling the hand, even at the cost of generating complex patterns of joint rotations.
Description B: The motor system is more concerned with controlling the joints, even at the cost of generating simple patterns of hand movements.

Description A: The optimal movement is one that minimizes the bad consequences of noise while saving energy.
Description B: The optimal movement is one that maximizes the bad consequences of noise while using more energy.

Description A: Optimal feedback control emphasizes feedback gains, which can be partially instantiated by reflexes that generate rapid motor responses.
Description B: Optimal feedback control dismisses feedback gains, which cannot be instantiated by reflexes that generate rapid motor responses.

Description A: Error-based learning involves adapting internal sensorimotor models.
Description B: Error-based learning ignores the adaptation of internal sensorimotor models.

Description A: Most motor learning tends to become automatic with time.
Description B: Most motor learning tends to remain non-automatic with time.

Description A: The variability of force production increases with the level of the force.
Description B: The variability of force production decreases with the level of the force.

Description A: Learning skills involves improving performance in the absence of a perturbation.
Description B: Learning skills involves degrading performance in the presence of a perturbation.

Description A: Channelopathies can affect phases of synaptic transmission, including neurotransmitter release and neuronal excitability.
Description B: Channelopathies are the only cause of all human epilepsies affecting synaptic transmission.

Description A: Many epilepsy genes can affect multiple phases of synaptic transmission, including the migration of interneurons and the release of neurotransmitters.
Description B: Epilepsy genes only affect the genetic code without influencing neurotransmitter functionality or interneuron migration.

Description A: Helmholtz proposed the idea of unconscious inference, believing the brain makes decisions without our awareness.
Description B: Helmholtz believed that consciousness is necessary for all brain activity and inferences.

Description A: The majority of cognitive processing never enters consciousness, supporting Helmholtz's theory.
Description B: All cognitive processing is consciously perceived, contrary to Helmholtz's theory.

Description A: Unconscious processing in patients can be demonstrated using images with differences, such as a fire in one of two identical-looking houses.
Description B: Patients with unconscious processing deficits cannot be shown images with differences despite their ability to process it.

Description A: Unilateral neglect can result from lesions in the right parietal lobe, causing patients to ignore the left side of objects.
Description B: Unilateral neglect affects only the right side of objects and is caused by lesions in the left occipital lobe.

Description A: Interneurons have an essential role in epilepsy by influencing network formation and synaptic conductances.
Description B: Interneurons are irrelevant for network formation and synaptic conductances in epilepsy.

Description A: Change blindness occurs when perception remains unchanged despite significant sensory input alterations.
Description B: Change blindness is characterized by an immediate perception change when sensory input is altered.

Description A: The Rubin figure and Necker cube demonstrate that perception changes can occur without changes in sensory stimulation.
Description B: The Rubin figure and Necker cube show that sensory input changes always lead to perception changes.

Description A: In schizophrenia, hallucinations are sometimes linked to increased neural activity in specific sensory brain regions.
Description B: Hallucinations in schizophrenia are unrelated to any neural activity changes in sensory brain regions.

Description A: Transmitter release can be modulated intrinsically or extrinsically as an aspect of synaptic plasticity.
Description B: Transmitter release can only be modulated extrinsically as an aspect of synaptic plasticity.

Description A: Synaptic strength can be influenced by the pattern of firing in phenomena known as 'depression' and 'facilitation.'
Description B: Synaptic strength can only be affected by external substances and not by the pattern of firing.

Description A: Extrinsic neuromodulators can alter the dynamics of release by regulation of Ca2+ channels.
Description B: Extrinsic neuromodulators do not affect the dynamics of release through Ca2+ channels.

Description A: The interaction of neurotransmitters with receptors is typically transient.
Description B: The interaction of neurotransmitters with receptors is typically permanent.

Description A: A neurotransmitter typically acts on a target other than the releasing neuron itself.
Description B: A neurotransmitter always acts on the releasing neuron itself.

Description A: Neuropeptides and small-molecule transmitters can be co-released.
Description B: Neuropeptides and small-molecule transmitters cannot be released together.

Description A: Removal of the transmitter from the synaptic cleft terminates synaptic transmission.
Description B: Synaptic transmission continues indefinitely after transmitter release.

Description A: Small-molecule transmitters are actively taken up into vesicles.
Description B: Small-molecule transmitters are not actively taken up into vesicles.

Description A: Synaptic vesicles are closely associated with specific Ca2+ channels at active zones.
Description B: Synaptic vesicles are randomly scattered and have no specific association with Ca2+ channels.

Description A: Ca2+ entry evoked by an action potential leads to neurotransmitter release.
Description B: Ca2+ entry does not play a role in neurotransmitter release.

Description A: In mice lacking rapsyn, muscles form normally and ACh receptors accumulate in normal numbers but fail to aggregate at the synaptic sites on the membrane.
Description B: In mice lacking rapsyn, muscles do not form normally and ACh receptors fail to accumulate in normal numbers at the synaptic sites on the membrane.

Description A: Agrin is required to maintain clustering of ACh receptors at synaptic sites.
Description B: Agrin is not required to maintain clustering of ACh receptors at synaptic sites.

Description A: The motor neuron ensures that patches of postsynaptic membrane contacted by axon branches are rich in ACh receptors.
Description B: The motor neuron ensures that patches of postsynaptic membrane are devoid of ACh receptors.

Description A: After birth, all motor axons but one withdraw from each fiber, and the surviving axon becomes more elaborate.
Description B: After birth, all motor axons remain at each fiber and none withdraw.

Description A: The synapses that form in neurexin- or neuroligin-lacking mutants are defective, with varying nature and severity of defects among synaptic types.
Description B: The synapses that form in neurexin- or neuroligin-lacking mutants are perfectly functional without any defects.

Description A: Pre- and postsynaptic elements regulate each other's differentiation by organizing synaptic components.
Description B: Pre- and postsynaptic elements do not influence differentiation or organization of synaptic components.

Description A: Gephyrin is highly concentrated in synaptic densities at glycinergic and some GABAergic synapses.
Description B: Gephyrin is not present in synaptic densities at glycinergic and some GABAergic synapses.

Description A: Newly formed myotubes exhibit expression of genes encoding ACh receptor subunits in most nuclei.
Description B: Newly formed myotubes do not exhibit expression of genes encoding ACh receptor subunits in any nuclei.

Description A: ACh receptors are composed of α-, β-, δ-, and ε-subunits postnatally.
Description B: ACh receptors are composed of α-, β-, δ-, and γ-subunits postnatally.

Description A: The nerve uses ACh to repress expression of ACh receptor genes extrasynaptically.
Description B: The nerve uses ACh to enhance expression of ACh receptor genes extrasynaptically.

Description A: The amygdala is necessary for Pavlovian fear conditioning: Animals with amygdala damage fail to learn the association between the CS and the US.
Description B: The hypothalamus is necessary for Pavlovian fear conditioning: Animals with hypothalamus damage fail to learn the association between the CS and the US.

Description A: The lateral nucleus of the amygdala receives sensory input from the thalamus directly.
Description B: The central nucleus of the amygdala receives sensory input from the thalamus directly.

Description A: The central amygdala mediates outputs to brain stem areas involved in the control of defensive behaviors.
Description B: The lateral amygdala mediates outputs to brain stem areas involved in the control of defensive behaviors.

Description A: Figure 42–5 shows that the lateral nucleus communicates with the central nucleus directly.
Description B: Figure 42–5 shows that the lateral nucleus communicates with the lateral prefrontal region directly.

Description A: Neural circuits engaged during fear conditioning involve both the lateral and central nuclei of the amygdala.
Description B: Neural circuits engaged during fear conditioning involve both the basal and cingulate nuclei of the amygdala.

Description A: The emotional charge of a stimulus is evaluated by the amygdala together with other brain structures like the prefrontal cortex.
Description B: The emotional charge of a stimulus is evaluated solely by the amygdala without any other brain structures.

Description A: The amygdala's connections with dopaminergic nuclei influence cognitive processing.
Description B: The amygdala's connections with occipital nuclei influence cognitive processing.

Description A: The amygdala can modulate attention, perception, memory, and decision making due to its wide connections to cortical areas.
Description B: The amygdala mainly focuses on motor functions such as movement and balance.

Description A: In Pavlovian fear conditioning, a tone can become a conditioned stimulus predicting a shock.
Description B: In Pavlovian fear conditioning, a light can become a conditioned stimulus predicting a shock.

Description A: Research suggests the lateral nucleus is a site of synaptic change during fear conditioning.
Description B: Research suggests the lateral nucleus is not involved in any synaptic changes during fear conditioning.

Description A: Neurons generated in the ventricular zone migrate to their final position along radial glial fibers.
Description B: Neurons generated in the ventricular zone migrate to their final position along tangential glial fibers.

Description A: In the mammalian central nervous system, cells with high levels of Notch activation are diverted from neuronal fates.
Description B: In the mammalian central nervous system, cells with high levels of Notch activation become neurons.

Description A: Radial glial cells serve as precursors to neurons in the central nervous system and provide a scaffold for neuronal migration.
Description B: Oligodendrocytes serve as precursors to neurons in the central nervous system and provide a scaffold for neuronal migration.

Description A: The inside-first, outside-last rule describes the pattern of neuronal layer formation in the cerebral cortex.
Description B: The outside-first, inside-last rule describes the pattern of neuronal layer formation in the cerebral cortex.

Description A: Loss of Numb activity causes progenitor cells to proliferate extensively.
Description B: Loss of Numb activity causes progenitor cells to become quiescent.

Description A: Notch signaling regulates the expression of two bHLH transcription factors, Olig1 and Olig2.
Description B: Notch signaling regulates the expression of two bHLH transcription factors, Mash1 and neurogenin-1.

Description A: The ventricular zone in the mammalian neural tube gives rise to the cerebral cortex.
Description B: The subventricular zone in the mammalian neural tube gives rise to the cerebral cortex.

Description A: Excitatory cortical neurons migrate radially along glial guides.
Description B: Inhibitory cortical neurons migrate radially along glial guides.

Description A: Reelin mutants exhibit a partially inverted layering of neurons in the cortical plate.
Description B: Reelin mutants exhibit a normally layered cortex.

Description A: During cell division, radial glial cells give rise to postmitotic neurons that migrate away from the ventricular zone using radial glial cells as a guide.
Description B: During cell division, radial glial cells do not give rise to neurons but support oligodendrocyte migration instead.

Description A: Many psychologists doubted that memory is a discrete function, independent of perception, language, or movement until the middle of the 20th century.
Description B: Many psychologists affirmed that memory is a discrete function, independent of perception, language, or movement until the middle of the 20th century.

Description A: Memory storage involves many different parts of the brain, and these regions are not all equally important.
Description B: Memory storage involves a single part of the brain, and all regions are equally important.

Description A: Working memory in humans consists of at least two subsystems—one for verbal information and another for visuospatial information.
Description B: Working memory in humans consists of only one subsystem for verbal information and none for visuospatial information.
