Description A: Rehearsal of spatial and object information involves modulation in the parietal, inferior temporal, and occipital cortices by the frontal and premotor cortices.
Description B: Rehearsal of spatial and object information does not involve modulation in the parietal, inferior temporal, and occipital cortices by the frontal and premotor cortices.

Description A: H.M. could not transfer new information into long-term memory but had normal working memory for seconds or minutes.
Description B: H.M. could easily transfer new information into long-term memory and had impaired working memory for seconds or minutes.

Description A: The medial temporal lobe plays a crucial role in forming explicit or declarative memories.
Description B: The medial temporal lobe plays no role in forming explicit or declarative memories.

Description A: fMRI findings show that the hippocampus is involved in encoding episodic memories, with activity in frontoparietal networks.
Description B: fMRI findings show that the hippocampus is not involved in encoding episodic memories and does not interact with frontoparietal networks.

Description A: The medial temporal lobe interacts with cortical regions during memory consolidation and retrieval.
Description B: The medial temporal lobe does not interact with cortical regions during memory consolidation and retrieval.

Description A: Retrieval of memories can involve errors as it is a constructive process, much like perception is subject to illusions.
Description B: Retrieval of memories is error-free and is not a constructive process, unlike perception which is subject to illusions.

Description A: fMRI studies show overlapping brain regions active during memory retrieval and imagination of future events.
Description B: fMRI studies show completely separate brain regions active during memory retrieval and imagination of future events.

Description A: The hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis involves neurons in the paraventricular nucleus of the hypothalamus that synthesize and release corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH).
Description B: The hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis involves neurons in the amygdala that synthesize and release corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH).

Description A: In humans, the major glucocorticoid is cortisol.
Description B: In humans, the major glucocorticoid is corticosterone.

Description A: Feedback inhibition by glucocorticoids is attenuated in major depression.
Description B: Feedback inhibition by glucocorticoids is enhanced in major depression.

Description A: Major depressive disorder can be treated effectively with antidepressant drugs, cognitive psychotherapy, and electroconvulsive therapy.
Description B: Major depressive disorder can only be treated effectively with dietary changes.

Description A: In approximately half of people with major depression, the HPA axis becomes resistant to suppression even by potent synthetic glucocorticoids such as dexamethasone.
Description B: In all people with major depression, the HPA axis becomes more sensitive to suppression by potent synthetic glucocorticoids such as dexamethasone.

Description A: Functional neuroimaging studies of anxiety disorders and major depression have found decreased activity in prefrontal cortical regions.
Description B: Functional neuroimaging studies of anxiety disorders and major depression have found increased activity in prefrontal cortical regions.

Description A: During major depression, increased activity is generally observed in the rostral and ventral subdivisions of the anterior cingulate cortex.
Description B: During major depression, decreased activity is generally observed in the rostral and ventral subdivisions of the anterior cingulate cortex.

Description A: Studies have shown that patients with major depression have a decreased hippocampal volume compared to healthy subjects.
Description B: Studies have shown that patients with major depression have an increased hippocampal volume compared to healthy subjects.

Description A: Ketamine blocks the NMDA glutamate receptor and is studied as a rapid treatment for major depressive disorder.
Description B: Ketamine enhances the NMDA glutamate receptor and is studied as a treatment for major anxiety disorders.

Description A: The major serotonergic systems in the brain arise in the raphe nuclei of the brain stem.
Description B: The major serotonergic systems in the brain arise in the cortex.

Description A: Repeated cocaine exposure increases the intrinsic excitability of nucleus accumbens neurons, contributing to reward tolerance.
Description B: Repeated cocaine exposure decreases the intrinsic excitability of nucleus accumbens neurons, leading to reward sensitization.

Description A: Orexinergic neurons are lost in narcolepsy, causing disruption in sleep patterns.
Description B: GABAergic neurons are lost in narcolepsy, causing disruption in sleep patterns.

Description A: The ventral tegmental area is involved in increasing the intrinsic excitability of dopaminergic neurons due to repeated opiate exposure.
Description B: The prefrontal cortex is involved in increasing the intrinsic excitability of dopaminergic neurons due to repeated opiate exposure.

Description A: The nucleus accumbens is a key component of reward-related circuitry impacted by drugs of abuse.
Description B: The cerebellum is a key component of reward-related circuitry impacted by drugs of abuse.

Description A: Drug addiction requires repeated exposure and is often accompanied by tolerance and dependency.
Description B: Drug addiction can occur after a single use and rarely involves processes of tolerance or dependency.

Description A: The loss of motor neuron inhibition during REM sleep allows for the physical enactment of dreams.
Description B: The inhibition of motor neurons during REM sleep prevents the physical enactment of dreams.

Description A: Non-REM sleep is characterized by slow EEG activity and a decrease in muscle tone.
Description B: Non-REM sleep is characterized by high-frequency EEG activity and increased muscle tone.

Description A: Neurotransmitter release from areas like the locus ceruleus is diminished during sleep.
Description B: Neurotransmitter release from areas like the locus ceruleus is enhanced during sleep.

Description A: Sleep spindles arise from interactions between neurons in the reticular nucleus of the thalamus and thalamocortical relay neurons during stage N2 sleep.
Description B: Sleep spindles arise from interactions between neurons in the hippocampus and the reticular nucleus during stage N2 sleep.

Description A: The ascending arousal system, located in the brain stem and hypothalamus, is crucial for wakefulness.
Description B: The descending arousal system, located in the brain stem and hypothalamus, is crucial for wakefulness.

Description A: The spinal cord receives and processes sensory information from the skin, joints, and muscles of the limbs and trunk.
Description B: The spinal cord receives and processes sensory information from the skin, joints, and muscles of the head.

Description A: The medulla oblongata includes centers responsible for vital autonomic functions such as digestion, breathing, and control of heart rate.
Description B: The medulla oblongata is responsible for cognitive functions such as memory and learning.

Description A: The pons conveys information about movement from the cerebral hemispheres to the cerebellum.
Description B: The pons conveys information about sensory input from the cerebellum to the cerebral hemispheres.

Description A: The cerebellum modulates the force and range of movement and is involved in the learning of motor skills.
Description B: The cerebellum regulates emotions and autonomic functions such as heart rate and digestion.

Description A: The occipital lobe is critical for all aspects of vision.
Description B: The occipital lobe is critical for processing auditory information.

Description A: Broca's area controls the production of speech and lies near the region of the motor area that controls mouth and tongue movements.
Description B: Broca's area controls sensory perception and lies in the occipital lobe.

Description A: Wernicke's area processes auditory input for language and is important for understanding speech.
Description B: Wernicke's area controls motor outputs for speech production.

Description A: According to Wernicke's model, the communication between Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas is mediated via the arcuate fasciculus.
Description B: According to Wernicke's model, the arcuate fasciculus mediates sensory input processing in the occipital lobe.

Description A: The central sulcus separates the precentral gyrus from the postcentral gyrus.
Description B: The central sulcus separates the temporal lobe from the occipital lobe.

Description A: The frontal lobes are important for higher cognitive processing and motor planning.
Description B: The frontal lobes are primarily involved in processing visual and auditory information.

Description A: In the random dot motion discrimination task, the observer decides if the net motion of dots is in one direction or its opposite.
Description B: In the random dot motion discrimination task, the observer decides if the net motion of dots is stationary or moving.

Description A: Neurons in the parietal and prefrontal cortices change their firing rates to represent the accumulation of evidence bearing on the direction decision.
Description B: Neurons in the parietal and prefrontal cortices maintain constant firing rates regardless of the accumulation of evidence bearing on the direction decision.

Description A: Area MT contains a complete map of the contralateral visual field, and almost all the neurons in area MT are direction selective.
Description B: Area MT contains no map of the visual field, and few neurons in area MT are direction selective.

Description A: Monkeys and humans perform the random dot motion task at nearly identical levels of accuracy.
Description B: Monkeys and humans perform the random dot motion task with significant differences in accuracy.

Description A: Neurons first encountered in the primary visual cortex respond differentially to the direction of motion.
Description B: Neurons first encountered in the primary visual cortex do not respond to motion direction.

Description A: Mountcastle found neurons in the somatosensory cortex with firing rates that were phase-locked to frequencies of the flutter.
Description B: Mountcastle failed to find any neurons in the somatosensory cortex that were phase-locked to frequencies of the flutter.

Description A: The decision model using signal and noise distributions was successful in explaining the perceptual decision-making process.
Description B: The decision model using signal and noise distributions failed to explain the perceptual decision-making process.

Description A: In higher mammals, neurons that respond differentially to motion direction are first encountered in the primary visual cortex.
Description B: In higher mammals, neurons that respond differentially to motion direction are first encountered in the auditory cortex.

Description A: Neurons in area MT are direction selective and contribute to evidence used for perceptual decision-making.
Description B: Neurons in area MT are not involved in direction selectivity or perceptual decision-making.

Description A: The decision rule predicts that if the decision variable is positive, the choice will be right; if negative, it will be left.
Description B: The decision rule predicts that if the decision variable is positive, the choice will be left; if negative, it will be right.

Description A: Electrical activity refines the specificity of synaptic connections of retinal ganglion cells.
Description B: Electrical activity abolishes the specificity of synaptic connections of retinal ganglion cells.

Description A: Retinal ganglion cells initially form axonal arbors that are large in their target fields in the superior colliculus.
Description B: Retinal ganglion cells never form axonal arbors in the superior colliculus.

Description A: Abolishing electrical activity in retinal ganglion cells decreases the remodeling of dendritic arbors.
Description B: Abolishing electrical activity in retinal ganglion cells increases the remodeling of dendritic arbors.

Description A: Muscle fibers express genes for distinctive isoforms of contractile proteins such as myosins and troponins.
Description B: Muscle fibers only express genes for a single isoform of contractile proteins.

Description A: Most muscles are composed of fibers of all types.
Description B: Most muscles are composed exclusively of a single type of fiber.

Description A: Different patterns of neural activity in fast and slow motor neurons can switch muscle properties.
Description B: Different patterns of neural activity in fast and slow motor neurons have no effect on muscle properties.

Description A: The neuromuscular junction consists of a motor neuron, a muscle fiber, and Schwann cells.
Description B: The neuromuscular junction consists only of a motor neuron and a muscle fiber.

Description A: After denervation, electrical stimulation can prevent excessive increase of ACh receptors.
Description B: After denervation, electrical stimulation causes an excessive increase of ACh receptors.

Description A: Presynaptic and postsynaptic structures organize each other's differentiation at the neuromuscular junction.
Description B: Presynaptic and postsynaptic structures develop independently at the neuromuscular junction.

Description A: Muscles of mutant mice lacking rapsyn fail to cluster ACh receptors at synaptic sites.
Description B: Muscles of mutant mice lacking rapsyn effectively cluster ACh receptors at synaptic sites.

Description A: The male-specific Y chromosome of fruit flies does not bear a sex-determining locus.
Description B: The male-specific Y chromosome of fruit flies carries the sex-determining locus.

Description A: Sex determination in fruit flies does not depend on gonadal hormones as it does in vertebrates.
Description B: Sex determination in fruit flies depends heavily on gonadal hormones similar to vertebrates.

Description A: A ratio of 0.5 drives male differentiation in fruit flies.
Description B: A ratio of 1 drives male differentiation in fruit flies.

Description A: In males, one particular mRNA (fruM) is translated into functional proteins.
Description B: In females, one particular mRNA (fruM) is translated into functional proteins.

Description A: The fru gene encodes a set of putative transcription factors.
Description B: The fru gene encodes a set of DNA polymerases.

Description A: Male courtship behavior requires the sex-specific splice variant of the fruitless (fru) gene.
Description B: Female courtship behavior requires the sex-specific splice variant of the fruitless (fru) gene.

Description A: fruM appears to initiate cell-autonomous male-typical differentiation of the neurons.
Description B: fruM appears to initiate cell-autonomous female-typical differentiation of the neurons.

Description A: FruM is necessary and sufficient to drive most steps in the male fly courtship ritual.
Description B: FruF is necessary and sufficient to drive most steps in the male fly courtship ritual.

Description A: fruF males do not court females and do not reject mating attempts by wild type males.
Description B: fruF males do court females and reject mating attempts by wild type males.

Description A: fruM is expressed in a neural circuit essential for male fly courtship.
Description B: fruM is expressed in a neural circuit that is non-essential for male fly courtship.

Description A: Mirror neurons discharge both when the monkey actively grasps and manipulates objects and when it observes similar actions performed by another monkey or the experimenter.
Description B: Mirror neurons discharge only when the monkey actively grasps and manipulates objects, not when it observes similar actions performed by another monkey or the experimenter.

Description A: Some premotor and parietal areas can be activated when no overt action is intended, such as when an individual imagines performing a certain motor act.
Description B: Premotor and parietal areas cannot be activated unless overt action is intended, even when an individual imagines performing a certain motor act.

Description A: A neuron in the dorsal premotor cortex has a higher discharge rate whenever the nonmatch rule is in effect during the delay between the presentation of the first and second images.
Description B: A neuron in the ventral premotor cortex has a higher discharge rate whenever the nonmatch rule is in effect during the delay between the presentation of the first and second images.

Description A: Neurons in the primary motor cortex are more prominent in humans than in other species, leading to profound effects on voluntary motor control following lesions.
Description B: Neurons in the primary motor cortex are less prominent in humans than in other species, leading to minimal effects on voluntary motor control following lesions.

Description A: Corticomotoneuronal cells in the primary motor cortex project monosynaptically to spinal motor neurons and are located almost exclusively within the anterior bank of the central sulcus.
Description B: Corticomotoneuronal cells in the primary motor cortex project polysynaptically to spinal motor neurons and are located exclusively outside of the central sulcus.

Description A: Large lesions in the primary motor cortex in humans typically result in severe motor deficits or complete paralysis of affected body parts.
Description B: Large lesions in the primary motor cortex in humans typically result in no motor deficits or paralysis of affected body parts.

Description A: The motor map in the primary motor cortex is not an exact point-to-point reproduction of the body's anatomical form, with fine motor control regions like fingers having disproportionately large areas.
Description B: The motor map in the primary motor cortex is an exact point-to-point reproduction of the body's anatomical form, with equal representation of all body parts.

Description A: The activity of many neurons in the prefrontal cortex, SMC, and PMv scaled with the frequencies of f1 and f2 while they were being delivered.
Description B: The activity of all neurons in the prefrontal cortex, SMC, and PMv did not scale with the frequencies of f1 and f2 while they were being delivered.

Description A: During the interval between f1 and f2, there was no sustained activity in S-I representing the memorized f1.
Description B: During the interval between f1 and f2, there was sustained activity in S-I representing the memorized f1.

Description A: The primary motor cortex includes a detailed map of the motor periphery and generates motor commands to control spinal activity.
Description B: The primary motor cortex includes no detailed map of the motor periphery and plays no role in generating motor commands to control spinal activity.

Description A: The for gene is expressed at high levels in the brains of active foraging honeybees.
Description B: The for gene is expressed at low levels in the brains of active foraging honeybees.

Description A: Crowded environments favor the rover larva, which is effective at finding new food sources.
Description B: Sparse environments favor the rover larva, which is effective at finding new food sources.

Description A: Oxytocin stimulates pair-bond formation in female prairie voles during mating.
Description B: Oxytocin inhibits pair-bond formation in female prairie voles during mating.

Description A: Neuropeptide receptors regulate social behaviors in several species.
Description B: Neuropeptide receptors do not regulate social behaviors in any species.

Description A: Rett syndrome is an X-linked, progressive neurodevelopmental disorder.
Description B: Rett syndrome is an autosomal dominant, progressive neurodevelopmental disorder.

Description A: Expression of V1a vasopressin receptors is high in the ventral pallidum of prairie voles.
Description B: Expression of V1a vasopressin receptors is low in the ventral pallidum of prairie voles.

Description A: GWASs have identified over 100 risk loci for schizophrenia.
Description B: GWASs have identified less than 10 risk loci for schizophrenia.

Description A: Phenylketonuria is a genetic disorder that can be managed with dietary intervention.
Description B: Phenylketonuria is a genetic disorder that cannot be managed with dietary intervention.

Description A: Fragile X syndrome results from mutations that reduce expression of the FMRP gene.
Description B: Fragile X syndrome results from mutations that increase expression of the FMRP gene.

Description A: Rover-type larvae move from patch to patch, whereas sitter-type larvae stay put on a single patch.
Description B: Rover-type larvae stay put on a single patch, whereas sitter-type larvae move from patch to patch.

Description A: Large M1 lesions in monkeys have more drastic consequences, including initial paralysis and usually the permanent loss of independent movements of the thumb and fingers.
Description B: Large M1 lesions in monkeys have mild consequences, allowing immediate recovery of independent movements of the thumb and fingers.

Description A: Focal lesions of M1 typically result in muscle weakness, slowing and imprecision of movements, and discoordination of multi-joint motions.
Description B: Focal lesions of M1 typically result in increased muscle strength and precision in multi-joint motions.

Description A: Large motor cortex lesions in humans result in severe motor deficits or complete paralysis of affected body parts, usually with limited potential for recovery.
Description B: Large motor cortex lesions in humans result in mild motor deficits with significant potential for recovery.

Description A: Control of fine motor skills, such as independent movements of the fingers and hand and precision grip, is abolished after severe M1 lesions.
Description B: Control of fine motor skills, such as independent movements of the fingers and hand and precision grip, is improved after severe M1 lesions.

Description A: In cats, the pyramidal tract neurons in M1 are more strongly activated when an animal must modify its normal stepping motion to clear an obstacle under visual guidance.
Description B: In cats, the pyramidal tract neurons in M1 are more strongly activated during normal unimpeded locomotion over a flat, featureless surface.

Description A: The activity of M1 neurons has been intensively studied since the 1960s.
Description B: The activity of M1 neurons was not studied until the 1990s.

Description A: Most frequently, a CM cell axon directly excites the spinal motor neurons for several agonist muscles and indirectly suppresses the activity of some antagonist muscles through spinal inhibitory interneurons.
Description B: Most frequently, a CM cell axon suppresses spinal motor neurons for agonist muscles and excites antagonist muscles.

Description A: Neural activity is broadly tuned to the direction of the mechanical disturbance.
Description B: Neural activity is not influenced by the direction of the mechanical disturbance.

Description A: Afferent input from cutaneous and muscle sensory neurons is equally prevalent for hand-related neurons, reflecting the importance of both sources of sensory feedback when grasping and manipulating objects with the hand.
Description B: Afferent input from cutaneous and muscle sensory neurons is predominantly cutaneous for hand-related neurons.

Description A: The Primary Motor Cortex Is Dynamic and Adaptable.
Description B: The Primary Motor Cortex Is Static and Inflexible.

Description A: Morphemes are the smallest structural units of a language, best illustrated by prefixes and suffixes.
Description B: Morphemes are the smallest structural units of a language, best illustrated by complete sentences.

Description A: In English, the prefix un (meaning not) can be added to many adjectives to convey the opposite meaning.
Description B: In English, the prefix re (meaning again) can be added to many adjectives to convey the opposite meaning.

Description A: Irregular verbs do not follow the rule of adding an ending to indicate tense, for example, go becomes went.
Description B: Irregular verbs follow the rule of adding an ending to indicate tense, for example, go becomes goed.

Description A: Syntax specifies word and phrase order for a given language.
Description B: Syntax specifies the vocabulary used in a given language.

Description A: In English, sentences typically conform to a subject-verb-object order.
Description B: In English, sentences typically conform to an object-subject-verb order.

Description A: By the age of 3 years, children know approximately 1,000 words.
Description B: By the age of 3 years, children know approximately 100 words.

Description A: Language acquisition in children follows a universal pattern regardless of culture.
Description B: Language acquisition in children follows a specific pattern unique to each culture.

Description A: Phonotactic rules specify how phonemes can be combined to form words.
Description B: Phonotactic rules specify how words can be combined to form sentences.

Description A: Formant patterns for the sentence “Did you hit it to Tom?” illustrate the rapid changes that underlie normal speech.
Description B: Formant patterns for the sentence “Did you hit it to Tom?” remain constant and do not vary.

Description A: Japanese people find it very difficult to hear the acoustic differences between the American English /r/ and /l/ sounds.
Description B: Japanese people easily discern the acoustic differences between the American English /r/ and /l/ sounds.

Description A: The ventral stream maps speech sounds to meaning and is largely bilaterally represented.
Description B: The ventral stream maps speech sounds to motor programs and is largely unilateral.

Description A: Studies using DTI and tractography indicate that the arcuate fasciculus and the uncinate fasciculus connect language regions by 3 months of age.
Description B: Studies using DTI and tractography indicate that the arcuate fasciculus does not connect language regions until 2 years of age.

Description A: Broca's aphasia results from damage to Broca’s area, the surrounding frontal fields, and other regions like the insula.
Description B: Broca's aphasia results from damage primarily to the right hemisphere auditory areas only.

Description A: Conduction aphasia is caused by damage to the left superior temporal gyrus and inferior parietal lobe.
Description B: Conduction aphasia is caused by damage solely to the cerebellum and left occipital lobe.

Description A: Transcortical motor aphasia can be linked to damage to the left dorsolateral frontal area.
Description B: Transcortical motor aphasia is typically linked to damage in the occipital cortex and cerebellum.

Description A: The neural architecture for language develops rapidly during infancy.
Description B: The neural architecture for language remains largely undeveloped until adolescence.

Description A: The dorsal stream is strongly left hemisphere dominant.
Description B: The dorsal stream is strongly right hemisphere dominant.

Description A: Broca's aphasia results from damage to the left inferior frontal lobe.
Description B: Broca's aphasia results from damage to the right parietal lobe.

Description A: Wernicke’s aphasia is characterized by fluent but unintelligible speech and typically involves damage to the left posterior temporal lobe.
Description B: Wernicke’s aphasia involves speech that is slow and effortful and is typically caused by damage to the frontal lobe.

Description A: The ventral pathway extends to the anterior temporal lobe and the posterior inferior frontal cortex.
Description B: The ventral pathway does not extend beyond the auditory cortex.

Description A: Central neuronal tissue is a poor source of growth-promoting molecules and contains little laminin.
Description B: Central neuronal tissue is a rich source of growth-promoting molecules and contains abundant laminin.

Description A: Myelin inhibits regeneration of central axons by providing a growth-inhibiting environment.
Description B: Myelin promotes regeneration of central axons by providing a growth-enhancing environment.

Description A: Injury-induced scarring hinders axonal regeneration by mechanical interference and growth-inhibiting proteins.
Description B: Injury-induced scarring enhances axonal regeneration by providing structural support and growth-promoting proteins.

Description A: Peripheral nervous system retains the capacity to promote axon outgrowth into adulthood.
Description B: Central nervous system retains the capacity to promote axon outgrowth into adulthood.

Description A: Myelin-associated glycoprotein (MAG) inhibits the growth of some neuronal types.
Description B: Myelin-associated glycoprotein (MAG) promotes the growth of all neuronal types.

Description A: Reactive astrocytes generate scar tissue that suppresses axon regeneration.
Description B: Reactive astrocytes generate scar tissue that facilitates axon regeneration.

Description A: Chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans (CSPG) are major components of glial scar inhibiting axon regeneration.
Description B: Chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans (CSPG) are major components of glial scar promoting axon regeneration.

Description A: Nogo, MAG, and OMgp bind to common receptors like NogoR and PirB, inhibiting neurite growth.
Description B: Nogo, MAG, and OMgp do not interact with receptors and do not influence neurite growth.

Description A: Regeneration of central axons is not greatly enhanced in mutant mice lacking any of the growth-inhibitory factors.
Description B: Regeneration of central axons is significantly enhanced in mutant mice lacking any of the growth-inhibitory factors.

Description A: Neurons in the injured brain die but new ones can be born.
Description B: Neurons in the injured brain survive and no new ones can be born.

Description A: Damage in areas of the frontal cortex in the mesial surface of the left hemisphere impairs the initiation of movement (akinesia) and causes mutism.
Description B: Damage in areas of the frontal cortex in the mesial surface of the left hemisphere enhances the initiation of movement and causes increased speech.

Description A: Infants' speech production and speech perception skills are 'universal' at birth but become language-specific by the end of the first year.
Description B: Infants' speech production and speech perception skills are language-specific at birth and become universal by the end of the first year.

Description A: By the age of 3, infants know 1,000 words and continue to master grammatical structure until the age of 10.
Description B: By the age of 3, infants know 10,000 words and continue to master grammatical structure until the age of 5.

Description A: A new 'dual-stream' model of language shows that numerous brain regions support sound-to-meaning and sound-to-articulation pathways.
Description B: A new 'single-stream' model of language shows that only one brain region supports sound-to-meaning and sound-to-articulation pathways.

Description A: Studies on the infant brain reveal a fully formed ventral pathway at birth and a dorsal pathway to premotor areas.
Description B: Studies on the infant brain reveal an undeveloped ventral pathway at birth and a dorsal pathway to Broca's area.

Description A: Hemispheric specialization generally increases with age and language experience.
Description B: Hemispheric specialization generally decreases with age and language experience.

Description A: The classical forms of aphasia, such as Broca's and Wernicke's aphasia, are described within the context of the dual-stream model.
Description B: The classical forms of aphasia, such as Broca's and Wernicke's aphasia, are described outside the context of any neural models.

Description A: By the age of 3, young children, regardless of the language(s) they are learning, have mastered all levels of language.
Description B: By the age of 3, young children, regardless of the language(s) they are learning, struggle with basic language levels.

Description A: Infants' strategies in language learning require a social context and are not well described by operant conditioning or innate representation theories.
Description B: Infants' strategies in language learning do not require a social context and are well described by operant conditioning theories.

Description A: The basal ganglia are closely interconnected with the frontal and parietal cortex and may have a role in assembling morphemes into words.
Description B: The cerebellum is primarily interconnected with the occipital cortex and may have a role in assembling morphemes into words.

Description A: Threshold is defined as the stimulus intensity detected on 50% of the trials, which in this example would be about 5.5 (arbitrary units).
Description B: Threshold is defined as the stimulus intensity detected on 100% of the trials, which in this example would be about 5.5 (arbitrary units).

Description A: The psychometric function plots the percentage of stimuli detected by a human observer as a function of the stimulus magnitude.
Description B: The psychometric function plots the percentage of stimuli missed by a human observer as a function of the stimulus magnitude.

Description A: Sensory thresholds are a feature, not a bug.
Description B: Sensory thresholds are a bug, not a feature.

Description A: Thresholds can also be determined by the method of limits.
Description B: Thresholds cannot be determined by the method of limits.

Description A: The neural coding of sensory information is better understood at the early stages of processing.
Description B: The neural coding of sensory information is better understood at the later stages of processing.

Description A: Decision theory and signal detection theory quantify the variability of subjects’ responses.
Description B: Decision theory and signal detection theory eliminate the variability of subjects’ responses.

Description A: Rod and cone cells in the retina respond to light.
Description B: Rod and cone cells in the retina respond to sound.

Description A: Each major sensory system has several submodalities.
Description B: Each major sensory system has only one submodality.

Description A: Sensory receptors are morphologically specialized to transduce specific forms of energy.
Description B: Sensory receptors are morphologically identical and transduce all forms of energy.

Description A: Humans lack receptors that detect ultraviolet light or infrared radiation.
Description B: Humans have receptors that detect ultraviolet light and infrared radiation.

Description A: The parietal cortex provides information about the position and movements of the body for state estimation to plan and execute motor actions.
Description B: The parietal cortex provides unrelated visual processing for recognition without contributing to state estimation for motor planning.

Description A: The pyramidal tract is the key descending pathway for voluntary motor control and originates in cortical layer V of multiple precentral and parietal areas.
Description B: The pyramidal tract primarily originates in the occipital cortex and has no role in voluntary motor control.

Description A: Neurons in pre-SMA do not send direct axons to the spinal cord but instead project indirectly via subcortical structures.
Description B: Neurons in pre-SMA send direct axons to the spinal cord, bypassing subcortical structures.

Description A: The primary motor cortex (M1) contains corticospinal neurons with monosynaptic connections to spinal alpha motor neurons in primates.
Description B: The primary motor cortex (M1) lacks corticospinal neurons with monosynaptic connections to spinal alpha motor neurons in primates.

Description A: Visual fields of some VIP neurons expand to include tools when the monkey grasps them, reflecting adaptation tied to the workspace.
Description B: Visual fields of VIP neurons remain fixed regardless of tool usage or workspace expansion.

Description A: Monkeys with lesions in the superior parietal lobule show deficits in proprioceptive and tactile-guided reaching under non-visual conditions.
Description B: Monkeys with lesions in the superior parietal lobule show improved proprioceptive and tactile-guided reaching under non-visual conditions.

Description A: Delayed motor task studies indicate that similar neural populations contribute to both motor planning and execution.
Description B: Delayed motor task studies indicate that separate neural populations contribute exclusively to motor planning and execution.

Description A: Lesions to the posterior parietal cortex in humans impair the ability to use sensory information for guiding motor actions.
Description B: Lesions to the posterior parietal cortex in humans enhance the ability to use sensory information for guiding motor actions.

Description A: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) are involved in attention and coordinate vision with saccadic eye movements.
Description B: Neurons in the lateral intraparietal area (LIP) are exclusively involved in auditory processing and have no role in eye movements.

Description A: Neurons in areas PE and MIP are involved in integrating multiple body joint positions to create a body schema for movement control.
Description B: Neurons in areas PE and MIP process exclusively visual information, unrelated to body joint positions or movement control.

Description A: The human retina contains approximately 100 million rods and 5 million cones, with rods outnumbering cones significantly outside the fovea.
Description B: The human retina contains approximately 5 million rods and 100 million cones, with cones outnumbering rods significantly outside the fovea.

Description A: Rods are highly sensitive to light and enable vision under dim illumination, whereas cones are responsible for vision in daylight.
Description B: Cones are highly sensitive to light and enable vision under dim illumination, whereas rods are responsible for vision in daylight.

Description A: Primates have three types of cone photoreceptors: L (long-wave), M (medium-wave), and S (short-wave), enabling color vision.
Description B: Primates have only one type of cone photoreceptor in addition to rods, enabling limited color vision.

Description A: The central fovea contains no rods but is densely packed with small cones, making it specialized for daytime vision.
Description B: The central fovea contains no cones but is densely packed with small rods, making it specialized for nighttime vision.

Description A: In rods, the discs in the outer segment are free-floating, separated from the plasma membrane.
Description B: In cones, the discs in the outer segment are free-floating, separated from the plasma membrane.

Description A: Light hyperpolarizes photoreceptors by reducing the intracellular concentration of cGMP.
Description B: Light depolarizes photoreceptors by increasing the intracellular concentration of cGMP.

Description A: Rhodopsin is the visual pigment in rod cells and consists of opsin and retinal.
Description B: Rhodopsin is the visual pigment in cone cells and consists of opsin and chlorophyll.

Description A: Loss or deficiency of vitamin A can lead to night blindness.
Description B: Loss or deficiency of vitamin A has no impact on vision.

Description A: Retinal ganglion cells with center-surround receptive fields respond strongly to spatial contrast.
Description B: Retinal ganglion cells with center-surround receptive fields respond strongly to uniform illumination.

Description A: Cones respond faster than rods and are solely responsible for daylight vision.
Description B: Rods respond faster than cones and are solely responsible for daylight vision.

Description A: The primary visual cortex V1 contains orientation columns that repeat a full 180° cycle every 750 μm.
Description B: The primary visual cortex V1 contains orientation columns that repeat a full 360° cycle every 750 μm.

Description A: Ocular-dominance columns in the primary visual cortex alternate between left-eye and right-eye dominance, with a periodicity of 750 to 1,000 μm.
Description B: Ocular-dominance columns in the primary visual cortex alternate between left-eye and right-eye dominance, with a periodicity of 500 to 750 μm.

Description A: Blobs in the primary visual cortex specialize in processing color information and are distributed in a patchy pattern with diameters of a few hundred micrometers.
Description B: Blobs in the primary visual cortex specialize in processing orientation selectivity and are distributed in a patchy pattern with diameters of a few hundred micrometers.

Description A: The parvocellular layers in the LGN project to layer IVCβ in the primary visual cortex.
Description B: The parvocellular layers in the LGN project to layer IVCα in the primary visual cortex.

Description A: Feedback projections from the visual cortex to the LGN are 10 times greater in number than feedforward projections from the LGN to the cortex.
Description B: Feedforward projections from the LGN to the visual cortex are 10 times greater in number than feedback projections from the visual cortex to the LGN.

Description A: The dorsal visual pathway is primarily concerned with visually guided movement and direction of movement.
Description B: The dorsal visual pathway is primarily concerned with object identification and color processing.

Description A: The ventral visual pathway, which specializes in object identification, is primarily concerned with form and color.
Description B: The ventral visual pathway, which specializes in object identification, is primarily concerned with direction of movement.

Description A: Intrinsic-signal optical imaging visualizes activity in the visual cortex based on changes in local blood flow and the oxidative state of hemoglobin.
Description B: Intrinsic-signal optical imaging visualizes activity in the visual cortex based on fluorescence of voltage-sensitive dyes exclusively.

Description A: Horizontal connections in the visual cortex integrate information across a large portion of the visual field by linking columns with similar orientation specificity.
Description B: Horizontal connections in the visual cortex integrate information across a large portion of the visual field by linking columns with differing orientation specificity.

Description A: Magnocellular neurons from the LGN project to layer IVCα of the primary visual cortex.
Description B: Magnocellular neurons from the LGN project to layer IVCβ of the primary visual cortex.

Description A: T-type calcium channels help control excitability at the resting potential by opening in response to small depolarizations around −60 to −40 mV.
Description B: T-type calcium channels are activated by strong depolarizations, requiring voltages positive to −40 to −20 mV, similar to high-voltage-activated channels.

Description A: Mutations in the P/Q-type calcium channel α1-subunit can result in hemiplegic migraine or epilepsy.
Description B: Mutations in the P/Q-type calcium channel α1-subunit result exclusively in Lambert-Eaton syndrome, characterized by muscle weakness.

Description A: Fast synaptic transmission is mediated mainly by P/Q-type and N-type calcium channels concentrated at the active zone.
Description B: Fast synaptic transmission is mediated primarily by L-type calcium channels concentrated at the active zone.

Description A: The rhythmic pacemaker activity in certain brain and heart cells is influenced by T-type calcium channels.
Description B: The rhythmic pacemaker activity in certain brain and heart cells is influenced by P/Q-type calcium channels.

Description A: The frequency of miniature end-plate potentials can increase with a small depolarization of the presynaptic terminal.
Description B: The frequency of miniature end-plate potentials remains constant and is unaffected by depolarizations of the presynaptic terminal.

Description A: The L-type calcium channel is important for slower forms of transmitter release, like neuropeptide release, and is not typically involved in fast synaptic transmission.
Description B: The L-type calcium channel predominantly contributes to fast synaptic transmission at the active zones.

Description A: Each quantum of transmitter corresponds to the simultaneous release of approximately 5,000 molecules of ACh.
Description B: Each quantum of transmitter corresponds to the simultaneous release of approximately 500 molecules of ACh.

Description A: At the neuromuscular junction, an action potential typically releases 150 quanta of transmitter in about 1 ms.
Description B: At the neuromuscular junction, an action potential typically releases 15 quanta of transmitter over 100 ms.

Description A: Miniature end-plate potentials represent the spontaneous release of quanta from the presynaptic nerve terminal, even in the absence of an action potential.
Description B: Miniature end-plate potentials are evoked exclusively by action potentials in the presynaptic nerve terminal.

Description A: Calcium influx through P/Q-type and N-type channels regulates the amount of transmitter released during synaptic transmission.
Description B: Calcium influx through T-type channels regulates the amount of transmitter released during synaptic transmission.

Description A: Axons from nasal hemiretina neurons cross the optic chiasm and project to the contralateral optic tectum.
Description B: Axons from nasal hemiretina neurons fail to cross the optic chiasm and instead project to the ipsilateral optic tectum.

Description A: Ephrin-A concentrations run from posterior-high to anterior-low in the tectum.
Description B: Ephrin-A concentrations run from anterior-high to posterior-low in the tectum.

Description A: Commissural axons fail to reach the floor plate when netrin-1 is eliminated.
Description B: Commissural axons reach the floor plate successfully even when netrin-1 is eliminated.

Description A: Temporal retinal axons with high EphA expression are repelled from posterior tectum.
Description B: Temporal retinal axons with high EphA expression are attracted to the posterior tectum.

Description A: Growth cones become sensitive to Slit repellent signals after crossing the floor plate.
Description B: Growth cones lose sensitivity to Slit repellent signals after crossing the floor plate.

Description A: Netrin-1 attracts commissural axons to the floor plate by acting as both a secreted factor and a membrane guidance molecule.
Description B: Netrin-1 repels commissural axons from the floor plate by acting as a secreted factor.

Description A: Ephrin-B/EphB interactions influence both dorsoventral mapping and midline crossing decisions.
Description B: Ephrin-B/EphB interactions influence anteroposterior mapping but not midline crossing decisions.

Description A: Temporal retinal axons avoid ephrin-rich caudal tectum and terminate in rostral tectum areas.
Description B: Temporal retinal axons are indifferent to ephrin concentration gradients and target random tectum areas.

Description A: Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) secreted by the roof plate direct commissural axons ventrally.
Description B: Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) secreted by the floor plate attract commissural axons dorsally.

Description A: Growth cones switch their sensitivity to guidance cues after exposure to floor plate signals.
Description B: Growth cones retain their initial sensitivity to guidance cues even after interacting with floor plate signals.

Description A: Long-term potentiation (LTP) in the hippocampus demonstrates properties such as cooperativity, associativity, and synapse specificity.
Description B: Long-term potentiation (LTP) in the hippocampus demonstrates properties such as cooperativity, redundancy, and generalized activation.

Description A: NMDA receptor-dependent LTP is synapse specific because inactive synapses do not undergo LTP despite strong postsynaptic depolarization.
Description B: NMDA receptor-dependent LTP occurs uniformly at all synapses during strong postsynaptic depolarization.

Description A: Late LTP at the Schaffer collateral pathway involves cAMP, PKA, and CREB, leading to synapse-specific protein synthesis.
Description B: Late LTP at the Schaffer collateral pathway involves cAMP, PKA, and CB1 receptors, leading to non-specific protein synthesis.

Description A: NMDA receptor antagonists block spatial learning in the Morris water maze but do not inhibit memory recall if applied after learning.
Description B: NMDA receptor antagonists block spatial learning in the Morris water maze and also inhibit memory recall if applied after learning.

Description A: Spike-timing-dependent plasticity results in LTP when presynaptic firing precedes postsynaptic firing, but results in LTD when postsynaptic firing precedes presynaptic firing.
Description B: Spike-timing-dependent plasticity always results in LTP regardless of the timing between presynaptic and postsynaptic firing.

Description A: Mutant mice lacking the NR1 subunit of the NMDA receptor exhibit impaired spatial memory and abolished LTP in the Schaffer collateral pathway.
Description B: Mutant mice lacking the NR1 subunit of the NMDA receptor exhibit enhanced spatial memory and increased LTP in the Schaffer collateral pathway.

Description A: NMDA receptor-mediated LTP is required for many forms of explicit memory, including spatial and object recognition tasks.
Description B: NMDA receptor-mediated LTP is only required for spatial memory and not for other forms of explicit memory.

Description A: The synaptic capture hypothesis suggests that synaptic tagging allows activated synapses to utilize newly synthesized proteins during late LTP.
Description B: The synaptic capture hypothesis suggests that all synapses simultaneously utilize newly synthesized proteins during late LTP without tagging.

Description A: Mutant mice overexpressing the NR2B subunit of the NMDA receptor exhibit enhanced LTP and improved spatial memory.
Description B: Mutant mice overexpressing the NR2B subunit of the NMDA receptor exhibit reduced LTP and impaired spatial memory.

Description A: Long-term depression (LTD) in the hippocampus is induced by low-frequency stimulation and involves endocytosis of AMPA receptors.
Description B: Long-term depression (LTD) in the hippocampus is induced by high-frequency stimulation and involves exocytosis of AMPA receptors.

Description A: When viewing a face, brain activity increases in the fusiform face area of the inferior temporal lobe (FFA).
Description B: When viewing a face, brain activity increases in the parahippocampal place area of the inferior temporal cortex (PPA).

Description A: The problem of verifying subjective reports can partially be addressed with the use of brain imaging.
Description B: The problem of verifying subjective reports can be comprehensively resolved with the use of brain imaging.

Description A: In schizophrenia, the most common hallucinations are auditory, such as hearing voices.
Description B: In schizophrenia, the most common hallucinations are visual, such as seeing objects that aren't there.

Description A: Cognitive impairments in schizophrenia target working memory, executive function, declarative memory, verbal fluency, and social cognition.
Description B: Cognitive impairments in schizophrenia only affect verbal fluency but not other aspects of cognitive functions.

Description A: Antipsychotic drugs reduce psychotic symptoms but have no effect on cognitive impairments or deficit symptoms in schizophrenia.
Description B: Antipsychotic drugs reduce all symptoms of schizophrenia, including cognitive impairments and deficit symptoms.

Description A: The risk of schizophrenia rises with genetic relatedness to an affected individual.
Description B: The risk of schizophrenia is unaffected by genetic relatedness to an affected individual.

Description A: The onset of schizophrenia typically occurs during the late teen years or early to mid-twenties.
Description B: The onset of schizophrenia typically occurs during early childhood or the late forties.

Description A: Delusions in schizophrenia are firm beliefs that have no realistic basis and are not amenable to change by evidence.
Description B: Delusions in schizophrenia are beliefs that are easily corrected by presenting counter-evidence.

Description A: The 22q11.2 microdeletion is the most common cause of syndromic schizophrenia.
Description B: The 22q11.2 microdeletion is unrelated to syndromic schizophrenia.

Description A: Mental illnesses constitute the leading cause of disability worldwide, according to the World Health Organization.
Description B: Mental illnesses constitute a minor cause of disability worldwide, according to the World Health Organization.

Description A: The tip link is composed of the heterophilic association of protocadherin 15 and cadherin 23.
Description B: The tip link is composed of the homophilic association of protocadherin 15 and cadherin 23.

Description A: Hair cells that respond to the highest-frequency signals possess the shortest bundles.
Description B: Hair cells that respond to the highest-frequency signals possess the tallest bundles.

Description A: In the absence of LHFPL5, the conductance of the transduction channel is reduced, but significant transduction currents can still be measured.
Description B: In the absence of LHFPL5, the transduction channel is completely non-functional and no currents can be measured.

Description A: The cochlea amplifies sound energy and improves hearing sensitivity by actively emitting otoacoustic emissions.
Description B: The cochlea passively amplifies sound energy and does not emit otoacoustic emissions.

Description A: Hair cells use adaptation to maintain sensitivity to transient stimuli while rejecting static inputs.
Description B: Hair cells use adaptation to maintain sensitivity to static inputs while rejecting transient stimuli.

Description A: The voltage-induced movement of outer hair cells amplifies basilar-membrane motion and enhances human hearing sensitivity.
Description B: Voltage-induced movement of outer hair cells has no impact on basilar-membrane motion or hearing sensitivity.

Description A: Nonmammalian ears are generally limited in response to frequencies lower than about 12 to 14 kHz.
Description B: Nonmammalian ears are generally limited in response to frequencies higher than about 100 kHz.

Description A: Adaptation restores mechanical sensitivity to small rapid deflections of the hair bundle during prolonged stimuli.
Description B: Adaptation suppresses mechanical sensitivity to small rapid deflections of the hair bundle during prolonged stimuli.

Description A: Spontaneous otoacoustic emissions occur in most normal human ears under quiet conditions.
Description B: Spontaneous otoacoustic emissions cannot occur in normal human ears, even under quiet conditions.

Description A: The upper frequency limit of hearing is generally higher in mammals compared to nonmammalian species.
Description B: The upper frequency limit of hearing is generally higher in nonmammalian species compared to mammals.

Description A: The cerebellum constitutes only 10% of the total volume of the brain but contains more than one-half of its neurons.
Description B: The cerebellum constitutes 50% of the total volume of the brain but contains only 10% of its neurons.

Description A: The cerebellar cortex comprises a series of highly regular, repeating units, each of which contains the same basic microcircuit.
Description B: The cerebellar cortex comprises an irregular arrangement of units, each with a unique microcircuit.

Description A: Damage to the cerebellum causes distinctive symptoms, including abnormalities of movement and posture.
Description B: Damage to the cerebellum does not affect movement or posture at all.

Description A: The cerebellum contributes to feedforward sensorimotor control and timing of movements.
Description B: The cerebellum relies solely on sensory feedback for controlling movements and timing.

Description A: The cerebellum indirectly controls movement through other brain structures.
Description B: The cerebellum directly innervates limb muscles without other brain structures involved.

Description A: Cerebellar damage affects proprioceptive abilities, especially during active movements.
Description B: Cerebellar damage enhances proprioceptive abilities during active movements.

Description A: The cerebellum connects with the cerebral cortex through recurrent loops via relay in the thalamus.
Description B: The cerebellum does not connect with the cerebral cortex, and no relay through the thalamus exists.

Description A: Damage to the lateral areas of the cerebellum may result in disruptions to more distal limb movements.
Description B: Damage to the lateral areas of the cerebellum exclusively affects axial muscles without any impact on limb movements.

Description A: The cerebellum is divided into three functional areas: the vestibulocerebellum, spinocerebellum, and cerebrocerebellum.
Description B: The cerebellum is divided into two functional areas: the sensorycerebellum and motorcerebellum.

Description A: Cognitive deficits from cerebellar damage are less pronounced compared to sensory–motor disturbances.
Description B: Cognitive deficits from cerebellar damage are more pronounced compared to sensory–motor disturbances.

Description A: Climbing fibers can selectively induce long-term depression in the synapses between parallel fibers and Purkinje cells that are concurrently activated with climbing fibers.
Description B: Climbing fibers can selectively induce long-term potentiation in the synapses between parallel fibers and Purkinje cells that are concurrently activated with climbing fibers.

Description A: Patients with cerebellar damage are severely impaired or unable to adapt their eye-hand coordination when wearing prisms that distort visual input.
Description B: Patients with cerebellar damage show faster adaptation of eye-hand coordination when wearing prisms that distort visual input than healthy individuals.

Description A: Motor learning in the cerebellum involves synaptic plasticity at multiple sites, including long-term depression of parallel fiber-Purkinje cell synapses.
Description B: Motor learning in the cerebellum is strictly limited to the adjustment of deep cerebellar nuclei, excluding parallel fiber-Purkinje cell synapses.

Description A: Saccadic adaptation in monkeys involves learning to adjust the amplitude of eye movements over several hundred trials.
Description B: Saccadic adaptation in monkeys involves eliminating the need for eye movement adjustments entirely after just a few trials.

Description A: Adaptation of the vestibulo-ocular reflex requires the cerebellum and can be entirely blocked by lesions to the floccular complex.
Description B: Adaptation of the vestibulo-ocular reflex happens independently of the cerebellum and cannot be blocked by floccular complex lesions.

Description A: Learning of walking patterns using a split-belt treadmill is impaired in cerebellar patients compared to healthy individuals.
Description B: Learning of walking patterns using a split-belt treadmill is faster in cerebellar patients compared to healthy individuals.

Description A: Climbing fibers fire at very low frequencies and generate complex spikes in Purkinje cells.
Description B: Climbing fibers fire at very high frequencies and generate simple spikes in Purkinje cells.

Description A: The cerebellum relies on internal models to ensure smooth and accurate movement in advance of sensory feedback.
Description B: The cerebellum relies solely on sensory feedback to ensure smooth and accurate movement.

Description A: Current theories recognize many sites of synaptic and cellular plasticity within the cerebellum that contribute to motor learning.
Description B: Current theories recognize a single, isolated site of synaptic plasticity within the cerebellum for motor learning.

Description A: Patients with cerebellar ataxia experience profound difficulty coordinating movements across multiple joints.
Description B: Patients with cerebellar ataxia experience improved coordination of movements across multiple joints.

Description A: Long-term habituation in Aplysia leads to pruning of synaptic connections between sensory and motor neurons, reducing the number of terminals of each sensory neuron by one-third.
Description B: Long-term habituation in Aplysia leads to growth of synaptic connections between sensory and motor neurons, doubling the number of terminals of each sensory neuron.

Description A: Sensitization in Aplysia involves presynaptic facilitation, which enhances transmitter release from siphon sensory neurons.
Description B: Sensitization in Aplysia involves presynaptic suppression, which decreases transmitter release from siphon sensory neurons.

Description A: Classical conditioning in Aplysia requires the conditioned stimulus to precede the unconditioned stimulus by about 0.5 seconds for effective learning.
Description B: Classical conditioning in Aplysia is most effective when the conditioned stimulus follows the unconditioned stimulus by about 0.5 seconds.

Description A: Serotonin enhances CREB-1 activation by reducing miRNA-124 levels, leading to efficient memory consolidation.
Description B: Serotonin enhances CREB-1 activation by increasing miRNA-124 levels, leading to efficient memory consolidation.

Description A: Protein kinase A (PKA) becomes persistently active during long-term sensitization, even after cAMP levels return to resting levels.
Description B: Protein kinase A (PKA) becomes inactive during long-term sensitization once cAMP levels return to resting levels.

Description A: In Aplysia, sensory neurons weakened by habituation can be strengthened through dishabituation caused by tail shocks.
Description B: In Aplysia, sensory neurons weakened by habituation cannot be strengthened by tail shocks, even through dishabituation.

Description A: CREB-1 binds to the cAMP response element (CRE) to activate transcription for long-term memory consolidation.
Description B: CREB-1 binds to the TATA box to directly activate transcription for long-term memory consolidation.

Description A: PKA and PKC work together to enhance the release of neurotransmitters by phosphorylating key presynaptic proteins.
Description B: PKA and PKC work together to suppress the release of neurotransmitters by dephosphorylating key presynaptic proteins.

Description A: Long-term sensitization in Aplysia is characterized by the growth of new synaptic connections.
Description B: Long-term sensitization in Aplysia is characterized by the elimination of new synaptic connections.

Description A: Serotonin activates PKC via the Gq/11 protein pathway, which contributes to presynaptic facilitation in Aplysia.
Description B: Serotonin activates PKC via the Gi protein pathway, which contributes to presynaptic facilitation in Aplysia.

Description A: ACh-sensitive GIRK channels are opened directly by the βγ subunits of a G protein after activation by a muscarinic receptor.
Description B: ACh-sensitive GIRK channels are closed directly by the αi subunit of a G protein after activation by a muscarinic receptor.

Description A: Stimulation of the parasympathetic vagus nerve releases ACh, which acts at muscarinic receptors to open GIRK channels in cardiac muscle cells, slowing the heart rate.
Description B: Stimulation of the parasympathetic vagus nerve releases serotonin, which acts at ionotropic receptors to open GIRK channels in cardiac muscle cells, slowing the heart rate.

Description A: Opening of GIRK channels by ACh does not require freely diffusible second messengers because the βγ-subunits remain tethered to the membrane.
Description B: Opening of GIRK channels by ACh requires freely diffusible second messengers because the βγ-subunits diffuse away from the membrane.

Description A: The S-type K+ channel in Aplysia is closed by serotonin through a cAMP signaling cascade, increasing neuronal excitability.
Description B: The S-type K+ channel in Aplysia is opened by serotonin through a cAMP signaling cascade, decreasing neuronal excitability.

Description A: Neuromodulators can produce long-term effects in neurons by altering gene transcription via second-messenger cascades.
Description B: Neuromodulators only produce short-term effects in neurons by altering ion channel conductance.

Description A: The pyloric rhythm in the crustacean stomatogastric ganglion is influenced by dopamine, which modulates slow-wave amplitude in neurons.
Description B: The pyloric rhythm in the crustacean stomatogastric ganglion is completely independent of dopamine and shows no modulation.

Description A: Acetylcholine decreases M-type current amplitude, leading to a slow depolarization and decreased adaptation.
Description B: Acetylcholine increases M-type current amplitude, leading to a rapid hyperpolarization and increased adaptation.

Description A: Nitric oxide diffuses across membranes and stimulates cyclic GMP synthesis.
Description B: Nitric oxide is a small molecule neurotransmitter that binds directly to ionotropic receptors.

Description A: The anterior burster (AB) and pyloric dilator (PD) neurons in the crustacean stomatogastric ganglion are electrically coupled by gap junctions.
Description B: The anterior burster (AB) and pyloric dilator (PD) neurons in the crustacean stomatogastric ganglion are chemically coupled by inhibitory synapses.

Description A: The cyclic AMP pathway involves activation of adenylyl cyclase, synthesis of cAMP, and activation of protein kinase A.
Description B: The cyclic AMP pathway involves inhibition of adenylyl cyclase, breakdown of cAMP, and deactivation of protein kinase A.

Description A: The visual cortex in mice contains a small region that receives thalamic (lateral geniculate nucleus [LGN]) inputs from both eyes. In this binocular region, most neurons are predominantly responsive to contralateral eye input, fewer respond to binocular inputs, and very few respond to ipsilateral eye input only.
Description B: The visual cortex in mice contains a small region that receives thalamic (lateral geniculate nucleus [LGN]) inputs from both eyes, where most neurons are predominantly responsive to ipsilateral eye input, fewer respond to binocular inputs, and very few respond to contralateral eye input only.

Description A: Enhancing GABA signaling through administration of benzodiazepines shifts the critical period for monocular deprivation to an earlier developmental time.
Description B: Enhancing GABA signaling through administration of benzodiazepines shifts the critical period for monocular deprivation to a later developmental time.

Description A: In mice lacking Nogo or Nogo receptor (NogoR), the critical period remains open into adulthood, allowing greater plasticity.
Description B: In mice lacking Nogo or Nogo receptor (NogoR), the critical period is shortened, reducing opportunities for plasticity.

Description A: Dendritic spine motility in the mouse visual cortex increases shortly after one eye is closed during the critical period, reflecting synaptic rearrangement.
Description B: Dendritic spine motility in the mouse visual cortex decreases shortly after one eye is closed during the critical period, reflecting synaptic stabilization.

Description A: Spontaneous, wave-like neural activity in the retina before eye opening regulates refinement and segregation of visual inputs.
Description B: Spontaneous, wave-like neural activity in the retina after eye opening regulates refinement and segregation of visual inputs.

Description A: Axons from the open eye sprout new terminals at sites vacated by fibers conveying input from the closed eye.
Description B: Axons from the open eye retract terminals at sites previously occupied by fibers conveying input from the closed eye.

Description A: Visual experience during the critical period in barn owls instructs the auditory map, aligning it with the visual map for proper sensory integration.
Description B: Auditory experience during the critical period in barn owls instructs the visual map, aligning it with the auditory map for proper sensory integration.

Description A: The pruning and remodeling of thalamocortical axons persistently reinforce cortical responses to the open eye, making changes enduring and structural.
Description B: The pruning and remodeling of thalamocortical axons temporarily reinforce cortical responses to the open eye, making changes reversible and short-term.

Description A: Myelination and formation of perineuronal nets contribute to the closure of the critical period by creating molecular barriers to plasticity.
Description B: Myelination and formation of perineuronal nets extend the critical period by creating molecular supports for prolonged plasticity.

Description A: Homeostatic plasticity ensures that loss of excitatory input from the closed eye is compensated by an increase in excitatory drive from the open eye.
Description B: Homeostatic plasticity ensures that loss of excitatory input from the closed eye is mitigated by decreasing excitatory drive from the open eye.

Description A: In vertebrates and insects, each olfactory neuron typically expresses only one functional odorant receptor gene.
Description B: In vertebrates and insects, each olfactory neuron typically expresses many functional odorant receptor genes.

Description A: Axons from sensory neurons expressing one type of receptor converge onto two invariant glomeruli in the antennal lobe, one on each side of the insect's body.
Description B: Axons from sensory neurons expressing one type of receptor converge onto a single glomerulus in the antennal lobe.

Description A: In C. elegans, the diacetyl receptor is expressed in specific sensory neurons responsible for behavior like attraction or repulsion.
Description B: In C. elegans, the diacetyl receptor is expressed in all sensory neurons distributed across the body.

Description A: The T1R2/T1R3 receptor complex mediates the detection of sweet compounds.
Description B: The T1R1/T1R3 receptor complex mediates the detection of sweet compounds.

Description A: In Drosophila, the main odorant receptor family consists of around 60 genes.
Description B: In Drosophila, the main odorant receptor family consists of over 300 genes.

Description A: Taste cells are non-neural but have characteristic synapses to transmit chemical signals to gustatory sensory neurons.
Description B: Taste cells are neural and independently transmit chemical signals to the brain without synapses.

Description A: The giant panda lacks a functional umami receptor due to losses in evolutionary niche adaptation.
Description B: The giant panda lacks both functional sweet and umami receptors due to losses in evolutionary niche adaptation.

Description A: High concentrations of sugars can be detected by T1R3 alone in mice.
Description B: Low concentrations of sugars can be detected by T1R3 alone in mice.

Description A: Bitter taste is detected by a family of approximately 30 G protein–coupled receptors called T2Rs.
Description B: Bitter taste is detected by a family of approximately 10 G protein–coupled receptors called T1Rs.

Description A: Food and pheromone cues in nematodes regulate development by influencing the activation of insulin signaling pathways.
Description B: Food and pheromone cues in nematodes regulate development solely by influencing their sensory neurons without insulin pathway involvement.

Description A: The hypothalamus controls the pituitary gland both directly and indirectly through neuroendocrine neurons.
Description B: The hypothalamus controls the pituitary gland only indirectly through neuroendocrine neurons.

Description A: Vasopressin and oxytocin are released into the general circulation from the posterior pituitary.
Description B: Vasopressin and oxytocin are released into the median eminence from the posterior pituitary.

Description A: Prolactin secretion is predominantly under inhibitory control mediated by dopamine.
Description B: Prolactin secretion is predominantly under excitatory control mediated by dopamine.

Description A: The parvocellular neurons releasing gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) are scattered in a continuum from the medial septum to the mediobasal hypothalamus.
Description B: The parvocellular neurons releasing gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) are located exclusively in the paraventricular nucleus.

Description A: Activation of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) neurons facilitates the release of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) from the anterior pituitary.
Description B: Activation of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) neurons inhibits the release of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) from the anterior pituitary.

Description A: Body temperature is controlled by neurons in the median preoptic nucleus.
Description B: Body temperature is controlled by neurons in the median eminence.

Description A: Brown adipose tissue is especially abundant in newborns and small mammals.
Description B: Brown adipose tissue is especially abundant in adult humans and large mammals.

Description A: Thermoreceptor neurons in the shell predominantly respond to cold temperatures.
Description B: Thermoreceptor neurons in the shell predominantly respond to warm temperatures.

Description A: Prostaglandin E2 inhibits warm-activated GABAergic neurons in the MnPO, contributing to fever.
Description B: Prostaglandin E2 excites warm-activated GABAergic neurons in the MnPO, contributing to fever.

Description A: The median eminence is outside the blood–brain barrier due to its fenestrated capillaries.
Description B: The median eminence is inside the blood–brain barrier due to its tight capillary structure.

Description A: Mutations of the PMP22 gene on chromosome 17 produce several hereditary peripheral neuropathies, while a duplication of this gene causes one form of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.
Description B: Mutations of the PMP22 gene on chromosome 17 produce several hereditary peripheral neuropathies, while a deletion of this gene causes one form of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

Description A: Astrocytes regulate synapse formation by secreting thrombospondins, hevin, and glycipans.
Description B: Astrocytes regulate synapse formation by secreting thrombospondins, insulin, and glycipans.

Description A: The central nervous system contains glial cells such as oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells, which produce myelin.
Description B: The central nervous system contains glial cells such as astrocytes and microglia, which produce myelin.

Description A: Proteolipids are soluble only in organic solvents because they contain long chains of fatty acids covalently linked to amino acid residues throughout the molecule.
Description B: Proteolipids are soluble only in water because they do not possess fatty acid chains.

Description A: Astrocytes continue to phagocytose synapses in the adult CNS, contributing to synapse remodeling based on neuronal activity.
Description B: Astrocytes reduce synapse phagocytosis in the adult CNS, preventing further remodeling based on neuronal activity.

Description A: The blood-brain barrier is maintained by tight junctions between endothelial cells of cerebral capillaries.
Description B: The blood-brain barrier is maintained by Schwann cells forming tight junctions around the capillaries.

Description A: Reactive astrocytes can be neurotoxic and are prominent in patients with Alzheimer disease.
Description B: Reactive astrocytes are harmless and do not contribute to Alzheimer's disease pathology.

Description A: Microglia contribute to the immune response in the CNS by releasing cytokines and neurotoxic proteins that can induce neurotoxic reactive astrocytes.
Description B: Microglia prevent immune responses in the CNS and avoid releasing cytokines and neurotoxic proteins.

Description A: The choroid plexus produces most of the cerebrospinal fluid that bathes the brain.
Description B: The choroid plexus produces only a small fraction of cerebrospinal fluid, with the majority produced by neurons.

Description A: Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is caused by mutations in a membrane-spanning domain of the PLP molecule.
Description B: Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease is caused by mutations in the extracellular glycosylation domain of the PLP molecule.

Description A: ON cells are excited by a bright spot in the receptive field center, OFF cells by a dark spot.
Description B: ON cells are excited by a dark spot in the receptive field center, OFF cells by a bright spot.

Description A: Sustained retinal ganglion cells are excited throughout the duration of stimulation, while transient cells only show a brief burst of spikes upon onset.
Description B: Sustained retinal ganglion cells only show a brief burst of spikes upon stimulation onset, while transient cells are excited throughout the duration of stimulation.

Description A: If a bright stimulus excites the center of a receptive field but is applied to the surround, firing is suppressed.
Description B: If a bright stimulus excites the center of a receptive field but is applied to the surround, firing is enhanced.

Description A: Temporal flicker sensitivity in humans is band-pass, with peak sensitivity at around 10 Hz.
Description B: Temporal flicker sensitivity in humans is low-pass, with peak sensitivity at very low frequencies.

Description A: In dim light, ganglion cell receptive fields lose their antagonistic surrounds, leading to low-pass spatial filtering behavior.
Description B: In dim light, ganglion cell receptive fields preserve their antagonistic surrounds, maintaining band-pass spatial filtering behavior.

Description A: Horizontal cells are connected to each other through gap junctions, enabling lateral inhibition in the outer retina.
Description B: Horizontal cells are completely isolated, lacking connections through gap junctions, preventing lateral inhibition.

Description A: Midget bipolar cells in the central retina connect to a single cone and excite a single P-type ganglion cell.
Description B: Midget bipolar cells in the central retina connect to multiple cones and excite a single P-type ganglion cell.

Description A: Rod bipolar cells exclusively transmit signals to AII amacrine cells and do not connect directly to ganglion cells.
Description B: Rod bipolar cells directly transmit signals to ganglion cells without the involvement of AII amacrine cells.

Description A: Protanopia and deuteranopia are forms of red-green color blindness and are more common in males.
Description B: Protanopia and deuteranopia are forms of blue-yellow color blindness and are equally common in males and females.

Description A: Light adaptation in human vision allows the retina to adjust its sensitivity to background illumination, preserving contrast perception.
Description B: Light adaptation in human vision results in the retina ignoring background illumination levels, leading to a loss of contrast perception.

Description A: The cerebellum contributes to motor control by using internal models to preprogram a sequence of muscle contractions for smooth, accurate movement.
