Description B: The cerebellum primarily reacts to incoming sensory feedback to adjust movements in real-time rather than preprogramming muscle contractions.

Description A: Lesions of the cerebellum disrupt the accuracy and coordination of voluntary movement.
Description B: Lesions of the cerebellum prevent all voluntary movement the same way lesions in the cerebral cortex do.

Description A: Climbing fibers originate in the inferior olivary nucleus of the brain stem and each Purkinje neuron receives input from only a single climbing fiber.
Description B: Climbing fibers originate in the spinal cord, and each Purkinje neuron receives input from multiple climbing fibers.

Description A: The cerebellar cortex is organized into three layers: granular layer, Purkinje cell layer, and molecular layer.
Description B: The cerebellar cortex is organized into four layers: granular layer, Purkinje cell layer, intermediate layer, and molecular layer.

Description A: The Purkinje cell layer is the output layer of the cerebellar cortex, projecting to the deep nuclei using GABA as an inhibitory neurotransmitter.
Description B: The granular layer, not the Purkinje cell layer, is the output layer of the cerebellar cortex, projecting excitatory signals to the deep nuclei.

Description A: Mossy fibers affect Purkinje cells indirectly through granule cells and parallel fibers.
Description B: Mossy fibers directly synapse on Purkinje cells without involving granule cells or parallel fibers.

Description A: Parallel fibers run perpendicular to the Purkinje cell dendrites and form synapses with many Purkinje cells.
Description B: Parallel fibers run parallel to the Purkinje cell dendrites and form synapses with only one Purkinje cell.

Description A: Feedforward control by the cerebellum allows it to anticipate muscle contractions needed for smooth movement before sensory feedback is received.
Description B: Feedforward control by the cerebellum relies entirely on sensory feedback during movement for adjusting contractions.

Description A: Lesions in the oculomotor region of the vermis cause saccades that overshoot their target.
Description B: Lesions in the oculomotor region of the vermis improve the precision of saccades, preventing overshooting of the target.

Description A: Climbing fibers generate complex spikes in Purkinje cells characterized by an initial large action potential followed by smaller spikes.
Description B: Climbing fibers generate simple spikes in Purkinje cells without any large initial action potentials.

Description A: Motor neuron diseases do not affect sensory neurons, as seen in conditions like Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS).
Description B: Motor neuron diseases primarily affect sensory neurons, as seen in conditions like Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS).

Description A: Myopathies cause weakness of skeletal muscle with little or no change to motor neurons.
Description B: Myopathies primarily cause changes to motor neurons rather than skeletal muscle weakness.

Description A: Fasciculations, visible twitches of muscle, are often signs of neurogenic diseases.
Description B: Fasciculations, visible twitches of muscle, are often signs of myopathic diseases.

Description A: Needle electromyography (EMG) can distinguish between neurogenic and myopathic diseases by analyzing motor unit potentials.
Description B: Needle electromyography (EMG) cannot distinguish between neurogenic and myopathic diseases due to similar motor unit potentials.

Description A: Peripheral neuropathies often affect distal areas, leading to sensory deficits in a glove-and-stocking pattern.
Description B: Peripheral neuropathies primarily affect proximal areas, avoiding sensory deficits in distal regions.

Description A: Upper motor neuron disorders can present with spasticity and abnormal reflexes, such as the Babinski sign.
Description B: Upper motor neuron disorders rarely present with spasticity or abnormal reflexes, such as the Babinski sign.

Description A: In normal muscle, there is usually no activity recorded at rest using electromyography (EMG).
Description B: In normal muscle, spontaneous activity at rest is always recorded using electromyography (EMG).

Description A: Diseases of skeletal muscle can be inherited, such as muscular dystrophies, or acquired, such as dermatomyositis.
Description B: Diseases of skeletal muscle are only acquired, such as dermatomyositis, and not inherited.

Description A: Some inherited diseases of skeletal muscle arise from defects in voltage-gated ion channels.
Description B: Inherited diseases of skeletal muscle never involve defects in voltage-gated ion channels.

Description A: Progressive bulbar palsy primarily affects cranial nerve-innervated muscles, causing dysarthria and dysphagia.
Description B: Progressive bulbar palsy does not affect cranial nerve-innervated muscles and avoids symptoms like dysarthria or dysphagia.

Description A: Humans can resolve the location of a sound source directly ahead to within approximately 1 degree, corresponding to an interaural time difference of 10 μs.
Description B: Humans can resolve the location of a sound source directly ahead to within approximately 10 degrees, corresponding to an interaural time difference of 1 ms.

Description A: Mammals can localize sounds in the vertical plane using spectral filtering, which provides cues due to interactions of high-frequency sounds with the head and external ears.
Description B: Mammals primarily use interaural time differences to localize sounds in the vertical plane.

Description A: Sound shadows created by the head are particularly important for localizing high-frequency sounds in the horizontal plane.
Description B: Sound shadows created by the head are particularly useful for localizing low-frequency sounds in the horizontal plane.

Description A: Cochlear nerve fibers terminate in a tonotopic pattern in the cochlear nuclei, with low-frequency fibers terminating ventrally.
Description B: Cochlear nerve fibers terminate randomly in the cochlear nuclei, showing no organized pattern.

Description A: Interaural time differences are particularly well conveyed by neurons that encode relatively low frequencies.
Description B: Interaural time differences are primarily conveyed by neurons that encode high frequencies.

Description A: Large spherical bushy cells form circuits that detect interaural time delay and contribute to localizing low-frequency sounds in the horizontal plane.
Description B: Large spherical bushy cells form circuits that detect spectral filtering and contribute to localizing high-frequency sounds in the vertical plane.

Description A: In humans, the maximal interaural time difference is approximately 600 μs.
Description B: In humans, the maximal interaural time difference is approximately 6 ms.

Description A: Octopus cells detect the onsets of sounds and mark spectral components that necessarily start together.
Description B: Octopus cells primarily encode interaural time differences for localizing low-frequency sounds.

Description A: Fusiform cells in the dorsal cochlear nucleus integrate inputs from parallel fibers and cochlear nerve fibers.
Description B: Fusiform cells in the dorsal cochlear nucleus only process somatosensory information.

Description A: The auditory pathway includes ascending signals as well as efferent feedback at many levels.
Description B: The auditory pathway exclusively relies on ascending signals without efferent feedback.

Description A: Infants in the prison nursing home showed normal development and tended to fare better than those in the foundling home by the end of the first year.
Description B: Infants in the prison nursing home showed delayed development compared to those in the foundling home by the end of the first year.

Description A: Studies of neglected orphans raised in impersonal institutions revealed long-lasting effects, including neurocognitive dysfunction and impaired ability to establish relationships.
Description B: Studies of neglected orphans showed temporary effects, with cognitive and social deficits resolving entirely after adoption by caring families.

Description A: Monkeys isolated during the first 6–12 months of life displayed persistent behavioral disturbances, confirming the critical importance of early social experience.
Description B: Monkeys isolated during adulthood showed the same behavioral disturbances as those isolated in early months of life, proving social isolation affects all ages equally.

Description A: Children born with congenital binocular cataracts experience permanent visual deficits if not treated surgically before the age of 10 years.
Description B: Children born with congenital binocular cataracts can regain normal vision even if treated surgically after the age of 10 years.

Description A: Hubel and Wiesel demonstrated that monocular deprivation during the critical period permanently impairs cortical responses to the deprived eye.
Description B: Hubel and Wiesel demonstrated that monocular deprivation during any stage of life reversibly affects cortical responses to the deprived eye.

Description A: Ocular dominance columns develop in response to sensory competition between axons from the two eyes.
Description B: Ocular dominance columns form spontaneously without competition between axons from the two eyes.

Description A: In frogs, experimental introduction of a third eye led to competition between axonal inputs and the formation of ocular dominance columns.
Description B: In frogs, experimental introduction of a third eye had no effect on competition between axonal inputs or the formation of columns.

Description A: Monkeys reared with siblings learned social skills that allowed them to interact effectively in later life.
Description B: Monkeys reared with siblings showed the same level of social dysfunction as isolated monkeys, indicating siblings have no impact on social learning.

Description A: Early misalignment of eyes (strabismus) prevents children from developing stereoscopic vision unless corrected within the first few years of life.
Description B: Early eye misalignment (strabismus) has no lasting impact on stereoscopic vision, even if corrected later in adolescence.

Description A: During critical periods, visual cortex circuits can be altered by sensory deprivation or changes in neural activity.
Description B: During critical periods, visual cortex circuits remain unaffected by sensory deprivation or changes in neural activity.

Description A: Somatosensory information from the limbs and trunk reaches the central nervous system through the 31 spinal nerves.
Description B: Somatosensory information from the limbs and trunk reaches the central nervous system through 41 spinal nerves.

Description A: The trigeminal nerve conveys somatosensory information from the lips, mouth, cornea, and skin on the anterior half of the head.
Description B: The trigeminal nerve conveys somatosensory information from the posterior half of the head.

Description A: Each spinal or cranial nerve receives sensory inputs from a particular region of the body called a dermatome.
Description B: Each spinal or cranial nerve receives sensory inputs from multiple unrelated regions of the body.

Description A: The largest myelinated fibers (Aα) terminate in or near the ventral horn of the spinal gray matter.
Description B: The largest myelinated fibers (Aα) terminate exclusively in the dorsal horn of the spinal gray matter.

Description A: Lamina I neurons generally have small receptive fields localized to one dermatome.
Description B: Lamina I neurons generally have large receptive fields spanning multiple dermatomes.

Description A: Mechanosensation in touch fibers is mediated by Piezo2 proteins.
Description B: Mechanosensation in touch fibers is mediated by TRPV1 proteins.

Description A: Passive touch is tested by naming objects or describing sensations.
Description B: Passive touch is tested by manipulating objects with the hand.

Description A: The spinothalamic tract conveys pain and thermal information to the midbrain or thalamus.
Description B: The spinothalamic tract conveys proprioceptive and tactile information to the medulla.

Description A: Thermoreceptors are excited by transient receptor potential (TRP) ion channels gated in response to local temperature gradients.
Description B: Thermoreceptors are excited by Piezo2 ion channels gated by compression or stretch.

Description A: The dorsal column–medial lemniscal system transmits tactile and proprioceptive information to the thalamus.
Description B: The dorsal column–medial lemniscal system transmits pain and thermal information to the spinal cord.

Description A: The Tomb of the Dancers contains six painted panels depicting 30 dancing women moving with arms interlocked.
Description B: The Tomb of the Dancers contains eight painted panels depicting 40 dancing women moving with arms interlocked.

Description A: The skeletal remains in the Tomb of the Dancers belonged to a distinguished male warrior.
Description B: The skeletal remains in the Tomb of the Dancers belonged to a female dancer.

Description A: The panels from the Tomb of the Dancers are now exhibited in the Naples National Archaeological Museum, inventory number 9353.
Description B: The panels from the Tomb of the Dancers are now exhibited in the Louvre Museum, inventory number 9353.

Description A: The Tomb of the Dancers has a semi-chamber design.
Description B: The Tomb of the Dancers has a fully open design.

Description A: The frescoes in the Tomb of the Dancers illustrate women dancing in a circle around the tomb’s interior.
Description B: The frescoes in the Tomb of the Dancers illustrate men engaged in combat around the tomb’s interior.

Description A: Voluntary movements are generated by neural circuits spanning different levels of sensory and motor hierarchies.
Description B: Reflexive movements are generated by neural circuits spanning different levels of sensory and motor hierarchies.

Description A: Noise is present at all stages of sensorimotor control, from sensory processing to motor outputs.
Description B: Noise only occurs in motor outputs and does not affect sensory processing.

Description A: Time delays in the sensorimotor system can be on the order of 100 ms and depend on the sensory modality involved.
Description B: Time delays in the sensorimotor system are always less than 10 ms, irrespective of sensory modality.

Description A: Spinal reflexes like the monosynaptic stretch reflex have a latency of around 25 ms.
Description B: Spinal reflexes like the monosynaptic stretch reflex have a latency of over 100 ms.

Description A: The basal ganglia and cerebellum are subcortical areas involved in voluntary movement control.
Description B: The basal ganglia and prefrontal cortex are subcortical areas involved in voluntary movement control.

Description A: Receptor adaptation reduces the neural response to a constant stimulus over time, eventually causing the sensation to fade from consciousness.
Description B: Receptor adaptation prevents sensory neurons from responding to prolonged stimuli, ensuring that sensation persists continuously.

Description A: Rod cells in the retina are activated by very low light levels and reach their maximal firing rates in dim daylight.
Description B: Rod cells in the retina are activated by bright light and reach their maximal firing rates in direct sunlight.

Description A: Cone cells do not respond in very dim light but report differences in daylight brightness, allowing us to perceive colors.
Description B: Cone cells respond primarily in very dim light, enabling the perception of colors in total darkness.

Description A: Slowly adapting receptors encode stimulus duration by generating action potentials consistently throughout prolonged stimulation.
Description B: Slowly adapting receptors fail to encode stimulus durations as they only fire when stimuli are applied initially.

Description A: Rapidly adapting sensors fire at the beginning and end of a stimulus, ceasing activity during steady stimulation.
Description B: Rapidly adapting sensors fire continuously throughout the duration of a constant stimulus.

Description A: The receptive field of a sensory neuron defines the region of skin or sensory organ where stimuli evoke neural responses.
Description B: The receptive field of a sensory neuron refers to the entirety of the brain area where stimuli evoke responses.

Description A: Sensory neurons within the fovea have smaller receptive fields due to high receptor density, enabling greater visual detail.
Description B: Sensory neurons within the fovea have larger receptive fields due to high receptor density, reducing visual detail.

Description A: Topographic organization in sensory systems preserves spatial relationships of receptor neurons in early processing stages.
Description B: Topographic organization in sensory systems disrupts spatial relationships between receptor neurons in early processing stages.

Description A: Parallel processing in sensory pathways allows for massive combinations of neural activity, greatly exceeding the number of atoms in the universe.
Description B: Parallel processing in sensory pathways limits neural activity to simple patterns, far fewer in number than atoms in the universe.

Description A: Ventral pathways process sensory information needed for object recognition and classification in the temporal cortex.
Description B: Ventral pathways process sensory information needed for motor decisions and actions in the frontal cortex.

Description A: At chemical synapses, the presynaptic terminal and the postsynaptic neuron are separated by a synaptic cleft.
Description B: At chemical synapses, the presynaptic terminal and the postsynaptic neuron are directly connected by gap-junction channels.

Description A: Ionotropic receptors function as ion channels that open when a neurotransmitter binds to them.
Description B: Ionotropic receptors indirectly control ion channels through second-messenger cascades when a neurotransmitter binds to them.

Description A: Chemical synapses can amplify neuronal signals, even allowing small presynaptic nerve terminals to affect large postsynaptic cells.
Description B: Chemical synapses only transmit signals passively like electrical synapses and cannot amplify neuronal signals.

Description A: Synapses were first described histologically by Ramón y Cajal using light microscopy in the late 19th century.
Description B: Synapses were first discovered using electron microscopy in the late 19th century.

Description A: Synaptic delay at chemical synapses is caused by processes such as neurotransmitter release and receptor binding.
Description B: Synaptic delay at chemical synapses is absent due to direct ion flow between cells.

Description A: Electrical synapses allow bidirectional transmission with virtually no synaptic delay.
Description B: Electrical synapses allow unidirectional transmission with significant synaptic delay.

Description A: Connexons in gap-junction channels are composed of six identical subunits called connexins.
Description B: Connexons in gap-junction channels are composed of eight identical subunits called connexins.

Description A: Neurotransmitter identity does not exclusively determine the excitatory or inhibitory response; receptor properties influence the signal type.
Description B: Neurotransmitter identity universally determines whether a signal is excitatory or inhibitory, regardless of receptor properties.

Description A: Chemical synapses commonly feature presynaptic vesicles, active zones, and postsynaptic receptors.
Description B: Chemical synapses are primarily composed of electrical channels without presynaptic vesicles or receptors.

Description A: Electrical synapses were first demonstrated in the giant motor synapse of the crayfish.
Description B: Chemical synapses were first demonstrated in the giant motor synapse of the crayfish.

Description A: The basal ganglia are an essential component of brain architecture that have been retained for more than 500 million years.
Description B: The basal ganglia are a non-essential component of brain architecture and only appeared in the last 50 million years.

Description A: The Subthalamic Nucleus is traditionally considered an important internal relay in the indirect pathway but is now also recognized as a major input nucleus of the basal ganglia.
Description B: The Subthalamic Nucleus is traditionally considered an important direct pathway and has no known input role within the basal ganglia.

Description A: The striatum, subthalamic nucleus, and substantia nigra pars compacta are the three major input nuclei of the basal ganglia.
Description B: The striatum, subthalamic nucleus, and internal globus pallidus are the three major input nuclei of the basal ganglia.

Description A: Disinhibition is the final expression of basal ganglia output, allowing targeted regions to influence behavioral output.
Description B: Excitation is the final expression of basal ganglia output, ensuring suppression of behavioral options.

Description A: Parkinson Disease can be viewed as a failure to select sensorimotor options.
Description B: Parkinson Disease arises from an over-selection of sensorimotor options.

Description A: The external globus pallidus is an intrinsic structure that mostly interacts with other basal ganglia nuclei.
Description B: The external globus pallidus is an output structure that mostly interacts with regions outside the basal ganglia.

Description A: Medium spiny neurons, the principal cell type of the striatum, are inhibitory and co-localize GABAergic and peptidergic neurotransmission.
Description B: Medium spiny neurons, the principal cell type of the striatum, are excitatory and regulate glutamatergic neurotransmission at high frequency.

Description A: Reentrant loops, a cardinal principle of basal ganglia circuitry, allow information to flow between the basal ganglia and cortical regions.
Description B: Reentrant loops, a cardinal principle of basal ganglia circuitry, only operate within basal ganglia nuclei without any cortical involvement.

Description A: The striatum receives both synaptic and non-synaptic dopaminergic input, contributing to both precise and diffuse signal modulation.
Description B: The striatum receives only synaptic dopaminergic input, ensuring strictly precise signal processing.

Description A: Reinforcement learning is an inherent property of the basal ganglia’s selection architecture.
Description B: Reinforcement learning is unrelated to the basal ganglia’s selection architecture.

Description A: The fovea is where vision is sharpest, and the density of photoreceptors, bipolar cells, and ganglion cells is highest.
Description B: The optic disc is where vision is sharpest, and the density of photoreceptors, bipolar cells, and ganglion cells is highest.

Description A: The blind spot corresponds to the area of the retina devoid of photoreceptors, caused by the optic nerve exit.
Description B: The foveola corresponds to the area of the retina devoid of photoreceptors, caused by the optic nerve exit.

Description A: Rods and cones are distinguished by their morphology, with rods having long cylindrical outer segments and cones having shorter tapered outer segments.
Description B: Rods and cones are indistinguishable by their morphology, both having identical outer and inner segment structures.

Description A: The outer segment of photoreceptors is located at the distal surface of the neural retina, where phototransduction begins.
Description B: The inner segment of photoreceptors is located at the distal surface of the neural retina, where phototransduction begins.

Description A: In the foveola, layers of the retina are pushed aside to allow direct access of light to the photoreceptors.
Description B: In the optic disc, layers of the retina are pushed aside to allow direct access of light to the photoreceptors.

Description A: Horizontal cells in the outer synaptic layer provide lateral inhibition in retinal circuitry.
Description B: Horizontal cells in the ganglion cell layer provide lateral inhibition in retinal circuitry.

Description A: The optic nerve is formed by the axons of retinal ganglion cells.
Description B: The optic nerve is formed by the axons of bipolar cells.

Description A: The retina adjusts its sensitivity to changing illumination to maintain stable vision.
Description B: The retina adjusts its sensitivity to changing illumination to maintain unstable vision.

Description A: The retina contains specialized connections provided by horizontal cells and amacrine cells.
Description B: The retina contains specialized connections provided solely by bipolar cells.

Description A: Horizontal connections in the retina involve electrical synapses and glutamatergic synapses.
Description B: Horizontal connections in the retina involve glycinergic synapses exclusively.
